pros: Good company to work for.  Well respected and has a recognizable brand.  Values employees and the contributions they bring.  Values doing what is right for the customer and doing it right the first time.  I enjoyed the people I worked with.  I enjoyed the leadership and the direction given.
cons: In an exempt position, the hours usually run over 40/week.  Sometimes a great idea gets pushed through before it has been fully tested or piloted.  This can be challenging at times as you have to make adjustments in a live environment rather than a test environment.

review_title: it was the best experience I had when I look back and compare all the jobs I told in the last 26 years.
job_title: Mortgage Underwriter in Costa Mesa, CA
pros: the customer service and the fact we always worked with others in team work to get the job done correctly and value the customer all the time. I remember we had to send the customer letter afterword and thanking them for the business.
cons: Non that I recall, I wish I could have been working there now and if they give a chance I will go back and work as an underwriter, I have 26 year of banking and underwriting experience and will be the employee they want to hire.

review_title: Great if it Wasn't just about Sales
job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Houston, TX
pros:
People are genuinely friendly
Encouragement and support structure are awesome in the experience's I've had. 
Co-workers have been some of the nicest and honest people I have ever worked with
Career opportunities are plentiful
cons:
Everything rides on what sales you have
Does not matter if you are in a market saturated with nothing but Wells Fargo. Sales are expected
This leads to bankers doing shady things to make numbers so they can make bonuses or not get fired. 
Say that everything is about the customers but fail to realize that not all customer's need 100 products.

job_title: Inbound Sales Specialist in Roanoke, VA
pros:
A lot of time off (Paid and sick)
Benefits
Pay with commission is good if you don't have a degree...
A lot of room to grow (I am currently being advised by someone who had my job for 4 months)
cons:
Sales goals are crazy hard, but if you reach them, you get promoted very quick.
Too many regulations to follow, our ability to meet with such detailed regulations and getting points knocked off (resulting in lower commission) is kind of bogus. 
AHT (Average Handling Time) is very low. Some loans take 45 minutes to an hour, let's not talk about home equity, but our AHT has to be around 10 minutes per call on average...

review_title: Its all about numbers here, you don't sell, you don't survive.
pros: They give you PTO, good 401k, and decent benefits.
cons: NUMBERS NUMBER NUMBERS!! At training they make you believe its all about the customers but once you start working in your assigned branch, all they care about is you selling everything single kind of product Wells has to offer. Even if the customer does not need a particular service/account, you better sell it!! If you like high stress work environments this is the place for you.

review_title: Good stepping stone, poor long term options.
job_title: Wholesale Banking Consultant in Charlotte, NC
pros: Lot's of opportunities to gain experience. Decent work life balance, but that goes away the higher up you go. But that is expected.
cons: Internal politics incent poor behavior on part of management. Cut throat. No job security even if you perform.

review_title: Not the company I thought it was
pros: Decent benefits including 401k plan
cons: Management above following same rules set in place for the team.  Improper training and inconsistent policies.  Entirely too much micromanagement by upper management.  More concerned about the almighty dollar than serving the customer.

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Santa Ana, CA
pros: Reputation built on name recognition helps with individual customers, often very good individual people working within the organization.
cons: The very good individuals are generally not in positions of authority those positions are permanently reserved for the "yes men" of management. Pro's reputation of name recognition goes out the window for anyone that has ever used this bank for anything but the most basic of services . Most professional organizations know WF is a huge marketing budget but offers very little quality.

review_title: IT Support - As good or bad as the manager and management tree you work under.
job_title: IT Support in San Francisco, CA
pros: Time off - They lump both sick leave and vacation together which left me with 5-6 weeks PTO per year.  The management trees I worked under really worked us to death but I had friends in different management trees that had managable workloads.
cons: I worked for weak management that said yes to everything.  During the financial crisis there was a  hiring freeze and reorgs so we wound up supporting many more users with fewer people.  They really worked us to death but that is because of the management I was under.

job_title: Regional Bank Private Banker in South Florida, FL
pros: Strong training program and support from the training department and office.  Made me an hourly employee and i received over time....
cons: Seemed like a bait and switch with the comp program.  It changed the week after I started.  You would think the recruiters would have known this.  Treated like an hourly employee.  Did not allow me to attend networking events so that I could be in the branch helping open $100.00 checking accounts and limit overtime.

pros: I enjoyed working there and was hopeful to establish myself. I was asked several times by a non-conforming mgr to come to work on her team but at the time I was not ready to make the move. I was still trying to get my lending authority for conforming.
cons: I was laid off and applied for non-conforming jobs twice and was not hired on. How could they want me so bad then but not when I applied.

pros: Amazing benefits for full-time team members! From coupons for everyday life that makes your savings grow to all the legal, financial, medical and more. Great network of store managers, District managers and all team members of up above. Very customer experience orientated coaching. Amazing company to work for in the NW. Always room to grow in this company, many open opportunities to succeed fast.
cons:
They don't like paying you in overtime even when its desperatly needed in times of other team member achievements/ promotions. 
High demand in sales goals when trying to accompany what each individual needs.

job_title: Customer Service/Sales Representative in Saint Augustine, FL
pros: great leadership and growth opportunities are you make your way through the company - competitive compensation and benefits many locations around us
cons: often low man on totem pole until you have an advocate that has some power and authority with out that helping hand often tie you are stuck in the same position - lack of vision and leadership at retail branches - many times messages of why gets lost in translation and focus becomes sales numbers and goals

pros: flexible, good benefits for team members. Great perks still like a lot of days paid for to be off. Do not have to work all weekends if you are at a branch thats open on weekends
cons: aggressive goals, hard to promote past retail, takes away from enjoying your job when they only want to knowhow much you have produced. The company only sees its employees as revenue drivers, and if you are not driving accounts they will figure out a way to push you out of the company

pros: A lot of opportunities for advancement in different lines of business due to the size and locations of the bank.
cons:
Micromanagement - consistently monitoring employees to the point that it can become difficult to do job
Sales pressure - all the stories about sales ethics and pressure are true
Low salary - way below national average for banking salaries

pros: They provide great pay with bonuses and benefits. Wells Fargo is the best company to work for if you have a family. They are the one company that puts family first. Love, Love, Love Wells Fargo!
cons: The process of moving up within the company, having to wait 12 months, and the transfer policy.

review_title: Good place to learn, but depends on manager
pros:
Good place to learn all about sales, customer service
Service managers and coworkers were very helpful
Good chance to move to a different branch with more traffic and more referral opportunity.
cons:
Branch manager didn't really care about the team and didn't care if you are good at sales. 

Offered me promotion  but went with another person and didn't tell me on purpose for a long time and never called me back.

pros:
Best thing about Wells Fargo is work life balance. I'd suggest people to wait for opportunities as the process internally is slow. Everyone will get a chance to work on upcoming technologies and will be able to develop exceptional skill related to capital markets provided they re are a part of capital market business
Awesome work life balance, work from home.
cons: Not a lot of freedom in terms of decision making as the final call will be made by stateside partners.

job_title: Phone Banker II in Sioux Falls, SD
pros:
Here is some pros
Advancement, They give you the tools you need to be success
Friendly Environment: Co-workers, Team Lead, and upper management all want you succeed and will give great advice on how to achieve that.
Training: Wells Fargo has one of the greatest training i've ever seen, they take some of their most veteran employees and have them assist the new employees
cons: Cons:  My opinion is this, there are always bad stuff about a business. As working for Wells Fargo i have not experienced any cons

review_title: While it was stressful during working there, it was good moment of my life as well.
job_title: Customer Service Associate in San Fernando, CA
pros: Paid training. Nice people to work with.
cons: Low wages, less benefits. The branch assigned to me is way too far from where I live (more than 40 miles).  In stead of assigning me to a community where my bilingual ability can benefit the company, they put me where I had no way to use my ability. The management pushed everyone to solicit customers to open more accounts if you don't have customers open more accounts, your job will be in jeopardy.

job_title: Research/Remediation Analyst I in West Des Moines, IA
pros: Good benefits of health insurance, 401K, and paid time off. 2 paid volunteer days each year and 8 paid holidays.
cons: Constant issues with management and operations across multiple departments. Very vague in management direction, they don't give solid answers and are not always helpful to provide solutions. No paid sick days, if you call off 3 times in a six month period, you're out. Not a lot of flexibility for sick time in that regard or for emergencies that arise.

pros: Company cares about it employees and its customers. You can work your way up without a degree.  Many opportunities for growth.  4.6 weeks of paid time off (PTO) by your 3rd calendar year,  in addition to 8 days of paid holidays.
cons: You're underpaid for the industry, even with a degree because anyone can work their way up in the company without one and could potentially even get higher pay.

pros: i love working for wells fargo the company itself and interacting with our customers that call in everyday .
cons: i had constantly problem with wells fargo when it was time to be paid one time i went 3 weeks without been paid due to unprofessional processing document in the adp payroll department which is so not right after being involved in  142.billion lawsuit class act they play with people money to much complaints about our customers account being hacked and fraud and account set up with incorrect information that was nevered authorized through the party alot of wrong business going on and i think they should adhere and be responsible for every action thats was taking placed .

review_title: If you like meetings and conference calls, this place is for you
pros: Benefits are OK. PTO could be better for mid-career hires.
cons:
There is an amazing amount of time and manpower spent on meetings, conference calls and training that is totally unrelated to your job. At the same time, you may not receive the tools and training required to do your job. Technology is also incredibly out-of-date.
Managers seem to spend a lot of time worrying about irrelevant details and don't have any time to do any work. That means they either work crazy hours or don't actually accomplish anything.

review_title: Not so good as the name suggests
pros:
Campus Facilities are good
Health insurance coverage for employees and dependents
Flexi working hours
cons:
Transport facilities are bad also parking is not provided if you dont book your slot 3 months in advance.
Uses old technologies and U.S partners not supportive of using latest technologies and new ideas
Does not follow industry's best practices
HR personnels not reliable.

pros: Not much. I had some great colleagues that were wonderful.
cons: Incredibly political. People were promoted who met sales goals by any means possible, including unethical means. There wasn5 any meaningful leadership. Management directed me more than once to direct clients to brokerage who would have been better served on the fiduciary platform. I disagreed because it was unethical and I refused to put my law license at risk by advising clients against their best interest.  After refusing, management made my work life so stressful that my only option was to look for another position in another geographical area. Leaving that company was the best decision I ever made.

job_title: Business Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: If you're lucky and are reporting to a good manager there's lots of support and flexibility. For the most part you leave the work behind on the weekends and evenings.
cons: Pay is below average, the mobility is limited and there are no perks, no fancy holiday parties where you can bring your partner, no team building activities or anything of the sort. Your every move is monitored and most of the web is blocked.

pros: Learning the ins and outs of the vault and gaining experience as a bank teller on the teller line
cons:
No respect for my job title
No opportunities for advancement
Leading you on to think you will move your way up
Upper management treats you unprofessionally
I recommend working at another bank if you want to work your way up into other roles.

review_title: The best job I've ever had
pros: I loved working at Wells Fargo. It may have been because I was at a great branch with awesome coworkers and managers, but I always felt right at home there. Customers could be difficult sometimes but my boss was always there to back me up. The company is also pretty good, I did enjoy the efforts on team building. They also had a great PTO plan and benefits.
cons: I think they could improve more with the salary though - they give a menial raise each year which only ends up being an extra 30 cents or something. I did enjoy the efforts on team building and such.

job_title: Registered Personal Banker in Denver, CO
pros: If management likes you, you'll like the good work environment. You meet great people while growing professionally and as an indiviual. Great co workers too.
cons: Procedures constantly changing and new ones are constantly implemented. Company continues to change its outlook per the sales scandal in 2017. Sometimes, the most overpaid are the employees that work the least. Internal growth can be prolonged at times due to "performance" metrics that are not within your control. New Collegues replace the old ones more frequently than normal due to better pay externally.

pros: The employee benefits are very comprehensive.  Be careful though -- they become a bit of a handcuff and people stay longer than they should because of the benefits.
cons: Wells Fargo doesn't penalize people for their incompetence.  Management is very cowardly in dealing with people who do not do their job well.  Perhaps this is a good thing, if you are unqualified for what you are being paid, but it is frustrating for those left behind to do all the work.

review_title: Not Perfect, but a great place to start out.
job_title: Customer Service Representative III in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: Great  atmosphere among assigned workgroup. Very fast paced; no two days ever really the same. I greatly enjoyed working with assigned account base. The health benefits are great and really affordable. PTO plan is one of the best I've ever seen. Monthly one-on-one reviews with supervisor were very helpful.
cons: A lot of good ideas often tanked due to poor execution. Poor communication and interactions between customer service teams and other departments. Too many accounts for each account manager.

review_title: Proud to work for Wells Fargo
job_title: Personal Banker Registered in Dallas, TX
pros: Career growth.  Easy to transfer to other states.  Good benefits:  6% match on 401k.  Friendly staff & management .  Strong company – you know they will be around for a long time.  They have great recognition events each year for the top performers.  All expense paid trips for you and a guest to places like Hawaii, Cancun, & Disneyworld in FL.
cons: Stressful at times.  If you are not a salesperson you may not like working at Wells Fargo.

review_title: Good Experience but wouldn't do it again
pros: It's an ok job for a college student, but I wouldn't stay any longer than is needed.
cons: Horrible people, complaining all the time like its our fault they overdrafted their account 20 times in one week.  They also do not work with school schedules well.  Make you work a mandatory 20hrs a week which either has to be morning hours or afternoon hours which can be difficult if you are trying to take classes with certain teachers.

review_title: Wells Fargo is a big bank culture, but truly respects diversity
pros: Competitive benefits, respect for diversity, and employee centric culture.  In individual situations, the human resources department will give more power to the employee rather than the manager, which is rare.
cons: Typical politics are at play here. Banks are very hard to work for if you are a maverick.  Just remember you have to conform to the corporate norms in certain ways, and you'll be fine.

review_title: Wells Fargo is great for "backroom" team members
job_title: Management Metrics Analyst I  in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Wells Fargo is a good place to work because the benefits seem pretty good and there are a lot of opportunities for advancement. There are a lot of very good bosses with Wells too. I've been here 11 years and haven't had a bad one.
cons: Working in the front room (i.e. the branches) can be difficult if you don't like sales and goals. Wells is very much a sales organization and you need to meet your numbers, whether you're a teller, banker or manager.

job_title: Registered Brokerage Banker in Los Angeles, CA
pros: They are well-managed. They were not involved in any of the excessive debt and equity securities that caused the financial meltdown in 2008. Although during the mortgage boom time, every firm made huge fortune in mortgage backed securities and CDOs, Wells Fargo stayed away from those securities.
cons: At the end, it's corporate America. With over 300,000 employees after Wachovia acquisition, really you're just a number in the company. Also, on retail banking side, some of the bankers are really not that knowledgeable. They don't know the basic financial terms and all they do is pushing products. They should be more selective with their employees.

review_title: Stay for a while, enjoy the visit but move on for something serious eventually
pros: It 's a great place to start out of college. They offer a competitive entry level salary.
cons: The pay does not increase over time.  They do not give big raises to employees who have stayed around for a while.   They believe that you are valued and therefore they do not need to earn you.  Honestly, work somewhere else once you have put two years in.

job_title: Accountant II  in San Francisco, CA
pros: If you want job security and like being told what to do. Benefits are good.
cons: Company is very centralized. Everything you do is scrutinized. Old school mentality.  Employees don't think outside the box. Salary is not so great.  Wells Fargo likes employees who just do what their told. Management not interested in asking for your opinion because they really don't care what you think.

pros: Great opportunities, good leadership, good work/life balance and community involvement. Passionate team members, very engaged and provide real value to customers,
cons: Being the 4th largest financial institution in the United States, has its downsides. For example, the entry level employees are not as well paid. Depending of the business unit, there are too many layers of management.

pros: Great benefits, Good compensation, bonus plan. Many employees are fantastic to work with and they are pretty much nationwide, so you can move.
cons:
Horrible Ethics regarding sales - sell to sell, not what's right for the customer. 
Blatant favoritism shown by management in regards to promotions, attitude, write-ups, recognition in every branch I've worked at. 
Managers who say one thing, and do another.

review_title: Lots of bureacracy, but lots of opportunities
pros: Solid business model that proved itself in the recent mortgage downturn. Committed to the customer. Strong history, probably the strongest bank in terms of future potential in the US, if not the world.
cons: Lots of changes still going on - still working on reducing the bureaucracy resulting from the recent Wachovia merger. Might be difficult for an external applicant to get their foot in the door because of the large number of people in the retention pool.

pros: Benefits, Salary and name recognition on resume
cons: Management only cares about solution (this is what they call a sale to a customer), If you close a loan or get a debit card same amount of solutions. Even though we get paid on the profit it generates the only care about widgets. Conference calls 3 times a day for check in and then you get blasted on the phone if we are not at were they want you.(you could have tripled production yesterday. Its what have you done for me today.

review_title: You are their racehorse - once you have run your races you will be sent to the glue factory.
pros: There are a large number of branches so you can usually work near your home so the travel time can be very short. It takes me 10 minutes to get to work
cons: It is difficult to be promoted if your manager dislikes you.  If you can not brown nose, you will not be promoted.

review_title: Great coworkers, but poor top down guidance and lack of direction.
pros: Supportive coworkers, some good managers, some who communicate.
cons: poor communication; poor processes; poor managers not held accountable.

review_title: not a place that develops growth, and micromanaging institution
pros: great collegues that are around. Some of my closest freinds may be some of my co-workers. The pay is fairly decent especially for someone right out of highschool
cons: its all sales sales sales. There is no real time to sit down with the client and the products getting pushed are not in their best interests.

review_title: It's all about Sales only!  Not employees or customers!  Run fast!!!
pros: Good starting salary. About 70k base plus comm for branch managers
cons: Its only about the numbers. First time you don't make them and they get you out.  Phone calls and emails are all monitored. They track you. You are expected to fire ur bankers if they don't make their numbers right away too.  They have no concept of loyalty. They r firing all women over 40. Bringing in a young boys club. I'm not just a disgruntled employee, I've worked t/o the conversions in the Bucks/Phila area for over 15 years. Wells is churning their clients accounts and secretly promotes it. Get on board with the shadyness or get out.

job_title: Personal Banker in Los Angeles, CA
pros: If you can sell dozens of accounts to one person. This could be a great job to you, they will promote quick if you can be one of the top sellers in your city.
cons: Wells Fargo takes advantage of a stiff economy to pressure the Personal Bankers into doing whatever it takes to hit their "numbers". Managers will threaten to fire you daily if you do not hit their obscenely high sales goals. Bankers are forced to open account after account for their family members and friends..January is another story...I don't even know how what they are trying to achieve is legal.

review_title: Great opportunity to help consumers and businesses, but challenging to maintain quotas
pros:
Working at a bank gives you a sort of local authority, I feel. Since you're dealing with their money, most people listen to you.

There's a lot of opportunity for growth, if you're willing to follow the road map provided for you.
cons:
The teller counter is a tough place to make sales pitches, and management doesn't think it should be. 

There are high expectations on banks, and if you don't satisfy people they have a fit.

pros: Resources for any and every question or problem you might ever have.
cons: Closing a loan on time is not the norm for them. Reputation they have with other companies in the business is horrible. Almost embarassing to say you work for them. Layoffs are all the time. They get the team built up and then it slows down a little bit and they lay them all off. Then they don't have the manpower to close loans because they are either training a new batch or just laid them all off.

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Competitive pay, work life balance (depending on where you work).  Great name for relationship building. Have great programs, and  flexible guidelines for loans. Great underwriters, looking to approve loans if possible. They give you enough freedom to develop your book of business your own way and establish your referral channels.   You have access to assigned branches book of business and management will even consider assisting in newspaper/internet ads if you make a good case. In other words they are thinking outside the box, and allow you to do business how you best see it fit, not only through their established channels.
cons: Draw + commission compensation can be challenging, but also very rewarding.

review_title: I was frustrated almost every day after work.
pros: Outstanding benefits.  Good pay potential for those who put in the time and effort to close a lot of loans.  As the largest mortgage company in the US, you do have the opportunity to benefit from internal leads.
cons: Initial training is OK, but once you start working in your branch, don't ever ask your boss for help because this is a cardinal sin at this company.  The "back office" operations end of the mortgage department is wholly incompetent and getting a loan closed takes forever.

pros: Large company with different career opportunities if you want to explore various departments
cons: Company going through major merger/consolidation/offshoring.  Aggressive schedule to meet upper management deadlines seemed more important than retaining quality of work and employee morale.  Resulted in overworked and overlooked team members and some inefficient processes and systems due to rush to meet deadlines and push for changes/automation.  Poor communication from upper management of what to expect of job outlook once consolidation was complete.  Offshoring = layoffs for some.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Great base salary
Room for growth, can potentially obtain a new position every year
Great benefits 401K, PTO and Health
Big company, can transfer anywhere in the country and still have a job
cons:
Never ending sales pressure
Non existent commission ex. $500 total for 3 months of sales work
Unable to view your incentive payout until 2 weeks after the quarter has ended
If you are good at sales they will block you from applying to non sales positions within the company
Management is in a protected class, if you call HR or Ethics it will  only hurt you and not them

job_title: Systems QA Analyst II in San Francisco, CA
pros: The work is not incredibly difficult but is challenging enough to not get bored. The people are all pretty much great, never had any problems. It's very easy to develop and move around within the company whether it be pure promotion or keeping your role but with a different group or leaving your role and group entirely. It's also a safe company where I have no fears of being laid off.
cons: Work can become redundant and if you're too efficient it can get boring if you don't seek out more varied work or projects.

pros:
Great Pay
Very rare in my experience, but great leadership at the location I worked
Flexible with hours, PTO, ect
cons: When I first started with the company, I started at the entry level positions, they step on you and treat you like crap unless you suck up basically.  I have seen it happen time and time again to fellow co workers.

job_title: Bankruptcy Team Lead in Raleigh, NC
pros: Leadership has improved dramatically. They are looking for smart and hardworking staff that are looking to improve themselves. There are a lot of different tools like the learning center that go underutilized that bring more to the company than most people take advantage of.
cons: The pay is not great for the amount of work that you do. There is a lot of running to take care of problems that doesn't always pan out. They will not get rid of people that do not perform. It is a very quiet work environment, and team members would rather eat alone than with one another.

pros: the company has great vision and values, benefits, and great team members. there are many locations and very flexible if you want to transfer or move to another state.
cons: retail banking - managers don't know how to treat people like humans, instead they treat their team members like a number and all they care about is the sale. a lot of the store managers are all about "I" instead of "WE". managers will favorite a person and go above and beyond for them but anyone else they don't favor, they will treat them like they don't matter.

review_title: Great place to work and build a career!
job_title: Learning & Development Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: This is a great place to work for those who are looking to build a career. So many opportunities are there, for moving around, for learning new things. I was mid-career/late-career and wish I had found Wells Fargo sooner. Senior leaders in my area cared about people and worked with them if there was a bad job fit to find something different -- not common in corporate these days.
cons: As with most places, there can be some favoritism, but it's not a career-ender or limiter. Very few cons to working here.

pros: Very structured, they have a formula that they want you to follow and you should be successful if you can follow it closely. There are so many bank customers that you always have opportunity for leads.
cons: The structure can be frustrating to follow. The loan officers are paid so little on their loans especially the bank leads that it is difficult to recruit quality loan officers. The matrix for manager pay is very difficult in a small market as well.

job_title: Business Banking Specialist in Tucson, AZ
pros: Great company who's overall culture is to help their customers succeed financially. Flexible schedules, internal resources for financial education, training, 401k, employee rate discounts. Easy to advance up.
cons: Majority of sales are not value driven but rather widget pushed. IES report is ineffective and unreliable. Too much movement for bankers and customers to establish a relationship.

job_title: Product Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Offers great opportunities to work in difference team environments.  Celebrates diversity and many positions have flexible work-life balance features.  Benefits are somewhat competitive with 401k matching.
cons: The actual salaries tend to be on par or a little less than the competition and annual raises are generally at or below the rate of inflation.  Changing jobs is critical to salary growth and career advancement.

pros: Wells Fargo is a great place to intern as well as start out a career in finance.  The teams very inclusive.  They welcome diversity as well one the new interns exploring other career options during the summer, networking with other team members.
cons: The pay is a little on the low side.  It was a little challenging to stay busy during the internship, and to feel that one provided enough value to their respective team.

review_title: Too stressful for the low pay
pros: Thought that there was upward mobilty
cons: The retail side is extremely stressful and competitive, You have to outperform everyone including yourself (from last quarter/month/week) and maintain perfect "shops" - if you do not, you may not be going anywhere within the company. The pressure to sale sale sale is constant and over the top. They say you have benefits like PTO etc but try to actually take your PTO, that's a whole other issue.

pros:
I was with Wells Fargo Advisors, a subsidiary of Wells Fargo Bank. 
When I joined in 2008 the company was Wachovia Securities. 
There was a blitz in rebranding and good momentum with new owner. 
We had an expanded platform from which to work.
cons: I was charged with building an advisory practice from scratch as a solo practitioner.  Despite thoroughness of training program it was often hard to secure good clients.  Working as part of a team might have been better for me.

review_title: Wholesale Banking is a caste system
job_title: Corporate Banking Relationship Associate in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Salary was competitive, customers were great, 401K and time off good. Wells does a good job with work/life balance and community involvement.
cons: Senior management entrenched in the old ways, old guard; no formal training or leadership program for managers; caste system in Wholesale Banking making it impossible to move from operations to lending. Incompetence and favortism rampant in upper management. Consistent and pervasive organizational behavior that is top down, reactive, short sighted, absolutely no concept of looking at the long term or long run. Approach to sales is short term with no focus on retention.

review_title: Great place to begin your career experience...
job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in Orlando, FL
pros: The company is well-known.  All the benefits you would want from a company such as health, accidental death and dismemberment, 401k matching, and stock purchasing program.  Corporate discounts can be found for most common commodities like cell phone plans and what not.  There are many entry level positions with little-to-no experience or degrees as long as you have the right attitude and can be coached for your role/responsibilities.  Company will accommodate most schedule changing needs if you've been with the company long enough or if the right people like you.  Lots of opportunity for growth and to explore other areas of the company as they like to promote within.  Pay can be negotiated.  People who are driven will like the environment.  Customer focused.
cons:
Location and your management is a huge factor (like most jobs) on your overall satisfaction with the company.  Though, it is, a pro to negotiate your pay, you will find that they will try to justify the lower than average pay.  There is a report for everything...there is a report for checking reports.  There are meetings about checking reports.  If you're low on numbers, which, is a huge focus, the stress amps up.  I feel a good number of upper management cares about you, but, there is a unrealistic expectation of your daily activities.  Most of the time I find that immediate managers are under stress from upper management resulting in conflicting outlooks of how things should be done.

Support is available in all areas, but, the process of getting to the right people can be frustrating at times.

pros: They have good benefits. The pay is well. Paid Vacation. A good part time job for college students. Teaches you how to multi task. Quick growth within the company.
cons: Very competitive. Standing all day. Company pressures you to follow a specific script that sounds robotic. Within the branch the management pressured tellers to sell products even though that was not the job description of a tell, a tellers job is to provide the best costumer service.

pros: I was a Bank Teller for Wells Fargo for six months. From the moment I got hired, I instantaneously fell in love with my coworkers and managers. My first day was very informative of how the job works and afterwards, I was treated to a free lunch. Training is two weeks long in front of a computer. A LOT of information, so try to take notes. The job itself is like any other customer service job. You help customers with their banking needs while also trying to figure out ways to further assist them with their finances. Managers and Bankers try to push you to get those referrals, but the goals aren't unrealistic and pretty easy to achieve if you actually put some effort into it. My coworkers were like my family, going above and beyond to help each other out not only with work, but with our personal lives as well. Even the monthly meetings were fun, being 75% role playing games and getting to know each other and 25% actual business talk.
cons: Work life balance kind of sucks. If you work full-time, you're most likely working open to close six days a week with Sunday being your only guaranteed day off. And although referral goals aren't outrageous, it can get a little frustrating when your manager gets more pushy than necessary.

job_title: Analytic Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Big company, so there are many career opportunities to choose from.  CEO has the right idea and right message, putting customers first, holding solid ethics, and viewing team members as competitive advantage.

Job security is great.  Layoffs are an inevitability of any company, but this one handles them well with decent severance package, and having an inventory of jobs available to any employee affected by layoffs
cons: Same inevitable pitfalls of any large company.  Siloed, specialized job skills and tasks.  Benefits have degraded a bit to almost average

pros: WF promotes its own people to advance and make a career and provides the right tools to exceed customers' expectations. In the top of that the benefits are great and you can find WF stores everywhere (40 States) in one is planning to transfer.
cons: We cannot use emails to follow up with customers, the fees for our services; hr rate and commissions are kinda low and the new Insurance company partner takes too long to answer calls when we have a customer interested in saving money.

job_title: Phone Banker II in Glen Allen, VA
pros: PTO, good benefits, encouraged to advance, hire within, large company, diverse environment, good infrastructure, systems and research materials.  Volunteer activities.
cons: Sales over customer service.   Despite 6 weeks training, not enough focus on learning how to service clients.  Can't be expected to develop report with a customer if you don't know how to help them.  Also not encouraged to transfer a customer to a supervisor, instead to de-escalate.  This only angers the customer more.

review_title: Working for Wells Fargo definitely has it's perks with benefits and a nice work schedule as a teller.
pros: The good reasons to work here is a good way to get started in the financial world and getting to know how the banking world works. It teaches you a lot about financing and gets you going in the right path.
cons: The only cons I see of working here is that sometimes the work schedule can't be as flexible and moving up can be a challenge is you don't push yourself to move up.

pros: Great place to work with wonderful benefits. If you are lucky enough to get a good manager you will actually learn and be very successful. It all depends on the manager.
cons: It is very important to have the right person to lead you. If your manager is not good enough to lead you and teach you you might be set to a failure.

job_title: Personal Banker/Loan Originator in Atlanta, GA
pros: There aren't any not one!!!
cons: Everything that they're saying in the news is absolutely true Branch Mgrs bully you and the customers or simply lie to get their numbers. They don't care genuinely about their customers unless you're an elite, they give credit so you'll forever owe them NO financial literacy period unless you're a heck of a Banker that care more about your customers/client than that piece of crap incentive. And another thing is they are very racist, and demographically placed to make the poor extremely poor and clueless. If you're not a butt kisser you'll NEVER make it with Wells!

review_title: Leaders give false income potentials during interview for new hires. Employees are not setup for success.
pros: Benefits for insurance,dental, are good. Tuition reimbursement but you have toxins out yourself how to take advantage of it. By the the time I found out how to get the benefits the timeline to get the benefit expired.
cons: Too many bad things coming out in the news making it hard to do business, and pay the bills for the average employee.

pros:
1. VTO (When calls are slow you have a chance to get off with earlier with no pay or occurrence) 
2. Lots of PTO given from day 1.... 144 hours!
3. Friendly environment
cons:
1. Poor commission structure
2. Too many procedures to remember (if you don't remember a procedure and you give a customer the wrong information you'll pretty much not qualify for any quarter bonus...which is at the most $500
3. PEOPLE ARENT GETTING PAID ENOUGH FOR WHAT THEY DO

job_title: Business Systems Consultant IV in Bangalore
pros:
1. Great work-life Balance.
2. Good Pay, above market average.
3. Lenient leave policy.
4. Great US partners to work with.
5. Great facilities.
cons:
1. Sluggish work pace.
2. Lot of old and experienced people with traditional thoughts, who hamper new thinking and possibilities.
3. Slowly turning into a service based company which has it's own problems.
4. Newer management recruits are low-grade and need to learn how to talk to people, let alone managing.
5. Too many re-orgs, which ends up disrupting work in-pipeline.
6. HR is lax in implementing policies when required.
7. Recruitment is a Big WTF!

review_title: First year was pretty good, killer benefits, ok compensation.
job_title: Field Service Representative in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Sign on bonus. Good benefits, 16 weeks paid paternity, vacation first year, no drug test, low supervision from managers. Get to make your own weekly schedule.
cons: Overnight travel 4-6 nights a month. WF does not provide company car. Drive 3600 miles a month (you make out ahead if done right).

job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in Denver, CO
pros: Great benefits, tons of opportunities for promotion...just have to wait for certain corporate policies to fall into effect. No more sales goals or pressure, yet still receive bonuses based on quarterly customer experience (surveys) and team performance.
cons: Base pay seems a little low compared to comp in my market. But, due to all the bad press, many changes are happening, and base pay likely will increase per position. Sacrificing a lot of service features (ie Coin Exchange Machines, Drive Up Tellers, etc) to save on expenses. Granted these two examples truly do cost a lot to maintain and repair, at which the company has made NO profit from either. With the amount of money lost during the past 6-8 months, one can't fault the company for making budget cuts where needed. Many customers do not understand the company's changes, and persist to complain at all costs, which makes a banker's job more stressful than it needs to be.

job_title: Full Time Teller in Mount Pleasant, SC
pros:
Great opportunities within the company.
Fun and exciting work environment.
Great benefits
401k with a match
Wells Fargo understands that by putting its employees first that we are in better positions to help our customers become successful financially.
cons: I have only been with the company for a little over a month so as of now I don’t have anything bad to say about the company. I guess I could say that I feel for anyone that had to deal with the sales driven version on Wells Fargo.

review_title: Little room for senior level growth
pros: No more sales goals.  If you want a steady low paying job and don't care about ever being promoted, you can find that.
cons: Managers aren't allowed to measure you against sales targets and don't know how to really manage people, so they don't give any direction and are making up metrics to measure you by.    We're still being led by all of the managers who got were pushing us with the sales goals that got WF into so much trouble.  That's what they were good at.

pros:
Lots of autonomy.
Nobody else had any idea what I was doing, conceptually or technically, so I got to make all the decisions.
It pays the bills.
cons: The environment fosters no incentive to provide quality work and the management reflects that. Most of the job consisted of avoiding blame, directed towards me and my immediate superiors. Nobody cared about fixing existing systemic problems, just immediate plausible-deniability. My manager spent most of her time chatting with friends. Raises and promotions are primarily based on years of experience. I suppose a lot of corporate jobs are like this, but it was new to me. Would recommend avoiding if you take pride in your work.

pros: Good benefits, great employee resources on hand
cons: Management will make a lot of promises, but they won't deliver. Promotions are joke when it comes to pay increase. There is a pay increase cap when you switch jobs or get promoted, they will not pay you what the job is worth. You will get paid a lot more if you leave the company and come back as new hire vs getting an internal promotion.

pros: I started atWells 5 years ago before the fall out with bank and auto practices.  The benefits are great, they have plenty of allowable vacation time, flexible working schedule, matching 401K, tuition reimbursement  and ability to move up, but only if you network and get to know people.
cons: Post the bank and auto scandals there has been a huge shift in organization.  New leaders come on board change everything and a year later they’re fired and you have to go through the same thing over and over again.  Annual raises are terrible and the whole bank follows a ridiculous code of 2-3% raises.  It’s pennies.  Bonuses are dependent on the entire business not your own work so if the business fails but you succeed... the bonuses are bases on the business alone.  It’s backwards.  Decision making takes forever but that’s expected of a company that size.  My opinion is there’s too many layers of management and no one is given the power to just make a decision.

review_title: Satisfaction Depends on the Team Around You
job_title: Business Systems Consultant V in Charlotte, NC
pros: Great benefits. Compensation better then most. Lost of areas of the bank to move into.
cons:
Even though there are hundreds of job postings, actually getting in front of a hiring manger is slim to none. Being as large as Wells is, you are small cog and basically helpless to change stupid stuff that goes on.
New leadership comes in every couple years and re-orgs everything.  Sometimes not for the better.

review_title: Wells Fargo - God Damn it's huge!
job_title: Applications Developer  in San Francisco, CA
pros: Wells Fargo has a great benifits package, and a lot of good growth opportunities.
cons: Mega - Bureaucracy. Sometimes it is really hard to get simple things done. It can be really difficult to navigate the giant corporate structure that is Wells Fargo. Often, just finding out who you have to talk to is have the battle of getting what you need to get done

review_title: Wells Fargo is a good place to work.
pros: They seem to really care about employess here. There are people that have spent 20+ years with WF because of the attitude.  When other financial institutions are laying people off, WF is doing what it can to, not only retain current employees, but hire new ones too.
cons: It is a BIG company!  And, with the economic situation the way it is, banking is going to be a place where you never know what will happen next.

review_title: Wells Fargo - Make sure you cross your T's, dot your I's and still CYA.
job_title: Assistant Vice President Business Deposit Consultant in Escondido, CA
pros: Large company with excellent benefits, Excellent ongoing training, Can move to other parts of the country and it is common for people to try many different types of jobs.
cons: You can get lost in the shuffle, H/R is too strict when it comes to policy - there is no gray area with them, inconsitencies when it comes to policy decisions - the same division can have two different sets of policy for a given issue.

pros: The training is good and your supervisor is always there to answer questions the hrs are good and the pay is not bad for the type of work.  The benefits are good if you use them.
cons: The sales can be a challenge being new to the company and with the economy being the way it is.  it's heard to sell new accounts to people that are scared to move there money.  But Cds are easy to sell with the stock market in the tank.

pros: Wells Fargo is one of the best companies to jump start you career. The opportunities and benefits are endless.  It is one of the only companies to provide paid time off for part time employees.  While getting my degree they were very understanding of my school schedule.  I definitely recommend working here if you a student or recent graduate.
cons: They push the sales a bunch and it can be difficult to achieve the goals. But that is about it.

pros: It isnt a very difficult job.  You are praised when you do a good job.  You have great benefits and a lot of opportunity to get promoted
cons: You call people all day everyday.  Every single day the goals and what is expected out of you changes.  The commission is difficult to get because you have to sell a certain amount of products and over a certain amount of money in volume before recieving anything which is extremely difficult to do.

review_title: Depends on your professional career level
job_title: Financial Consultant in Walnut Creek, CA
pros:
If you care to get your feet wet in an industry poised for growth or already have a productive book of business then you should try Wachovia Securities (which is now Wells Fargo Advisors).

Great beginning Financial Advisors program, licenses are paid for and mentoring is top notch.
Support staff is oustanding
Name recognition in and industry battered by change
cons:
Support staff are paid below market with enticement of bonuses that are non-existent
No performance recognition or promotion
Benefits available are below standard compared to several competing companies

review_title: OK Place to work, but room for improvement
pros: Great training. Good benefits.  Lots of opportunities to advance if you are willing to relocate. Strong brand recognition that is an asset when selling
cons:
Managament has lost sight of some of the true metrics that drive financial results. Example: revenue generated by a banker is not used as a performance measurement. 
For the past 2 years there have been arbitriary caps on pay raises.

review_title: Overall....  Great Benefits...  Lots of Stress
pros: WFHM had a very structured system in place for every aspect of the CSR role.   The reps are expected to be on their phones for the duration of the workday with the exception of scheduled breaks, lunch, team meetings or coaching sessions.   There are sales goals that have to be met as a part of the job requirements.   It can become mundane.
cons: The sales quotas can be hard to meet when the products offered are not applicable to the borrowers that are targeted for the product.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Rancho Cordova, CA
pros: I actually came to this site and it's been extremely helpful. 1st part is an assessment online which you fill out. 2nd part is phone interview. To push the process along I found the 800 recruitment center number on my own and inquired about an appointment. That seemed to confuse them a bit but the next day they scheduled my phone interview 5 days after. Simple questions like Describe a difficult situation and how you resolved it, How do you handle an irate customer, etc.
cons: Be aggressive in pursuing them for the job they are very slow at callbacks from what i've heard.

job_title: Customer Service and Sales Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: The company is very strong and has a lot of job security. Overall, when working in the retail banking section of Wells Fargo, you never have fear of being laid off. A manager once said to me, the closer you are to the customers the more job security you have. Also, the benefits are great, even for those tellers who are part time. They offer paid holidays, vacations, tuition reimbursement, etc. It's also a great resume builder. If you're looking for a career in sales, Wells Fargo bankers who are good end up getting great sales experience that will definitely help you in your future career.
cons: This company houses some of the most unethical bankers that set foot in the financial industry and the worst part is, it's the company's fault! They make the goals so unrealistic and therefore it pushes the pressure down from upper management to retail personal bankers and the only way they are capable of making their goals is to do things that most times are NOT in favor of the customer. Bankers are often closing and opening accounts, opening accounts for people who don't really need them, and worst of all opening numerous accounts for friends and family that end up getting charged fees and closing off on their own. The whole system for wells fargo sales goals focuses most on quantity of products opened rather than quality. Especially with the new account changes that makes it increasingly difficult for bankers to open accounts for customers who do not have direct deposit or a minimum balance. Also, this particular position i am in, which is the CSSR position, is basically a way for management to work you like a personal banker and pay you just a little above a teller. It's now becoming a company norm for retail managers to hire CSSRs instead of bankers just so the company can save money. 'd say its an okay company overall if you're ethical and are able to sell products the right way but be prepared to take the ride of your life.

review_title: A decent place to work, with many changes happening presently and in the near future.
pros: Well respected company with competitive compensation.  Financially stable relative to other big banks.  Merger has combined best practices from both companies, which closed the gap in many areas compared to the competition.
cons: Many changes, including significant job cuts currently in progress.  Culture of Wells Fargo is more "mom & pop" than other big banks.  Technology was about 10 years behind Wachovia.  Talent development is lacking.

review_title: I loved working for Wachovia, now that Wells Fargo has taken over, I can not wait to leave.
pros: The only pro going for Wells Fargo, other than the paycheck, is the people that you get to work with. I have met a lot of wonderful people while working there and made some friends along the way
cons: The pay is lower than it should be. The changes are so frequent and inconsistant that its hard to ever really know what it going on and what are the right procedures to even the most simplest of tasks. The managers are invisible and are obviously not interested in what their employees think or how they feel. The majority of the supervisors show how much they dont care about their directs.

review_title: My experience has been average, the job teaches you a lot about what it means to give outstanding customer service.
pros: Managers are very passionate about their and are  willing to help those who want to advance within the company. There is a lot you can learn from Wells Fargo about giving outstanding customer service.
cons: Wells Fargo main purpose is to give outstanding customer service, with that said if an employee gets surveyed and receives 4 out of 5 starts, they can be punished-written up (informal, formal, and termination). They are also very pushy when trying to sell products-checking acct./savings acct. etc. They do not always have the customer best interest at heart.

pros: The bank acts as a team, when the staff is short, management helps out.  The pay is decent and there are incentives and bonuses as well each quarter.  Benefits are great for a family!
cons: With the economy where we are at, there is a shortage of employees so the 50-60hr work weeks get a bit long after a while.  Was hired to work every other Saturday and right now each teller only gets one off a month.

review_title: NOT FAMILY OR MILITARY SPOUSE FRIENDLY, DON'T WORK HERE!!
job_title: Personal Banker in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: There were no pros.  They want you to cheat on your numbers and open accounts and credit for people without them knowing it, which you can personally get into alot of trouble for.
cons: They have no regards for your family, period.  They are all about business and their numbers.  You are just a scripted machine to them.  I liken it to a cult mentality.  Also, they will not work with military spouse schedules at all.  They do not care if your spouse is deploying, if your on the schedule, you better be there even though the military is very last minute.  I will never recommend anyone work here, nor do banking.

pros: I was able to work from home with excellent work life balance until....
cons: New management from Wachovia took over all IT aspects of the company and they are micromangers to the Nth degree.  Required to go to an office which was VERY far away from my home even though there were offices closer after working from home for the first year.  Nepotism is rampant.  New management was only focused on finding faults and not looking at success as a measuring stick.

pros: Excellent benefits and overall compensation package (higher for technical positions) - decent training opportunities. Lot's of locations and many open entry-level positions.
cons: Went from being a small community based company to a banking behemoth.  As a result, change is constant and high stress environments are the norm - tends to breed low employee morale as the work/home and personal ratio is seriously skewed.  With such a huge company, you can feel lost in the multiple layers of process they've built around things - slows production down considerably.  Senior management seems a little out of touch with people in the trenches actually doing the work.

review_title: Sometimes when a bank tries to get into the insurance business, it doesn't go too well.
pros:
Great brand loyalty and recognition.
Market leverage due to massive presence.
cons:
Too big to move quickly.
Ruled by the bank and compliance versus the customer.
Need more people to do the same job because of the various compliance requirements.
Too many compliance requirements that are bank-centric and have zero relevance to the insurance operations

job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Great relationships with partners and other team members.
cons: Not many chances for relocation or transfer. Pay structure was constantly changing making it more difficult to make incentive. Some managers were not great listeners or took the time out to really listen to team members. Goals were constantly being increased on a constant basis making it more difficult to hit them. New hire training is not lengthy enough before being placed in branch. No mentor program for new hires to work with.

pros: Good company if you are concerned about working for someone with a long history. Most upper management is very nice and treats you well.
cons: Ridiculous stats to meet, the job has so many land mines for you to trip over each month to divert you from bonuses...which you NEED to make the low pay bearable. You're told you will get specific shifts then in training they will tell you that you were hired and you need to work what they need.

review_title: A stepping stone for a younger professional, but finite amounts of opportunities within the company.
job_title: Registered Client Associate in Jenkintown, PA
pros:
It should be noted that this position and the experience working with Wells Fargo Advisors is entirely dependent on the Advisor(s) you work for. My experience was working with a Top 100 producer nationally, in a small team environment. This is the best case scenario for the position. The other option would be to work for multiple advisors, which I didn't have experience with, but seemed far less enjoyable/engaging. 

In general, I found the position to be a good opportunity to understand retail investment management from an operations stand point and build good communication skills. This job, like any other, gives only as much as your are willing to invest yourself. 

- Small team environment allows for experience working with many other tasks outside of a role that is traditionally administrative/sales support.

- I was able to build and maintain meaningful relationships with an affluent ($1-$5mm) client base and understand how to provide this segment of the retail market meaningful service.

- Daily contact with clients helps to build a foundation of "soft" skills. 
i.e. Professional communication in-person/over the phone/email, pro-active problem solving, confidently cold-calling (which isn't initially fun, nor is it for everyone, but its highly valuable.)

- Some days can be long, but for 90% of the time work stays at work
cons:
As mentioned before, your own experience depends greatly on the advisor you work for. Advisors for the most part have large egos and can be difficult to deal with. 

Pay from the branch is moderate at best. The only way to get substantial upside it to negotiate profit sharing agreements with the Advisor.

Compliance is often rigid and at times seems like their job is to stop you from doing yours.

There isn't too much of a career path as a Registered Client Associate. Either you stay in your current role, getting 2% pay raises annually or you try to become an advisor yourself or partner with your current advisor

Some clients can be a pain, but again, it depends entirely on the book of business.

This is a non-exempt position and their is plenty of time I worked 50-60 hours weeks and was only paid for 40. This was not mandatory but in on my team there was an expectation of executing regardless of hours needed.

pros: The bank has over 90 million profiles on SVP and one of the largest foot prints so having someone to talk should not be a problem
cons: Retail management as a rule is usually uneducated and unaccomplished. This is a reality because even though they work for a major bank, knowledge about basic economics, finance or leadership is not a requirement. This retail banks culture is focused on pushing checking accounts and superficial greetings to customers instead of cultivating client relationships.

review_title: You couldn't pay me to go back there
job_title: Wells Fargo in Grand Junction, CO
pros: Good benefits, good vacation pay/benefits. I loved many of my coworkers! Good place to learn a lot about being a teller.
cons: As a company overall, they don't seem to actually have the customer's well being in mind. They just want another sale. Many of the people climbing the corporate ladder there were doing so underhandedly and unethically, and with no discouragement from the management. Way too pushy with the sales goals.

review_title: Good company to gain experience at with good people.
pros: Since it is such a large organization there are many different roles you can play so a person can gain a lot of different experience. Also, the people there are for most part nice and try to help a person in their daily work. The company also tries to provide a good work life balance.
cons: Since the company is so large now there is a lot of bureacracy with in the organization and multiple layers of people. It can be challenging at times to get things done. Also, with so many layers it can be hard at times to get decisions made.

pros: Can be a rewarding and happy job if you are working in a location where all bankers are making their numbers.  Great pay and benefits. All holidays off, usually a few Saturdays a month, then you can get a weekday off which is nice. Managers are very cool. They are always willing to coach you to acheiving success.
cons: If you end up in a location where clientele is bad you are always working with so much stress to show management that you are doing your best. Locations not doing so well has a high turnover rate resulting in new people and management creating a not so nice atmosphere.

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Chandler, AZ
pros: Had a great manager and good team with walk in home buyers and lists to work from for refinance. Training is top notch and Wells Fargo does seem to care about their customers. No VA lending Origination fees for Veterans.
cons: Draw is $12.00 an hour with a 43 Bps pay. Must pay back $12.00 which accrues every month. Laid off too many processors and underwriters and slowed the pipeline. Underwriting guidelines are very tight and customers can go elsewhere to get financing.

job_title: Phone Banker I in San Antonio, TX
pros: the best things about working at wells Fargo is the campus,the cafeteria,the benefits and the training was fun.the pay was great and I miss the pay.
cons: the cons of working here were the sales pressure (as it was a customer service job taking inbound calls ), the sales goals  we're not attainable or realistic and I often felt I was suffering mentally from all the stress -because no matter how hard I tried I wasn't able to make the stats on a weekly basis and my supervisor would make me feel bad,like I was gonna get fired for not getting enough transfer to sales.

review_title: Changed for the worse over the last 10 years
job_title: Sales Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Decent medical insurance and PTO, though each has changed for the worse since the Wachovia merger.
cons: The company has a very different feel now than it did a few years back. The Wachovia merger worked out well for the Wachovia people, but not so well for the WF people. Employees now must review themselves, managers in general seem less qualified, and a sense of unease pervades the company. Besides the great recession, which most Wachovia/WF employees survived without losing their jobs, the culture seems to have changed for the worse. There is less trust, respect and sense of family or team now.

review_title: It was a great company to work for.  Management was wonderful and there was so much product knowledge to learn.
pros: Co-workers are very friendly. My manager was awesome.  She always appreciated my handwork and wanted me to get promoted fast.
cons: There weren't any.  I loved working with customers but we had to hurry at times. Vacation we could not take on time.  Most of the time corporate people put lots of pressure on management.

pros: Wells has the best culture in the industry and one of the most family friendly I've ever seen.  Coworkers were bright, friendly, and office politics were nearly non-existent.
cons: Wells seems to have an issue with funding.  I've tried to go back twice on a contract to hire and both times funding got cut for the position before conversion.

job_title: Phone Banker II in Beaverton, OR
pros: Recognition is a huge thing with the company, which is always such a great feeling to get from the workplace. Full on support whenever you need it
cons: Very stressful when it comes to sales/referrals. Told while going into the position it was a customer service job, and through training told multiple times it wasn't a sales job. During huddles it's all they talk about as well as getting hourly emails with updates of your sales stats.

job_title: Personal Banker Reg I in Fremont, CA
pros: Make sure you know how to handle the high pressure from your management level and up, good benefit, if you are looking for challenging job, this is a great job but unfortunately I have two kids, so I have to find a balance point.
cons: none, everything should be standard as a sale person, get ready to work and make plan will make your day faster and productive, otherwise your manager will be mad on you because they do check report every hour.

pros: Great benefits, all inclusive company for lgbt people, a nice amount of yearly pto. The company itself seems to be well lead and their is a lot of opportunity for growth if goals are met.
cons: The biggest draw back is the extremely high sales drivin environment, goals are attainable if giving the right conditions and support from bankers and service managers

pros: Wells Fargo is staffed by some of the brightest and most talented individuals anywhere.  The company has also invested in an amazing internal communications system to allow employees the ability to interact.
cons: Even though compensation plans provide incentives for cross sales between divisions, a culture of self protecting isolation prevents the various divisions from creating mutually beneficial working relationships with one another.

review_title: Good and Bad. What do you want from a job?
pros:
1) Great starting pay.  As a part-time job, especially if it's a first job or second job, you can make as much  as someone in the food or retail industry working full-time.

2) Banker hours! Earliest you'll need to get there is 8:30 am, typically out by 6:30 pm. Most holidays are paid.

3)  Great vacation time even when part-time. I forgot to take vacation last year and started 2017 with 192 hours of vacation.

4) Retirement contributions matched to 6%.

5)  Someone is always there to help you. At no point will you feel alone in dealing with a difficult situation  or difficult customer. Managers are very helpful in  answering your questions.

6)  Great starting point to continue a career in finance.  Opportunities to move up from being a teller can happen in as short as six months.

7) Education- Wells Fargo offers tuition reimbursement, IF the degree you are looking to attain is related to business or finance, and if you plan on remaining with the company.

8) Ability to move up is not hindered by a lack of a college degree. Wells Fargo is one of a growing number of companies realizing an employee does not need a college degree to be successful, and they hire and promote based on merit and skill, not college education.

9) On the job perks! Expect coffee, donuts, and the surprise lunch potluck. The job may be stressful at times, but you are fed well. Even more so if you have business owners  as customers who appreciate you. I've been given discounts around town just because people recognize me from the bank.
cons:
1) Everything is structured around cross-selling. Tellers are prevented from answering all but the most basic of questions; instead they are expect to hand the customer off to a banker, who is expected in turn to use the opportunity to push a product or two that the customer doesn't have, oftentimes regardless of need.

2) Sales goals still exist, despite press releases to the contrary.  Instead of individual goals, they are now "branch" goals.

3)  Teller privileges have been cut back severely, making basic job fulfillment oftentimes difficult.  Any attempt to look up a customer must have managerial approval; a move that theoretically increases security on behalf of the customer,  but hinders a teller's ability to perform needed critical to doing the job correctly.

4)  Abhorrently unethical behavior on the business banking side of Wells Fargo.  Business accounts have the most fees, merchant and payroll reps do not follow up with clients and tend to disappear once the sale has been made.

5) No full-time teller positions available.

6) Banker positions are usually fully staffed (if not overstaffed) in certain locations, which makes advancing in your career difficult if you are in an impacted area.

7) Surprise audits. A recent change, as before, your branch would be notified a day in advance to prepare for it.

review_title: If you have morals and ethics and half a brain...retail banking is not for you.
pros: The best reasons I can think of are a steady paycheck and above average benefits.
cons:
I am speaking for myself and also many current team members within the company, at least on the retail banking side of the company.  The "strong sales culture" of Wells Fargo dominates every moment of working in a retail store.  Most people do not realize how pervasive and important sales are in banking, unless they have worked in one.  I did for 9 years, beginning as a Personal Banker (I jokingly referred to myself as a "Personal Slave") and working my way up to an upper level Store Manager with 25 team members and many thousands of transactions per month.  I got those promotions primarily because of sales results.  I'm certainly under no illusions about that.  Fortunately, those sales were ethical and moral.  I never trained or encouraged any TM to sell just for the sake of selling or to lie to customers.  I feel a bank's most important asset, after their people, is their reputation.  And I don't mean a AAA rating.  I mean what the average customer would say about you.  Ethics should be #1 as anything pertaining to money is reliant on confidence, including the value of our currency.  

Unfortunately, as I progressed, I found that the sales goals became increasingly difficult to reach.  I saw other stores exceeding goal by 150% or more and initially, wanted to learn from those stores so I and my TM's could make bonus and receive recognition.  Perhaps they knew something I didn't or were better at communicating with customers.  What I found was that they had thrown all ethics out the door.  I was shocked and appalled, especially with all the lip service WF gives about their high ethics and their dedication to helping customers succeed financially.  So, naturally, I alerted my manager.  I reported blatant cheating to the ethics line WF provides to team members.  I alerted HR.  Nothing happened to the offenders except promotions!  I saw this time and time again.  While I was being forced to fired amazing TM's just for missing goal, these heartless, cruel and selfish beings were being promoted!  ..and still are to this day!  My friends who still work there told me that they have been told not to call the ethics line about cheating sales anymore "due to a high volume of these kinds of calls".  They are supposed to contact that person's manager.  A lot of good that does since managers make huge bonuses based on what their employees produce...obviously, there's no incentive to fire unethical people when it hurts you in your pocket book.  So the cheating of customers continues and is tacitly supported by upper management.

The things that makes me most angry is the disregard to human beings:  both customers and front line team members.  It all boils down to numbers and profit.  While I realize companies are in business to make money, the amount of profit this institution generates is mind boggling.  The biggest "fee income" generator for the state of Arizona is on Direct Deposit Advance...just another name for payday loans.  Usury.  Team members know what it does to customers and their lives and have been vocal about getting rid of it.  They know it's wrong, but since it's such a money maker, the bank continues offering that "service".  

For TM's, it's like this...sell sell sell.  Nothing else matters...customer service, being kind to other employees, working hard, trying to give proper advice to customers, intelligent recommendations...NONE of it matters except your numbers.  YOU don't even matter...except for your numbers.  They talk a good game about people being their competitive advantage, but after you begin working there, you will see the truth.

job_title: Personal Banker II (Premier Banker) in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great benefits, a lot of vacation days, people can be fun to work with depending on where you're at, potential to move up
cons: Besides the pros listed above, Wells Fargo is a horrible company to work for. Their structure forces bankers to lie to customers in order to meet solution goals. One of my co-workers actually said, "I just took the honest route with my last customer and got nothing out of it. That's the last time I'll do that." Unfortunately, that is a true statement. The goal is to open as many bank accounts and products for customers as possible. The higher the number, the better. This means that bankers are doing whatever is necessary for THEM to get those numbers on to the system, even if it means blatantly lying to customers in order to get the "solutions". The customer's interest is NOT the banker's priority because doing what's right for the customer usually means not "getting anything" out of them. Wells Fargo's system gives it's bankers the option to convert accounts without having to change the customer's account number, but instead of using this option, bankers always close accounts and reopen new ones in order to receive credit and make their numbers. This means that the customer has to take the time to change their direct deposits and any automatic debits or credits that they have coming into their accounts. This is NOT in the customer's best interest, but it happens EVERYDAY at EVERY BRANCH and management turns a blind eye. This is just one example of how CORRUPT this company is. Officially, managers tell the staff to go by the book. Unofficially, bankers are expected to do ANYTHING it takes to make their own numbers and help the branch meet it's goal. Anything means lie, cheat, take customers from other bankers, run to customers hoping to get something out of them, team up on customers in order to talk them in to opening new accounts. ANYTHING! Wells Fargo retail is horrible! I'll sum it up with this: When I gave my manager notice that I had found a better job and would be leaving, he asked me if I could try to get him a job also!! Then he proceeded to ask me not to tell my coworkers about me leaving because he didn't want them to start looking for other jobs as well. Enough said.
