pros: I really enjoyed working at Wells Fargo because the environment was very team oriented. You are never alone because there is always someone available to help out with transactions. They are very flexible with their hours which was great because I was a full time student at the time. Overall, I enjoyed my time there and got along very well with management, bankers, and tellers.
cons: I felt like a robot because everyday was the same day and the same conversation with the customers. The employees are overworked and underpaid and there is a high turnover rate. Saturdays are mandatory to work.

pros: Leared alot about post foreclosure expenses
cons: It's a production environment.  Literally no one is meeting both production and quality goals.  People are being let go all the time because of unrealistic expectations. Lots of one of situations with each claim that you're expected just to know.  Procedures are still being written.  stay out of claims if you want job security.

job_title: Consumer Loan Underwriter II in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Upward mobility, training opportunities, overtime compensation.
cons: Base salary is not high enough for the work and skill set required. Especially for the more experienced credit analysts. We are expected to train new hires, complete extra managerial tasks on top of just building the portfolio and working live deals. For all the work you do, to be paid so little while an outside hire can negotiate for higher salary than someone working there for much longer is counterproductive if you want to retain those employees who know the program inside out and are essential to keeping the volume coming in while training the new people (who the company will pay more)

review_title: Great Benefits and Room for Improvement
pros: Great opportunity to advance with company. Fair market salary but even better benefits.
cons: The workload can be strenuous sometimes. Systems could function a lot better. Accountability is preached down, not up. Management can be so stressed and busy that they do not have the time to help you fine tune your skills.

pros: Working at Wells always opened doors and allowed for initial time to engagement with a client to be shorter than at most other smaller banks.  It also had many services to be offered to help circle the client with many value add options.
cons: The company is too big to be nimble or creative at the local level and decisions, sometimes even small ones, are seemingly made by folks with no direct interaction with the situation.

pros: Nice building with a good cafeteria.  Management was generally nice face to face.  Low key dress code.  High security building.  Listening to music was allowed.
cons: Cancelled bonus program when I greatly exceeded their expectations.  They budgeted for $50-$100 per employee annually.  I was at nearly $2000 when they pulled the plug.  Management was sprawling is size and completely ineffective.

review_title: Wells Fargo has a long way to go
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Chandler, AZ
pros: There is not a lot positive I van say on this company. The department I was in did not work well with any other departments leaving customer's extremely frustrated.
cons: I would never recommend anyone working for this employer. In my short time there they constantly changed my job description and the in-fighting between managers and co-workers caused company morale to be virtually non-existent. There seemed to be a general lack of knowledge on what this position's responsibilities are among those directing us and what we actually do on a day to day basis

pros: You can usually find a position reasonably close to where you live, it want to live, if you're trying to relocate. Generous time off.
cons: You'll be hearing about the sales practices from customers for years and years, just like people still reference the McDonald's coffee case or children's Tylenol or Enron.

review_title: Good people, Great first step in career
pros: Easy to move up and around. Great Benefits and lost of vacation.
cons: Hard to get into management unless you are in good with upper management.  Pay is not the best. HR advised me that they are conservative in salaries. If you leave the company and come back you can make more than people who have been loyal to the company

review_title: Run far far away from WF BPS
pros: Laptop/ cell phone hence ability to work from anywhere
cons:
Management in business payroll services is unethical, manipulating, pushy and makes their own set of rules which are sometimes against company policy ( specifically the east/ mid Atlantic Florida market)
Used to be a good place to work in but has become a miserable environment after new managers in this particular area took over .
Only numbers focused with no regard for clients, rules or corporate policy. Sales reps are actively encouraged to do unethical things to make numbers 
Favoritism a huge issue
No work life balance and ridiculous turn over
Nepotism

job_title: Quality Monitor II in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Employee benefits such as; discount on cell phones, discount on mortgages, and employee health care plans.
cons:
negative publicity regarding the recent scandals around Wells Fargo's checking/savings accounts and collateral protection issues. 

Advancing your career within Wells Fargo is very difficult if you do not know someone like the hiring manager.  Wells Fargo doesn't seem to go off of your qualifications but rather if the hiring manager already knows someone who is applying for the job.

pros: I have worked within the banking field for 28 years. I have been with Wells Fargo since 2009. It is a great company to work for. They offer outstanding benefits including 4 months paid maternity leave. The starting salary is very competitive. The hours are great and some branches are closed on Saturday. Great customer service is the focus in everything they do. If you have awesome customer service skills everything else will come in time. The chance for advancement is achievable for everyone who works hard towards the goal.
cons: The annual merit increases in salary are very minimal. The turnover on the teller line is often.

review_title: Great company, very happy I joined.
pros: Pay is good. I get to run with lost of ideas. Work / home life balance is excellent. Colleagues are very happy to help and work with you. Company is in a huge growth period so lots going on. Perfect for people who want to roll their sleeves up and get stuck in.
cons: Slow place and risk adverse, there are some challenges in moving things forward. Lots of socialisation needs to take place. Company talks all the time about having more challenging conversations (i.e. everyone is too nice). Because the company is growing so fast there are some growing pains regarding role boundaries.

review_title: It's a Pretty good place to work
job_title: Loan Adjuster in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: You definitely learn a lot, there are a lot of opportunities for professional and personal development, there are nearly always some type of even going on and the management team genuinely car for their employees on a management and personal level
cons: Poor communication in regard to process procedure. The person with more experience will always get the promotion even if the person with less experience is a better candidate with more knowledge of the job functions

pros:
-If you are the kind of person who like the feeling to help people, you will like this job
-You could have really nice co-workers
-You get a lot of the major holidays off
cons:
-Unreasonable sale goals
-If you get anything less than a perfect score on a customer review you will written up
-They will not directly tell you to lie to customers to make a sale, but they will under handily imply it
-The bonus are not worth the effect
-Every other week they will make it a sale gauntlet week, where they really want you to make sale goals. They are just trying to make make more sales.

pros:
Good work/life balance.
Good benefits for the most part.
cons:
Hard to get promoted internally.
Management is disconnected from the main workforce.
Pay isn’t competitive compared to other institutions. Promotions/raises are insulting at a rate of .5%, doesn’t  even keep up with cost of living increases. New hires make more than seasoned team members. People are not a competitive advantage as they say they are and if they are it’s cause they are not valued and are paid no where near mid or upper market level conpensation rates. Also, upper compensation rates are unattainable.
Company speaks highly of their vision and values but doesn’t deliver in terms of team member compensation.

review_title: Get your knives and flak jackets ready
pros: Great potential to make some good money in sales along with great training modules.
cons: Your knives are for the inevitability of having to stab your coworkers in the back in order to really bust into the business and the flak jacket is to protect yourself from such attacks.  The business itself is set up to elevate favorites and to chase out those who don't quite fit the mold.  Many mortgage careers are simply started at Wells Fargo, so don't waste your time and head on over to a company that will value your presence.

review_title: Not the place for IT support work
job_title: Systems Support Analyst IV in Tempe, AZ
pros: They do offer benefits (but they're expensive), company match 401k, pay is not bad.
cons: They are ending telecommute for all technology positions, system administrators no longer have root access to support the server environment (until a crisis occurs) so routine maintenance and break-fix work is slowly being moved off-shore.. and overall performance reviews are being scored as pass/fail based solely on arbitrarily defined "data metrics".

review_title: Wells Fargo still trying to move past the scandals
pros:
Paid federal bank holidays
Great volunteer program
6% 401k match
cons:
Too many levels of management
Career advancement is not based on performance or what you know, it’s who you know
Medical benefits are not the best
Annual salary increases well below the cost of living adjustments 
Always the lowest when it comes to salary base pay
Technology is behind other banks

review_title: Great place to work - if you can get along with multiple personality types
job_title: Systems Architect in San Francisco, CA
pros: Someone in IT can make a career at Wells Fargo, as long as they have the personality to get along with a wide variety of people with a wide variety of skill sets.
cons: The diversity of Wells Fargo's employees is fantastic;  however, in addition to racial diversity there is also a broad spectrum of competence levels.  One must be patient and tolerant of a good number of less-than-competent co-workers.

review_title: Great Place to Work - Wells Fargo.
pros: Great opportunities to learn / advance within the company. Encourages personal development through training opportunities outside and within the company.  Managers are helpful in understanding personal needs and making accommodations to individuals.  Friendly atmosphere, great co-workers, great enviornment to work in, customers are pleasant, great benefits, great vacation time and jobs security.
cons: Wells Fargo is generally a great, exciting, fast pased, motivating place to work.  There are the same drawbacks that any large comany would have but I can't even think of what they are at the moment so they cant be that bad.

review_title: A great place to work if you love people and sales.
job_title: Lead Teller in San Antonio, TX
pros: It is a great company to work for.  The training is comprehensive and ongoing.  There are no surprises when it comes to the expectations of management.
cons: It is all about sales.  As with any other sales position, all the management sees are numbers.  Not every location is the same as far as traffic, new customers, etc.. and the sales goals are way too high.

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Phoenix, AZ
pros: i think the benefits are good.
cons: First and foremost, their Processing centers have absolutely zero sense of priority.  They are completely desynthizied about the transaction they process and how they relate to peoples homes.  The compension plan in 2009 is based on volume, but wait you can't close any deals because processing doesn't get your deal out to close.  It's so aggrivating!  Customer's and Realtor don't care about brand name any more, they would rather deal with a company who will get loan docs out on time.

review_title: Former tenured employee who moved onto greener pastures
pros: Great for those who need structure, pay is okay  once you move out of retail banking, brand recognition.  Career paths, very little hiring outside the company.
cons: Companny focuses on customer care, but really, its mainly about whether you sell enough or not.  High stress environment, must be willing to hunt for sales constantly.  if you cant sell/upsell, dont work here.  Be flexible with the location of your job, you will be transitioned.

pros: It's a large company that has a variety of different areas to get involved with.  Advancement is possible but must wait atleast 1 year before applying for another position within the company.
cons: Since it is a big company, there is a lack of individual feedback you receive.  Also because of the large coroporation there is a mix of education levels that I work with- sometimes it is frustrating

pros: Great direct management within Wells Fargo.   Wells Fargo also offers great benefits but the pay does not seem to be on par with the rest of the market.
cons: Senior management seems to be out of the loop as to what is going on in sales and operations.  Wells Fargo seems to implement new projects without review from the people it is directly effecting.

pros: Wells Fargo itself is a wonderful company to work for.  The benefits package is pretty generous, there is free parking and there are lots of team member engagement events.
cons: WFA as a business line is sometimes overridden on things at an enterprise level which sometimes causes the employees of WFA to lose out. For instance, all business lines are required to follow the FED holiday schedule which requires employees that follow other schedules such as the NYSE schedule to lose PTO days.

pros: Wells Fargo is a large and stable bank.  The sales goals are rigorous and you really have to be either strategic and hardworking in order to achieve and surpass your highest goals.  Benefits are great as well.
cons: Compensation is not in alignment with achievement.  I think they could reward their hardworking achievers with better bonuses and incentives.

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in San Bernardino, CA
pros: Great brand recognition. Great resume booster. If you are lucky enough to be assigned a retail branch bank it can be a great source of business for you if worked correctly.
cons: High turnover rates, incompetent self interested branch management. Most employees in the mortgage field are hired from part time real estate roles and extremley incompetent.

review_title: Management do not care about their employees and there is not much job security.
pros: Wells Fargo has good reputation in the market place.  The benefit package is one of the best in the industry.
cons: Management indicated that if you are not hitting your numbers, then you are easily replaceable. Lack of job security. Furthermore, there are no training available that would advance your career.  Forget about wanting to move between different divisions of Wells Fargo.  Working in Retail banking hurts your chances in your ability to transfer to another division.  Retail banking is considered the lowest in the totem pole.

pros: The people are great.  It is a very large financial sound company.  Relative to other financial services companies, your job is relatively safe.  Great training, especially for those in the early stages of their career.
cons: Very bureaucratic and must go through many levels before some things are approved.  Promotions many times are based on how long you have been there, rather than merit.

pros: Long-standing financial company with a strong brand and public recognition.  One of the few financial services firms that survived the financial crisis of 2008.
cons: Information is not readily shared.  Collaboration among various groups within the same line of business doesn't exist.  Management doesn't appear to have the mentoring ability required to build up and advance personnel.  Status quo is accepted as the standard norm with no room for creativity with work flows, processes and strategic methodologies.

review_title: The banking is good its the selling that'll get you
pros: they offer ample sick & vacation time. the tellers you work with are generally great people and become friends in and out of work
cons: they just told us they were reducing our benefits to hsa;s and hras which is nothing compared to the benefits package we used to have. the pay is not comparable to other banks but it is stable workplace. the selling is really what is pushing me to leave. i've been there 3 years i cant imagine what the goals will be as time goes on. the greed is ridiculous .

job_title: Personal Banker I in Tamarac, FL
pros: There are many opportunities available, given you have the experience. The company is extremely customer service oriented in regards to the consumer banking.
cons: Local branches can be extremely exhausting because we focus on making customer so very happy and also not scoring poorly on our internal survey. So much so that it seems like customers and managers don't think were human. They don’t understand when we’re hungry at or need a moment to complete paper work.

pros: Great place for self motivated people. plenty of support
cons: Huge company, Website access to info is good but so is looking into the Yellow Pages. You need a mentor I would look  to learn under a sucessful advisor with the desire to transition in as an equal. If you don't , your life in the 1st 5 years will be rough.

review_title: Wonderful company to grow and learn if you wish to pursue a banking career
job_title: Personal Banker I in West Chester, PA
pros: Company has an excellent culture of helping team members reach career goals and promoting from within.  Numerous career paths to follow.  Company maintains a very good reputation among other retail banks.  Very progressive in systems used to help bankers sell products and services.
cons: If one is not sales oriented this is not the job to pursue.  Very aggressive in attaining sales goals.  Company is heavily segmented and can be very bureaucratic with one getting connected to many different departments for resolutions.

review_title: Good for career, company has become too big to deal with people individually anymore
job_title: Vice President in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great learning, strong culture, great benefits, good opportunities to move within the company, a great reputation in the financial services industry.
cons: Huge, overly systematic and highly political, often fails to update antiquated systems, too much project recycle, salary adjustments are poor

review_title: Great job, but hard to compete with the cheats!
job_title: Personal Banker in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Secure job with great opportunities to expand. You really have the ability to do a lot of good in peoples lives. 401K, tuition reimbursement, professional staff.
cons: Sales goals not adjusted to accounting for the cheating that goes on.

job_title: Personal Banker in Long Beach, CA
pros:
Benefits
Wells Fargo in your resume is a great factor
cons:
Difficult to have PTO approved
Stores are ALWAYS short-staffed 
Ridiculous sales goals
If you wanna move up, you have to make your name known to upper management. Promotion is dependent on the type of manger you have. 
Managers are incompetent, not educated - they were just promoted because they had good sales as bankers/tellers - this creates problem because they do NOT know how to manage
They would push sales but when it's time for service, they want you to "speed things" up with customers and managers refuse to reverse fees even though it's the branch's fault

pros: Good thing working with bank technical team is that you will become more quality oriented about the code you deliver. After joining here, i started writing my code as more secure, maintainable, efficient, High quality and this is what job demands here. Also being a developer for bank you are supposed to learn the new technologies quickly and adapt it, Since banks are becoming competitive with the help of the technolgies only be it a internet banking, mobile banking, tablet banking... I truly enjoy my work in wells fargo, and thats the reason i am satisfied here.
cons: Very less or NO onsite opportunity

review_title: Visit the Same Realtor Offices Weekly and You will Succeed!
job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Redlands, CA
pros: Great benefits, make your own schedule, carry your own laptop, great support for your success.  It's all about follow up in this position.  Communicate with everyone during a transaction and you will be liked by your realtors, borrowers, processors, and listing agents.  This will lead to more business.
cons: No experience = a big learning curve which can cause heartache and pain for the mortgage consultant realtors and the borrowers.  Commission paid in advanced (no loans closed in one month gives you a deficit in your commission that you have to pay back in the following month).

pros: Tons of room to advance for people who work hard, some upper management is amazing lots of continue training great commission checks and good annual bonus. Nice recognition events.
cons: No work life balance, some upper management not good at all, they push solutions/ sales way to much huge goals which cause many bankers to do unethical things, get a text at 5-6 in the morning with service results. For the amount of hours you work pay is not good.

pros: Clean reputation, well run business, nice people and decent technology
cons: Payout cuts, grid/hurdle changes, way too many "productivity managers" and "retirement consultants" on staff. Too much $$ taken from producers to fund ridiculous marketing campaigns created by non-revenue generating staff (think Ritz Carlton referral campaign).

pros: Great place to work at. Never a dull moment with new and established customers..
cons: Sales sales sales. Im okey with this even as a teller. But its so hard to supposedly get promoted when they bire from outside of the compmany giving fulltime employment to others with no experience at all. They look at numbers and like I said my numbers get shut out over one who has nothing. Its all about sales. Nothing wrong with it but Still part time after 2 years... some would say your better off quiting and reapplying and getting hired at a different location for the position you want.

pros: I was lucky and had a great Service Manager who seemed to dislike Wells Fargo as much as I did... He left about 6 months after me. If you don't mind selling "products" to customers that they don't seem to need, then you'll do great and can be eligible for small quarterly bonuses. Coworkers can be great.
cons: Sales pressure is ridiculous.  SELL SELL SELL ridiculous "products" that nobody needs.  The  bank manager was an awful person.  Raises are minimal.  You can maybe become a personal banker, which is even more slave work for not much in return.

pros: Plenty of ways to grow - there are always postings for internal positions.  Each position is laid out clearly and the technology used makes it easy to track work.  This can also be a con as there's not much room for enhancing your position and easy to become micromanaged.
cons: Since its such a large company it can be easy to get lost.  Each department at the company is managed very differntly so its best to try to get as best a feel as you can for the environment before accepting a position.  Some departments are very micromanaged.

review_title: Wells Fargo takes care of its employees
job_title: Business Systems Consultant in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: Flexible, good benefits, appreciatiative and respectful environment. John Stumpf is fantastic and sets a very positive tone for hte entire massive company.
cons: long hours, chained to a desk and phone with very few breaks between meetings

pros: Excellent Benefits, solid foundation for a career in banking, lots of room for advancement, rewarding development, demonstrates diversity in the work force. This is a company that has high expectations but with it delivers high rewards.
cons: If you are not a self motivated person with strong self management skills then you may want to look elsewhere. If you are uncomfortable with high goals or like to abuse paid time off then you should look elsewhere.

job_title: Human Resources Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Wells Fargo has an incredibly diverse workforce. There's been time and time again where companies boast their diverse candidate look and, but extension, mixed workforce. Wells Fargo truly practices what they preach in sourcing top talent from many walks of life!
cons: Working in one line of business makes moving out of state difficult. While there are exceptions to the rule, ensure the line of business you're applying to has multiple sites across the country (or world if you're looking that route) before applying if you feel a relocation may be down the road.

job_title: Customer Service and Sales Representative in Charleston, SC
pros:
The work hours are great
A lot of vacation time
cons:
Too aggressive with sales to the point where some bankers sign customers up for services they did not even ask for. 
We do have a lot of vacation time but we can never use it when we want to
Sales goals are so high that it is almost impossible to get a good bonus
Bonus is QUARTERLY. average bonus is $300-$1500. not worth the work the employees put in.

pros: People fun and laid back, busy, overtime possibilities at the time. Location at the campus office convenient.  Parking ramp no fees to pay each day but got busy after about 9 am.
cons: Very fast pace, not a lot of training, computers didn't work in the training room.  Once on the floor not a lot of support as a new person, put on new duties very quickly.  Expected to work plenty of overtime if you wanted to keep up.

pros: Some of the reasons why I have stayed at Wells Fargo for so long are because of the benefits, stability, overall good reputation, my short commute to work, team that I work on, and my ability to learn and grow.
cons: There are too many hands in the pot sometimes, can be very "political", and lately there are ongoing issues with systems to do my job efficiently.  Due to the many levels of "leadership", decisions can take a while to be made.

pros: Fast paced career development- became a store manager from teller within 3 years of employment. Company is Customer oriented and number one priority is "to satisfy our Customers needs and help them succeed financially"
cons: Very fast paced environment, lots of requirements from managers, so effective time management is very import to the role. Definitely a lot of pressure when it comes to Sales by hard work gets rewarded. No need to push sales, it actually works as long as everyone is providing great customer service and recommend products and services that customers benefit from.

pros: Not many, except for my co-workers. Hours weren't too bad. Nice offices.
cons: harder to bonus, micro-manages everything, not able to use PTO, tells you what the mid point in salary but are never expected to get there. Raises take forever to get. Once you get into a collection position, it is hard to move to any other department.

pros: Great team. Really kept the work interesting and was given real responsibility. However the drags in development are definitely evident when working in a bank, as everything has to undergo lots of QA and requirement analysis.
cons: I feel it really depends what team you are on; the floor out in san francisco is not quite as loud and really stays quiet, so the atmosphere can feel a bit down.

review_title: Good Company, Good Culture, Slightly Boring
pros:
- Strong culture, definitely more lax compared to other Wall St. companies (probably due to its southern roots)
- Helpful people; leaders and peers help mentor, as the company wants to retain its employees
- Good work/life balance
- Upper management cares about your experience and what you're working on
cons:
- Lack of organization at times, can be very chaotic
- As a first year analyst not working with anyone in my year (or even close), it can get boring; no one to connect with or "hang out" with after work (but this could also be a pro)

pros: The pay starts about a dollar more an hour with a process of incentives.
cons: The company does not care about its employees from the entry level positions up to the management.  The revolving door of employees that this creates impacts the level of customer service that the company can offer and creates such a high amount of stress that the majority of the employees who left voluntarily had to address anxiety and depression issues.  When sales are more important than the customers who rely on your company you will fail at customer service.

review_title: One of the top 10 companies to work for!
pros: Seventeen years of great experience with this company. Like any large organization there will be challenges and changes, however this is a company that generally speaking takes care of its employees.
cons: Diversity is still a minor challenge... scorecard does not typically reflects the realities of what takes place at the grassroot structure of the organization. This is par for the course as it reflects the general corporate culture here in the US and to a greater extent, the current social and political culture of the country itself.

pros: Great benefits, 6% 401k match. Wells Fargo Advisor's FINRA registered associates qualify for NAV purchases in mutual funds, reducing costs significantly. WF associates also get NAV on WF Funds only.
cons: Specific to Wells Fargo Advisors -- there are no growth or advancement opportunities.  We are stuck in an entry level job making more money that if we start over somewhere else. Every way out is a step down, financially and otherwise. We are the industry black sheep. Management also views our job as mostly worthless, meaning they don't respect all that we do for client service.

pros: Large customer base.  Helping people. You meet good people, and Wells has a plethora of solutions to meet financial needs.
cons: Manager will not let you have the time to make calls to drive traffic to branch. As a Licensed PB II you are to focus on the affluent segment of the branch, but are constantly called to do temporary debit cards and affluent clients will leave. Best to set appointments ahead of time to block time. No support or advancement even if you are going over a beyond expectations. Its more about networking and who you know as oppose to overall performance.

pros: Training was great. You automatically get 2 week vacation when you start working as well as health benefits even as a part time employee. The company is located throughout the world, therefore, you have the ability to transfer from one region to another. There is always an abundance to grow with the company internally.
cons: The sales pressure of making goals are very intense. Management,at times, can be out of touch with employees.  There is a high turnover in the company.

job_title: Home Equity Underwriter in Phoenix, AZ
pros: There are a lot of entry-level positions available, which helps get your foot in the door & gives you crucial work experience. Most of my managers have seemed to care about me & my development / growth within the company.
cons: Salaries tend to be lower than competing banks & for some reason new employees are hired on at higher hourly pay than seasoned employees, leaving loyal employees feeling under valued. A lot of the monthly goals are unrealistic, which can create a stressful work environment.

pros: They help you to grow and there are many advancement opportunities. Good training and pay is better than most financial institutions.
cons: There is a lot of sales pressure, turnover in upper management, and when I tried to make suggestions on how to do business better my opinions were not heard.

pros: Solid company with great ethics despite the one-off credit card sales mess at the bank. WF Advisors is very clean.
cons: Wells Fargo Advisors- Customers do business with us because of the FA's and the local associates. Management is not experienced in sales with customers and they have become mis- perceived about where the business comes from. Lower level management has been turned over in recent years and our manager doesnt realize where client loyalty lies. Always confluence in this firm because management doesnt understand the customer anymore

job_title: Inbound Sales Specialist in Richmond, VA
pros: The  managers were nice and so were the coworkers. Training was very thorough and they prepared you well for the job ahead.
cons: Working in inbound sales, you had to process calls coming from the customer service dept. Not every customer needed new accounts or loans and we were always pushed to service ALL customers as a potential sale. The worst part was the unnecessary strain they put on the customer service dept. Poor guys had to answer phone calls and send almost every customer over to sales, whether they needed help or not. Low pay, no realistic goals.

pros:
Good Work life balance
Good infrastructure
Pay structure is little above average
Company plans for a number of trainings.
Lot of team lunch, outings and fun activities planned through year
Role change is easy till 10 yrs and becomes difficult as you move up in experience level.
cons:
No onsite exposure for young team members
Politics at senior level
Work from home happens in a very conservative way. People think before asking managers.
Hike is less though they have half yearly appraisal
1 HR business partner aligned to no. of employees in a LOB is very less.
Old technology and conservative mindset though company speaks loud about Innovation and cutting age technology.
Recent big challenge has come up w.r.t Car parkings.

job_title: Bank Teller in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Benefits but they will give you to use your avacition and then couple months later will ask you to pay them back. I don't think that's right without letting you know that before you taking the pto.
cons: All day Wednesday's the most boring day.

review_title: Wrong place to be if you are looking to make money
job_title: Business Specialist in San Fernando, CA
pros:
Trying to clean image
Easy Job, good for the lazy
Ok Benefits
GREAT 401k Plan
Good training
cons: Its going to be a while before Wells Fargo will look like a good company again. For those of team members like myself that actually produced a lot for Wells Fargo without screwing people over are now paying the price. They took all our commissions away and now its literally a joke compensation plan. There is no clear view on whether or not they will soon better compensate their old top producing bankers.

review_title: Time to move on in life
pros: Great benefits for current employees.
cons: Did not agree with Management style. Hard to advance within the company. Certain guidelines keep people in lateral move positions with no opportunities to grow unless you applied for a management position.  If you made a lateral move they capped your salary so you could not be offered more. Layoffs occur frequently.

pros: Good benefits (healthcare), 6% match to 401(k) and profit sharing as well.
cons:
Very difficult to get in at lower levels of the corporate structure. There are usually plenty of higher level positions, but finding an entry/lower level position is difficult.
Raises are usually capped at low percentages, which encourages jumping between positions to actually get any sort of meaningful increase. Even when considered a very good performer.

review_title: You are better going to a different bank.

job_title: Senior Credit Manager in Fargo, ND
pros: I work on the Financial side which has great opportunity for those who are willing to take there career into there own hands.  If you want to be stuck going nowhere then it wouldn't be the position for you but for those who are self motivated, money hungry, and are looking to work in a company that rewards you for what you are worth to them, Wells fargo Financial is something you should check out.
cons: Some basic downsides would be the amount of stress you can put on yourself to acheive your goals.

review_title: A view from the internet group
pros: The company is a good place to work if you're looking for work/life balance. Schedule and work place flexibility are good in nearly all groups.  The company is also good about developing their people -- continuous training is available for both deepening existing skill sets and developing new ones.  There is openness by most managers to have employees move from group to group.  A person could have a 20+ year career at Wells Fargo which includes 10 or more very different jobs.  In general, the culture is one of partnering and doing what's right for the customer.  The company has lots of community involvement.
cons: The downsides of the company is due to the double edge sword of having a culture of employees who stay with the company for 20+ years.  On the one hand, its great to have continuity through the years with employees who have deep customer, enterprise, system, etc knowledge.  However, many of the employees who are long tenured also stay in the same group and are adverse to change (hence staying in the same group).  Additionally, many of the long tenured employees also end up moving up the ranks because of their tenure and corporate knowledge vs. being the right leader for the group.  The combination of long tenured employees and managers staying in the same group leads to areas of the company that are very slow to change, lack innovation, lack leadership, and reward those that don't rock the boat.  Thank goodness not all groups within Wells Fargo are this way.  There are many great leaders who are long tenured with both deepth and breath -- the ones that have taken on varying roles in different groups vs. the ones who have stayed in the same group they were hired into.

job_title: Premier Banker in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: To get a chance to work for a well run company that will help with your career down the road.  It's truly what you make of it.  You can get your licenses and education paid for.  Just make sure you network with the right people and always attend any networking events the company might sponsor.  It's not who you know, but who knows you when it comes to getting promoted.
cons: Working within a large company you can get lost in the mix if not careful.  The advancement options into the side of business I wanted to get into were limited.

job_title: Business Development Officer in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Wells Fargo treats its employees with the respect they deserve. The benefits package is particularly strong and the compensation for high sales performers is good.

Morale is good, feedback is taken seriously and a generous time off program provides a good work/life balance.

Communication is generally good, but has its gaps like any big company has.

Senior management are generally thoughtful and sensitive people. I have never been yelled at in ten years of working here by any manager.
cons: It is a large, conservative organization that has all the downsides associated with a large bureaucracy. Trying to change things can sometimes be akin to changing the course of the titanic.

review_title: Working in Retail is a Dog & Pony Show that they call the Branch!
job_title: Loan Servicing Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: As many people have said previously, you can definitely start off in an entry-level job, like a Bank Teller position and work your way up to management fairly quickly. The company does have good benefits and offers a competitive 401k plan.  Having Wells Fargo on your resume looks good because its a well respected Financial Institution, and everyone in the Banking/ Financial world knows that they work you hard. You'll gain a lot of work experience.
cons:
Where do I begin?? I have work for this company for 11 years. I started off as a Teller, was a Personal Banker, worked in the Phone Bank,  Internet services department, and also worked as an Administrative Assistant and Loan Servicing Specialist. I've transfered around numerous departments within my career at Wells.

All I can say is that working in the Branch is COMPLETELY different from the corporate side of the Bank. In the Corporate side --or any department AWAY from Retail , there is a larger budget spent on the Team-Members. Overall they are treated nicer and your opinion and imput seems to count more for some reason.  In addition, there is more emphasis on quality training for better job performance. The atmosphere is less tense, not working in Retail. You end up working without all the sales goals and the Irate and Crabby Customers that storm the Branch regularely. You can rest peacefully instead of being stressed to peddle Check Card Rewards and other products that people don't need.  In the Branch you are pressured to get the sale no matter what---whether that means just ordering and sending out Gold ATM Debit Cards to customers that didn't even request them. The sales tactics are vicious and you're only as good as your Last sale.

pros: wells fargo offers great benefits, and has an amazing paid time off allocation - 5 weeks a year!  it also has great discounts on banking products.
cons: wells fargo is corporate america.  it is large, slow to make decisions, fraught with poor communication, mediocre middle management, and burdened with lots of public and financial sector reporting requirements.

review_title: Loved the work atmosphere. Everyone was very nice and treated with lots of respect! Easy job to move up in! Great!

review_title: My experience is what I make of my job. I choose to love my work regardless of the challenges and so I love my job.

Amazing team members

review_title: Great company overall; day to day experience dependent upon the line of business you're in

review_title: My branch in particular resembles a special kind of hell, but levels of hell-inesh vary by store.

job_title: Bank Teller in Pompano Beach, FL

job_title: Senior Project Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Diversity: you won't find a company with MORE focus on diversity than Wells Fargo, maybe equal but few can compare.

Reputation: of all the big banks and financial institutions, Wells Fargo is light years ahead of the competition when it comes to brand reputation, it's top notch.

Innovation: they are the leader of financial companies.

Tenure: you will find many team members who have been with the company fore more than 20 years.
cons:
All of this is my personal opinion, take it with a grain of salt, just know if one person is experiencing these things, then many probably are. 

Work /Life Balance: it used to be amazing but since the recent Wachovia acquisition, now much worse. Projects are piled on regularly.

Advancement: many San Francisco positions are being or have been eliminated and are being replaced with new employees in less expensive cities like Des Moines, Charlotte, Phoenix, St. Louis or Minneapolis which in my opinion is a major loss in west coast "Silicon Valley" "thinking at light speed" type of talent.

Perks: the perks that were there before are mostly gone due to cost cutting measures.

Recognition: Wells Fargo used to rank tops in the nation and now many forms of recognition have been limited to "words of praise" only. (ie no more trips to Cancun, no gift cards for a job well done, nothing)

Pace of Development: now slower than a snail. The company sometimes takes years to bring innovation to the marketplace because they fear releasing products and services that are not perfect. In the meantime many start up companies announce innovations before Wells Fargo leaving the bank to play "copy cat" and catch up.

review_title: Cheap company with the huge profit...

review_title: HR and Executive Management is your Opposition
job_title: Risk Management Consultant III in San Francisco, CA
pros: Specific areas of the bank are treated very well, the others are just treated as an expense. If you are in a true profit center like Wells Fargo Financial Advisors and can produce you will do very well. The benefits were good, but are being chipped away with each passing year. Work/Life balance is good. Extra holidays, especially if you work in an area related to markets, such as a trade desk. Leadership training is good as long as you are put on the fast track. The bank is very good promoting minority advancement and hiring practices. The banks image is intact through the recession. The co-workers are friendly and mostly intelligent. It is a good place to work in some areas to learn a skill set to take to a better company that pays better.
cons: The main challenge is that Wells Fargo, especially John Stumpf the CEO tries to maintain a community bank image. His mantra really is, "We are a community bank and customers come first." This is not the case in reality. The CEO and executive team gave themselves 20% salary increases on base salaries and millions of dollars in stock options all the while keeping their employees salaries stagnate. If you got 2% this year you were a lucky person. Quarter after quarter of profits, but none of it shared to the core employees only at the top of the pyramid. The top executives fly everywhere in the corporate jets. The bank does not promote from within, but makes you interview for every position and post many phantom positions that are cancelled. This is how they troll for talent instead of actually investing in their employees. The HR and upper management will give you insulting counter offers and are not tuned into the changing market. Management and HR make statements like," We do not want to get in an arms race with other departments for Risk Management talent so everyone needs to keep the salary offers limited". What they do not realize is that they are in an arms race with their competitors and a lot of talent has been leaving in the Risk Management areas because W.F does not pay enough to keep true talent. W.F is an old company. In the last year I have been witness to 5 retirements and the positions are not replaced in those areas. The remaining managers have 25 to 30 years at W.F, previous Norwest and are just biding time for retirement to collect their pensions. The new hires get benefits that are chipped away each year and I would not be surprised if they move all core employees to the Government Insurance Exchanges in the future.

review_title: Ok Part-Time Job For a College Student

review_title: WF is better than its reputation

Surveys are done annually and projects are put in place to improve our strengths and weaknesses.  Benefits are pretty good.  Pay is above average.
cons: Managers can be disconnected, but that may be specific to my situation.  Evaluations are done annually, without much feedback in between.

review_title: High Stress job but in the end I wish I never left
pros: You get great benefits.  401K, Pension, Medical, Dental, the whole 9 working fora big legit compnay lik ethis.  You will learn a lot that you can take anywhere to any field you choose in life.  The skills I've learned in Banking make me feel equipped to handle so many things and has proven to be teh case.  You can be well paid if you can endure the stress and pressure of a field full of variables and extenuating circumstances.  Economy, location, etc.  You can negotiate a good salary if you've had experience too.  I've worked for many major banks.  Chase the longest.  Wells Fargo paid me so much better it isn't even comparable.  Part of me regrets walking away.  Ways to prospect business depend.  I've worked in busy foot traffic branches which was great.  I've also worked in slower branches which was just cold calling.
cons: You will always be under a magnifying glass so to speak.  And you will feel like it.  There's alot of pressure coming down from up top.  It gets passed along until it finally reaches you from your branch managers.  Do the right thing.  Your name and user ID is what goes on the sale in the end.  Don't think a blind eye will be turned because all that matters is the numbers.  THe job has forced many good people to make horrible decisions that have costed them.  There's always  a threat you feel regarding losing your job in this field.  If you don't get this many BLAH than I'm going to write you up.  Scare tactics cause people to do the wrong thing.  Your friends and family will have had enough of you after you get them to do every single product whether they need them or not.

pros: Retirement plan was good with full 6% match and value has gone up.  Lots of opportunity to advance, especially if you are in one of their major markets.

review_title: Bens are ok cost is why high.

cons: 3800.00 before 80 20. Then 5700.00 max. That is the gold or top fam plan. Our team thinks only on CA time zone and not flexable at all. I dont see my family and I could WFH but they have me drive in each day just incase I need to push a button. :-/

job_title: Phone Banker I in Charlotte, NC
pros:
Pay- Nice base rate plus the opportunity to make a shift differential working in the afternoon(s).
Incentive Plan- Extra bonus pay for referrals and closing sales. 
Benefits- Choices between different medical plans, prescription coverage is awesome, FSA. The plans aren't terribly expensive. The 401(k) gives the option to increase contribution each year, up to 12%. Wells Fargo will match 100% up to 6% of gross pay after one year of service with the company. 
PTO- Provides a generous number of days off. Extra volunteer time, and floating holidays. 
Training- Provide ample classroom and applied training on the floor. You will have plenty of support during OJT. 
Promotions- Ample room to move up and out within the company.
cons: Sadly, the benefits listed above are about as far as it goes. Once hitting the floor, my whole morale went south. "Coaching" means getting pulled off the phone and told that you're not meeting your goals and that you need to basically find a way to do it or get threatened to be sent to senior management or written up. This stems from the unrealistic goals that Wells Fargo has for its bankers. In a short amount of time (4 minutes and 30 seconds or less), you must service the call, follow all procedures to stay in compliance (failing to do so can result in termination and other possible consequences), refer to the customer, and hopefully get them over to sales. The biggest struggles for most are AHT and the Referral Rate. It is possible to get the customers off the line in a short amount of time, but other metrics such as QA and KDM suffer because "you didn't take enough time with the customer." Sales is #1 in this call center environment, which is fine, but allow more time to spend with the customer. We have to go so fast through servicing the call that we don't get ample time to really know how the customer could benefit from another product or service, especially those that have almost all of them. It takes time and referrals would be of a higher quality if they weren't pushed so much OR if we could have a higher AHT. Those two metrics have been a struggle since the start, and instead of acknowledging that, the attitude is simply "you better fix it." This makes for a sometimes hostile work environment, depending on your current leadership. Not every minute of everyday is going to be top of the charts in terms of metrics. Having them is fine, but know how to coach them and help those who struggle meet them so we're not constantly worried about losing our jobs.

pros: Manage own pipeline, ability to make daily decisions on files. good incentive and bonus program. contact with customers is very limited.
cons: aggressive MPP goals, growth and development not as fast paced. base pay should be higher. do not get to focus on files or customer service as incentive is based on number of decisions. feel that customer service should be a higher priority.

review_title: A poor team lead and a lazy manager
pros: I got paid while I was there. Despite my negative experience, there are many friendly and intelligent people working there. There is a reason why their stock price is several times higher than some other global financial institutions.
cons:
"Team Lead" walked all over me, told me I was better suited to a "Data role". Sat in the next cubicle talking to our manager and saying things like "No skills", "I was ready to let him go after he did that", "I'm being very Zen about it", "He can live off his retirement", "Telephone interviews don't let you see the 'Intangables'. When auditors visited us, never introduced me, referred to me as "The Admin". I was told I wouldn't be trained further until my work was PERFECT, which it never was because the requirements were changed daily. Informing my recruiter brought me down in their eyes as a poor risk for any new position. Talking to our manager, who sits in another state, did nothing to help. When I asked how I was doing, she would ask me "How do you think you are doing?" I will try to avoid working for a remote manager in the future.
Also my application User Name/Password accesses never came. The Team lead was forced to log me in every time I needed access. Also my access badge was 1 month in coming which meant team lead walking me up from the door every day.

pros:
I had an amazing team at a large branch in a small town! My hiring manager was so amazing that I felt guilty if I didn't give 100% all day everyday.. We had weekly conference calls and if the sales/numbers from the prior week weren't up to par (which almost never happened), she would take the grunt of it. We often had potlucks, we were able to go to amazing events, we celebrated everyone's birthday (there were about 27 employees) & had an overall "family" dynamic. Of course there were clicks, office politics, etc., but I didn't involve myself in any of that.. Overall, it boils down to who you work with, who your Branch manager is & if you are good with angry people and can deal with rejection and the word "No." I do have to say that I learned a lot of valuable sales techniques there- they send you to a week long course of Banker Training (local), and if you're with a customer and have ZERO idea as to what you're doing, you can ALWAYS call the Bankers help line. Those people are AMAZING!! I still remember my first day as a Banker. Everything went smooth until we were about to close.. I had a woman come in who was in a hurry, she was rude and kept saying "what's the hold up??" Well, I remembered what they'd told me in training and I stopped panicking, and politely told her I was looking into the issue.. I called the Banker help line & was totally cool calm and collected. I said I was having an issue with her card (even though I wasn't), and the Banker on the phone soon caught on. She walked me through the process, I completed the womans transaction, and the woman never once knew that I had no clue as to what I was doing. 
Also- WF will help you with your tuition. I got my masters while working there.. I worked 40 hours/wk, and had school 2 nights/week. They were very accommodating and allowed me to leave 10-15 minutes early so I wouldn't be late.
cons:
I was a Personal Banker & fortunate to work with an amazing team at a large WF Branch. However, every Monday, we had a "Conference call," to discuss our daily/weekly/monthly sales goals. Unfortunately, near the end of my tenure at WF, corporate shifted dramatically & we were basically told to push the tellers for sales- meaning, they'd help someone who was there to deposit/withdrawal $ and want to be in and out if the ATM line was too long.. Well, the teller would have to use an insanely long scripted sales pitch and send them to a Banker. The customers-especially the "old school" people who'd been banking there for years would get extremely aggravated and upset. I worked in a small town where everybody knew everyone so that became an issue. In fact, it got to the point where they'd just come in, walk over to my desk- whether I was with a customer or not and just hover. I'd politely ask them to wait if I was with a customer, but if I wasn't, they'd just sit down (never mind the fact that I was clearly busy or on the telephone with a customer) & literally say, "can you please make a deposit/withdrawal, etc., I don't want to go to a teller because they always try to sell me something and end up sending me over to a banker anyway.." It put all of the Bankers in a bad situation & the entire dynamic of the Bank changed. Now that I'm not an employee, I can see that it's gotten worse.. I walk in to my local branch & they now have people standing around asking you what you're there for. If you say, "I need to make a withdrawal," (or whatever it is you're there to do), they keep probing you and probing you.. i e., "Do you have a savings account with us as well? (If you say yes), it's "Is it linked to your OD protection? If you say no, it's I can help you. Come with me." They then proceed to take you to a Banker and say, "So and so here is interested in a Savings account..." What the heck?! I've seen people take it with a grain of salt, but 9 times out of 10, the customer becomes extremely irritated, annoyed and a select few become irate! Because I was an employee, I was able to have the amount of $ I take out of the ATM on a daily basis increased.. But here's a secret-- YOU can TOO!! You just have to ask! If you're a good customer- no or very few overdrafts, have been a customer for over 5+ years and have an established relationship with your personal Banker, they'll raise it for you. I'm not saying everyone will, as it Is the Bankers discretion, but yes, you can get more than $300, $500 out a day. 
Also, for all the pushing they do to sell, the commission is HORRIBLE! They pay out quarterly (every 3 months). I kept a little notebook with all of my sales (they track them
Via the computer too). However, there are tons of errors. You're LUCKY if you make $800-$1000 in commission every 3 months.. But that's very rare. The average pay for a Personal Banker (DOE) is about $24,000-$30,000. So, if you think you'll make an extra $20k in commission, this is not the job for you. Be prepared to work Saturdays- they're open until 4:00pm (used to be 1:00pm), and if you work in an "in-store" Branch- i.e., inside of a Supermarket, be prepared to work later hours and Sunday's too.

pros: Some good benefits. Opportunities to move, advance within the company.
cons: Medical benefits were not great. Constantly changing the compensation plan. MPP (semi-annual and annual review) process is not good or fair. Matrix based but is not based on individual performance. Only group performance which promotes a slacker mentality by many peers. Big problem, managers are constantly changing and the reviews are given by your current manager with no consultation with previous managers.

review_title: Solid benefits, generous time off, and flex working arrangements
job_title: Operational Risk Consultant in Irvine, CA
pros: Great place to have a career, but must be proactive to find opportunities. Highly recommend moving across business lines if necessary. Lots of engagement in the community, and many lines of business offer flexible working arrangements (including working from home) but isn't always publicized.
cons: Not all WF business lines have the same talent development pipeline methodology, and in some of the offshoot businesses such as consumer lending, new hires are often outside the company. Company values experience over education, so most mid tier and senior level positions require 10+ years of direct and or/related experience

pros: Structure, training, strong vision and values. Great 401k match
cons:
senior management, too much of the "buddy buddy" system going on in the DFW area
Other regions have better career path opportunities

review_title: It was good at first went to another branch and was torn down until I quit.
pros: If you can get a good branch not to bad. Hours kind of suck I didn't get any Saturdays off. However everyone gets benefits even if your a part time employee.
cons: You don't get paid very well compared to other companies. Management doesn't care until you put your notice in. They don't like to have full time employees even when a full-time employee quits they replace them with a twenty hour employee.

pros: Regional President really cares about her Teammates and interacts with them daily. She knows each one of their names and most times knows some of the families. She has a huge Market so it's not always but nice to know she cares.
cons: Sales are a Strong and you can't always fix the Clients problems with so many departments. Middle Management can hide their faults and it can sometimes be harmful to Teammates that want to Excel.

pros: Even though Wells Fargo is a big corporate, employees are treated very well and there is a lot of room for growth if someone works hard.
cons: I believe Wells Fargo have a lot of potential in international markets and I don't understand why they haven't expanded yet. For example they should have a Wealth Management office in all cities that have a lot high net worth people residing it.

pros: The benefits are pretty good and the company has been around for a while which is good for job security.
cons: The closer you work with customer's, the less money you make. Call center positions make the least amount of money and the compensation incentives are hard to obtain and is peanuts compared to the money that you make the bank off of referring products to customer's.

job_title: Registered Personal Banker in The Woodlands, TX
pros: Good company reputation and customer service. Company benefits are great. A lot of room for growth. Competitive products and services.
cons: Expected to follow a process that is not always reasonable. Bonus structure is not competitive in the industry. Terrible branch manager which made work life miserable and probably not the norm.

pros: Lots of opportunity for growth, good benefits.  Too much favoritism between DM's and Store Managers. Some managers allowed to get away with treating employees harshly while treating others favorably. Work many Saturday's.
cons: Too much favoritism between DM's and Store Managers. Some managers allowed to get away with treating employees harshly while treating others favorably. Work many Saturday's.

job_title: Quality Assurance Analyst II in West Des Moines, IA
pros: Tons of vacation time, great pay, ability to move up is fairly easy, lots of training and do a lot for the community
cons: Sitting in cubicle all day, very repetitive, a lot of politics, people who truly work their butt off hardly get promoted, promotions normally go to people who brown nose

pros: Simple and straightforward job. Lots of Benefits.
cons: They push sales on you like crazy and now they're paying the price. If sales goals are taken out, then this job will be  a lot better. Bankers should focus on sales and Tellers should focus on transaction and customer service.

pros: Great benefits. 401k, 18 vacation days, sick time, kindercare (time off to take care of family) health insurance. Flexible schedules offered. Pay differential if you work late hours.
cons: It is a pretty stressful environment. Supervisors walk up and down the aisle screaming, "Get those referrals!" This is great for people who really enjoy sales. It is a great experience getting to learn about banking, but this is all about what products you can sell people every time you talk to them.

pros: Wells Fargo has a Great Vision and Values Statement. The company is structured to be a strong company supporter and works tirelessly to do outreach in the communities where retail banking  stores are located.
cons: Wells has forgotten that its main core value is its people. The sales culture environment puts so much pressure on employees to perform. It is unsurprising that questionable account openings have occurred.

review_title: Decent company, limited growth potential, salary is on the low-end.
pros: Decent healthcare and benefits, paid time off, friendly employees. This is a good place to get your feet wet in banking and if management likes you, you can move up. With the new lack of sales goals you are expected to focus primarily on customer service.
cons: Compensation is traditionally on the low end of the scale. If you are looking to get moved from a part-time position to a full-time one it can be a daunting task, or require you to move to another location.

pros: Some branches have a good team, I liked my coworkers.
cons: Management doesn't do much to protect you. Security protocols aren't followed which means if you're drawer is out you're screwed. Cameras don't help protect or defend you, they only show customers. Very insecure system with many flaws. It is absolutely a SALES position without the sales pay. Several coworkers acted unethically on a regular basis with management laughing it off. Management will sweep things under the rug and condoned a racially motivated atmosphere.

pros: Great Benefits, and awesome coworkers. I loved working with customers and building personal relationships with regulars. Bonuses were good.
cons: Strict sales goals, and low hourly pay. I left Wells Fargo due to the constant pressure of selling solutions to people who didnt need them. While the bonuses were good (if you met your goals) the hourly pay was low, and it was hard to move up within the company unless you met your goals consistently.

pros: Excellent coworkers and good Pay. Wells Fargo provides very good benefits. There are many opportunities to advance. You have the opportunity to make a real difference in the lives of business owners.
cons: There are many times when customers have a negative situation which may not have an easy resolutions (EX Bank fees). Often they expect the banker to which they speak to be able to fix it when there is not a fix.

pros: Great benefits and training. You have the ability to learn about banking in a far too relaxed atmosphere. If you're not goal driven, this is for you.
cons: Too scripted and inability to be yourself to accomplish your goals. WF has a set procedure for everything which in some cases is good, but not for every single interaction you have. Elimination of goals was a panicked reaction which inhibits growth.

pros: great thing about wells fargo is the PTO even if you are part time and consistency of hours.
cons: downside is that everyone working there parties and is unprofessional, their banks aren't updated, pay is low, too intense of training than what the job entails. They have these avenues of growth for employees to take, but the actual responsibilities and knowledge learned for each level is slim. People who don't want to go to college, this is a great job right out of high school because theres a lot of time to advance. Other than that, this job is only good for part time in school.

pros: Benefits are good, lots of opportunity in big cities, sales goals are currently gone from Retail
cons: Lots of political games, managers give positions to their friends who haven't done the work for it, too many chiefs and not enough workers, branches are short staffed across the board, not enough development opportunities, branch managers are often too occupied to assist with training or development because they are always on calls with their boss.

pros: 1. The money. 2. Benefits.  3. Corporate Discounts
cons: 1. The hours are a bit much. They change your schedule suddenly and then you are forced into the schedule or. You have to quit or work the hours given. They up and change your bonus structure without warning and you go from making great money to a prorate bonus. They single out certain teams and mistreat the others. It's a decent job if you are not looking for anything long term inn that environment but they will advance u quickly

job_title: Operations Clerk in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The Best team and supervisors.. When I was hired I cried and the last day I cried . Such wonderful people work for Wells Fargo.
cons: The only down fall working for Wells Fargo,  not being able to work for them longer, very hard to get other jobs even if you are already working for them.  I started filling out applications with Wells Fargo acouple months before my timed employment was up. I would love to work for Wells Fargo again.

pros: Met great people, benefits are great, many training opportunities. That’s pretty much it.
cons:
-Senior leadership needs to go to the trenches and see how their actions affect the frontline employees(what I previously did). They do not realize how their actions affect us.

-Unrealistic goals. We were ridiculously overworked.

-This is a reactive company and not a proactive company. Being a part of the company in this era is tough due to the negative press that occurs often (for some reason...). 

-Pay is ok to start, but I only received 1 tiny raise during my 2 years there (other employees I know received more than 1 raise who started at the same time I did).

pros:
Good PTO
Good Benefits 
Good starting pay
Off on holidays 
Bank gives two personal holidays
Free account
cons:
Hard to advance, been with the company for 2 & a half years, gained a business degree with Wells, have received numerous awards and done extensive volunteer work for the company. Job advancement is based off favoritism. If you apply to another branch they will most likely chose someone from their own branch, make you interview for the position just to tell you they chose someone else.

Tellers need better pay and better rotation to keep our mental state healthy. Counting money, having conversations and multitasking can take its toll on the mind eventually.
Management gets mad when you call in
Can only call out 3 times in a 6 month rolling period

Once staffing is in need of more coverage it can take a month of longer to hire new tellers and have them trained. I have experienced around 4-5 times where we have went a month or longer understaffed. This causes tellers to tire out, get sick and not want to help customers because they are overloaded.

Interview process is just scenarios and does not factor in length with the company, degree,work ethic and does not ask personal questions.

Last because of Wells Fargo’s own mistakes they are now very strict on ethics. Something small that is routine can end you with a final warning.

review_title: Culture of CYA and passing the buck
job_title: Senior Counsel in San Francisco, CA
pros: Most lawyers are personable and non-competitive. Benefits are fine.
cons: Extreme sensitivity regarding risk ends up making situations worse than they need to be. A good common sense approach is often overlooked. Beta type lawyers and business people always trying to CYA and pass the buck to shuck responsibility. Terrible pay for market. Many lawyers are not motivated and mediocrity reigns supreme. job_title: Applications Developer  in San Francisco, CA

review_title: work here if you have no ethics
job_title: Private Banker in San Diego, CA

cons: talking customers into products they do not need.  upper management encourages unethical practices.  organization is built around sales not customer service that they claim they are. All the way up through district management and market area presidents.

review_title: If you like dealing with problems, you'll love this job!
pros: Great benefits, opportunity for advancement, they value education, and good ethics.  Also, management is most often good.  Not a bad place to work.
cons: Some of the downsides of working for Wells Fargo include being the amount of pressure that is placed on you to sell products.  Phone Banker hours can be really tough as well, especially if you have a family.  With every promotion comes a new schedule.

review_title: Wells Fargo - Small business mentality within a large organization

review_title: Wells Fargo is over all not a very good place to work.

review_title: Teller Job within Wells Fargo Bank

It is up to the other bank associate to close that sale in order for the teller to receive credit for it.  Not the best way to guarantee a job.

pros: The money was great. Working collections, despite its stressful nature, pays well. The more direct personal influence you have over a company's income flow, the more you'll be paid. cons: Other than raising to higher tiers of collections, limited potential for growth in the company. Collections can become tiresome and repetitive, but that is a trait of the job, not the company.

pros: It was a job. There was very little satisfaction derived other than having a place to drive to each day.

review_title: Spent 15 years with the company, was able to advance a number of times.  Enjoyed most of the time I was there.
job_title: WFCC Supervisor in San Antonio, TX

review_title: An OK place to work depending on which department you're in.

job_title: Fixed Income Sales and Trading Analyst in San Francisco, CA

Benefits were expensive.  Any formal training was TERRIBLE.

review_title: I was a part time teller during college; I enjoyed the flexible schedule and work environment.

review_title: Costs cuts, downsizing impacting performance, morale.

review_title: Very good experience and well managed

cons: compensation and cost cutting with resources can hamper the employees and make them feel not valued.  To have a thriving organization and team it is important to not always cut corners at least not so tightly.

pros:
Branches are like your family, great team good market

2 week virtual training followed by 2 weeks of shadowing

job_title: Loan Document Specialist in Eagan, MN

review_title: Your worth is based on  production

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA

cons: The work is relatively monotonous, the work can be repetitive, once you are in one career track in can be difficult to move to another, technical computer and coding skills are required, the work can be tedious and stressful.

pros: Company with great benefits, admirable business standards, incentive program, ability to grow within. Opportunities to learn and grow independently. Full-time and Part-time positions available.
cons: The benefits certainly do not outweigh the pressure for a sale, the subpar management, or the contradictory procedures and policies. Promotions require an insatiable amount of a** kissing and showboating.

pros: Wells Fargo Home Mortgage focuses on diversity and strives to do what is right by the customer.  This makes it a great place to work.  Bankruptcy is constantly changing, and team members are able to be actively involved in improving processes and effecting change.

job_title: Security Guard I in Charlotte, NC

cons: Not much room to grow as far as security. You kind of just have to wait for someone to quit. The problem with that is that people tend to stay around here for a long time so you will be in the same position for a long time.

pros: You have a chance to connect with individuals from all over, which allows you to enhance your networking capabilities as well as propel your future.
cons: Although there has been progression, the company isn't really catering towards millennials and there desires. Thus, many people are choosing to leave the company in order to pursue entities that cater towards things such as a healthy work-life balance.

pros: They truly seem to care about their employees, giving them many different opportunities for their career. Wells Fargo is a very diverse company, and it drives its employees to understand the values behind what they do.

Unattainable sales goals, especially for a bank. Also, extremely unethical behavior that didn't even get so much as a slap on the hand. Sickening.

pros: benefits are not bad. work environment is acceptable.

review_title: Super smart people in Wealth Dept

job_title: Loan Servicing Specialist in Wells, TX
