review_title: Wells Fargo is a Class Act!
pros: Wells Fargo is one of the best banks to work for in terms of cross selling and data driven marketing.  Wells Fargo invests in the right technology to serve their customers.  The treat their employees fairly and have one of the fairest most objective bonuses processes I have ever seen, in that your bonus performance is tied to the company and individual.  The company is diverse and the do invest in their employees.  Out of all of the banks I have worked for Wells Fargo stands out as a beacon of light for fairness and just general professionalism.  Not a good old boys club at all and plenty of room to grow for Women, gay men, straight men and everyone really.  Very very good at getting the best talent from where-ever and whomever it come from!! True a great place to work.
cons: Sometimes the product silos withing the company sabbatoge getting projects done.  "Their are still a fair amount of organizational fiefdoms but that has been changing.  Wells Fargo has the infrastructure to act like a customer centric bank for sure!  But fails to act like a customer centric bank in the way they incent product line performance which is challenging when working on Corporate Project.  Many good people left the bank during a large scale project as the project silos's tend to not want strategic change from senior leaders.  The company sometime moves very slowing in their decision making.

pros:
The competition for Wells Fargo internships is really tough, but if you can make it in it's totally worth it. Pretty much all the internships can lead to full time job offers by the end...even if you're only in your junior year, a lot of employers will offer for you to come back the next summer if you express interest....which is a good thing to have in this economy. 
All WF internships are paid as well, which is nice. Depending on the internship, pay probably ranges between 12 and 27 dollars per hour...again, depending on which program you're in. There are also informal internships sometimes...it depends on the office, but I imagine compensation is similar. 

The interview process is fairly standard. I submitted an application online and then within a few days was contacted by HR to schedule a phone interview. I interviewed for positions in different locations across the US, so different interviewers contacted me at different points in time. After the phone interviews, I was scheduled to come in for a Super Day at an office where I would be working. I was interviewed by a panel of 3 people and pretty much told on the spot that they'd be extending an offer. At that point, I was contacted for an additional interview with the director at the specific office where I would be working, but that was mostly just an informal chat so he'd get a sense of who I was. The questions were mostly behavioral...a few were technical. They usually have a conference call before hand that you can listen in on to get a sense of what kinds of questions they're going to ask you on your interview. 

At the actual job, my co-workers were super nice! There were plenty of awesome training programs and events to attend. We also got to do really interesting work, and by the time I left I had made several strategic connections and had full time job offers.
cons: None that I can think of. There may be weird politics in some of the offices, but that's standard of any place and I never really noticed that it was a problem. Also, since WF is often decentralized, there isn't really a housed analyst class anywhere so a lot of co-workers will be old. However, there are programs and events to help you meet the other analyst-level young people, so you'll make connections...just don't expect a college-like environment like you might get at some other places.

review_title: I have been with the bank for years and have been overlooked for promotion too many times.
pros: Naitonal company, great benefits, generally good working conditions, empathetic managers.  Opportunities for advancement appear to be available from their job website.
cons: My experience has been that I am stuck in the department that I am in.  This is a low, entry level department that seems to preclude Human Resources from seeing a candidate's potential.  My department offers few opportunities for advancement and other departments require experience in the job being posted to be considered.  I feel that I need to take my skills elsewhere to get ahead.

pros:
- Sundays off
- For the most part, they work around school schedules
- Got to work with some great tellers
cons:
- Way too much micromanagement. Employees are observed several times throughout the day on the way they interact with customers. Every time we get done with our interactions the managers will go over with you what you did well and what you didn't do well. They do this because we get surveyed on random customers. This is done on a scale from 1-5, if we even get a 4, it's considered to be a "bad shop." This is probably the most annoying thing that wells fargo does with it's employees because it doen't matter if you've had 20 perfect shops they will continue to micro manage you with observations. They need to back off with this, if your employee is doing well with shops then you shouldn't have to do observations on him/her. 

- Managers place too much of an emphasis on sales aka solutions, they ask me everyday if I know friends or family who will open wells fargo accounts. The last thing I'm going to do is ask friends and family to open wells fargo accounts on my off days. 

- Solution system is messed up. Every solution is referred to a banker in which they have to contact the customer to finalize the sale. If all of that is successful you might get credit for the sale depending on if that same customer has already been referred by a different teller. This system is flawed because you're also suppose to send "service signals" as a referral to your manager whenever you have a disgruntled customer. This works against you because you could close someone on signing up for another account but if someone had already sent a referral for a service issue on him/her then they would still credit for that sale. It's ridiculous that people can get sales for unrelated matters, you should be able to credit for a sale that you closed. 

- Hitting bonuses are unrealistic as well, from what i've been told the goals in order to hit bonuses are the same for every store. This doesn't make sense because you could be at a branch thats 10 times slower than most branches in our market but you're still expected to hit the same bonus goal. Also, hitting a bonus is a requirement not a "bonus" if you do not hit your 1st tier bonus you will be written up. It's ironic how getting a bonus is considered expected, I thought it was a bonus because you went beyond your usual call and made extra sales. 

- Don't cap solution sales. A teller can only get a maximum of 3 solutions per customer regardless of what ever else the personal banker is able to get out of them. I can see why they did this from a business perspective but it definitely works against you as a teller. 

- Extreme punctuality guidelines. I know its expected at any employer to be on time, what gets to me is the fact that managers will still write you up for being a couple minutes late if it happens. 

- Incentives are horrible. Once again from a business perspective I understand that the company cannot give out $100 incentives but I feel like the company can do a lot better than handing out $5 gift cards or giving out company merchandise. Who wants wells fargo water bottles as an incentive to close sales? On top of that, my manager literally told me that we need to get more solutions in order for our district manager to get her bonus. This kind of thing frustrates me to hear because I can assure you that the DM is getting a much bigger bonus than I ever will see so to hear that as a motivation factor really makes me want to do the opposite and not get solutions. 

- All of these cons are coming from the retail side of Wells Fargo, I cannot obviously speak for any other department in the company.

cons: The department is very unprofessional. People are not on the phones, loud, cursing, arguing and should not be there. There are only a few team leads that know the business and none of the supervisors know anything. In training you are provided wrong information that will have to be corrected from the only team lead in the department that seems to know almost everything. Most of the leaders are looking to get you fired rather than help you succeed. You don't advance by performance. All but a few leaders have no idea what they are doing. Advancement is very difficult because the leaders are more focused on holding you back, or getting you fired rather than helping you succeed. Now I will say there are a few leaders that will help you and provide you with good advice, but only 2 or 3 out of the 10 or more leaders in the department. review_title: Used to be a great company...
job_title: Financial Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros: 401K match, number of PTO days (if a team member with longer tenure), 1 week of critical caregiving leave, parental leave benefit
cons:
Company retains low performing finance managers in Enterprise Finance.  There are managers with historical records of low team member survey scores, indicating ongoing low employee engagement and unwillingness to accept feedback or do action planning to improve management of their teams.  No accountability by senior leaders nor HR to implement corrective action or investigate these low performing finance managers.  

Some finance managers are also very inflexible about working remotely, have little respect for work/life balance, or practice double standards within their teams regarding daily attendance.  This type of old-fashioned thinking (typically from the baby boomer generation of managers) doesn't value efficiency or productivity or "as long as work gets done by deadline".  Instead, these managers count the number of hours spent in office and physical presence in office.   Not a positive for Gen X or millennial team members who actually want flexibility and work/life balance.  

Also, with E&E initiatives, opportunities for advancement or growth in Enterprise finance roles in SF Bay Area are shrinking or non-existent.  Many internal postings are steered towards lower cost geographies such as Charlotte, Minneapolis, Iowa, St. Louis.  Extremely difficult to transition to other functional roles in company unless one has significant technical skills , strategic planning/consulting experience, compliance experience, risk experience, etc.  Does not appear to be any centralized effort to evaluate / promote high performing individual contributors or manage talent pools.  

Annual bonuses keep decreasing each year.   Annual merit or salary increases are 2% or less or even zero for some team members.

review_title: Encompasses the worst aspects of a call center environment
job_title: Financial Crimes Specialist in Charlotte, NC
pros:
+The facility itself (Chick-fil-a, Starbucks, cafeteria, gym, dentist, barbershop, etc. all on site).  
+PTO
+ Promotions from within

The three weeks of classroom training is nice but it in no way prepares you for what actually happens on the call floor. You will learn a great deal about financial services in a short time. 

The department promotes from within, however you cannot transfer until after being with them for a year.
cons:
+Everything else.
+ Micromanagement
+ Verbally abusive customers that you're not allowed to hang up on 
+ Never having two days off back to back
+ Impossible to request time off within a 5 month window.
+ Quality Assurance department will fail your calls over the most illogical things.
+ Lots of stress 
+ High turnover 

Don't let the amenities on campus fool you, this is a call center job. You will be attached to your desk via headset taking one call after another for 8+ hours a day. A lot of people aren't cut out for this and if you've worked in one before then you know the deal. Every statistic is tracked and you cannot even get up to go to the bathroom without having to file an "exception" in the system. 

The calls can range from under a minute to 30-40 minutes based on the severity of the issue. Expect a healthy mix of angry customers and elderly folks that have no business having online banking in the first place.  Plus, with all the public mishaps Wells Fargo has been dealing with recently you might as well be painting a giant bullseye on yourself. 

It becomes depressing seeing how easily people share their personal information and open themselves up to fraud and identity theft. There is not a whole lot you can do for them besides sympathize and file a claim.  You'll need a thick skin and the ability to "unplug" as soon as you leave for home. 
 
This is not a career.

The amount of time my manager spent with me was shocking compared to other companies. You actually looked forward to them stopping by instead of dreading it. You are not yelled at for a mistake at all. I Love this company. I only left because my boyfriends father got leukemia in Arizona. I can reapply and come back, but I am moving.

review_title: Pretty good place to work, but a lot of room to grow
pros: Benefits are good, PTO is really nice, stores are usually furnished nicely and kept clean, has a positive reputation in the industry. Upward mobility is achievable
cons: Moving up can be a struggle, sometimes I question how managers got into their positions, pressure to sell can be overwhelming, compensation is mediocre for the amount of responsibility the job has. Personal Bankers are really the face of the company to most of its customers; when they have a problem we are who they see and who they expect to give them everything they ask for. It really is two jobs in one: customer service and sales. I think the pay should be higher for having so much to do. The bonuses are kind of a joke too, if you get silver in everything your bonus is only around $2000 per quarter, and almost half gets taken out for taxes. Since the Wachovia merger the company seems to have gotten more focused on meeting the bottom line than meeting our customer's expectations of their financial instutution.

pros: If you like almost impossible and aggressive daily numbers, this is the right place for you.  Some of the managers (including mine) genuinely care about your progress.  When you go to training, chances are you'll be 1-2 hours from home, in which they provide a nice hotel, per diem, and mileage reimbursement for roughly 19 training days.  That was a great time.
cons: Coming from Wachovia, we had a great culture and caring employees with a relaxed non aggressive sales environment.  In a way, it is the reason why Wachovia didnt survive.  With Wells Fargo moving in, things have changed alot.  Now, our days are driven by how many solutions we can get from every single customer.  It is personal opinion if whether or not it is going to help them, but regardless, you better profile every single person that comes in, even for a thumbprint and try to get them to open accounts.  The ironic thing is, a free checking account from a new client is worth more to the company then, say, a Interest Bearing CD on a daily basis in terms of solutions.  For example, a branch would need 12 checking accounts and 60 solutions, which is basically 2  equally divided amongst 6 bankers.  If you open 5 CD's in one day, but dont open a single checking account, it is frowned upon.  Each branch's atmosphere is different.  My branch had a pretty positive environment where our tellers and bankers care about the customers for the most part.  I have personally been to some, where its like walking into a fast food joint at 3am in the morning.  The hours you will work as a Personal Banker are horrendous.  Most days, you'll be in around 830-845 but are expected to work until 6pm.  If you dont have your numbers, some managers will make you work until 7.  Say good bye to saturdays if your branch is low on Bankers because you'll be working every saturday until atleast 215 with no lunch break.  The only good thing about that is, you'll have a day off during the week.  If you get sick and your low on numbers, or another banker is out, you'll be told to "suck it up" and come in anyways.  Count on always being sick, expecially flu season, because every other customer that comes in is contanimated.  You're always working, even out of work because you're expected to build leads on your own.  You're going to become "that guy or that girl" that's always asking for new accounts, merchant services, payroll, investment services, etc. Wells Fargo Partners are hit and miss.  Our branch has had really good ones that are loyal and as aggressive as you are expected to be, and some that dont care at all and never return phone calls, leaving you to look really bad infront of your customers.  Health insurance is a joke.  The only affordable insurance is the High Premium, which has a deductable so high, you might as well NOT have insurance.   Last but not least.... beware January.  That's all I can say without releasing too much information.

review_title: Once great company heading downhill fast
job_title: Personal Banker I in Austin, TX
pros:
Good pay with opportunity for quarterly bonuses
PTO
401k with company matching
Great insurance
Loved my coworkers and my customers! I have made friends for life there. I still have customers begging me to come back.
There are a lot of tools available to help your succeed.
Ability to be promoted. I started as a teller and was promoted to Lead Teller within a few months, then finished off as a personal banker.
cons:
HIGH sales pressure! This is the ultimate reason I left the company. I loved my store manager, but the sales goals went beyond reasonable. Our store just could not make its numbers, which it turn resulted into more demand on us. We had solicit businesses at their own stores, work 6 days a week, have 3 confirmed SALES appointments each day (and get in trouble if they didn't show up), stay late and makes sales calls. I've been in retail for a long time. I understand sales help a company, but when your DM is telling you to kick customers out of your office if you are not making a sale off of them its ridiculous. It got to the point that I just didn't feel morally right anymore.

Turnover was insane. In the 3 1/2 years I was there we went through 2 district mangers, 3 store managers, 6 service managers, and I don't even know how many bankers and tellers.

The benefits to this job are so good, that it was heartbreaking for me to have to leave. I just saw too many good and honest people (customers and employees) worked over by a once great company.

review_title: failure to treat employees in the same manner as the customers

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Victorville, CA
pros: Wells Fargo has very good health benifits and 401k services.  They also do profit sharing.  When you start there you are automatically given 18 days of paid vaction plus holidays.  Most branches are highly competitive, however there is almost always a family feel.
cons: Wells Fargo in general mistreats their employees.  They demand more and more without giving raises to compensate.  They also encourage their employees (vocally) to take advantage of customers by persuading them into agreeing to accept products and services that many of them really do not need.  On paper however everything is very above board and ethical, they always tell employees to do what is best for the customer first.  however many employees are written up and terminated for not acheiving the desired sales numbers and are often harrassed by management into leaving.  If one plans to work for Wells Fargo they must be prepared to faced with making a decision everyday that may violate the companies or their own code of ethics.  Another thing to remember is if you work for Wells Fargo be prepared to make markedly less than your competitors at some other banks.  In general other banks (such as Chase) pay much better, maybe not better hourly but there compensation plans are drastically better.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
- Very nice benefits package.  
- Online resources for professional development.
- Relatively open source of communication to upper management.
- If performance is high, they will pay for your licensing to become a licensed banker.
- Many opportunities to move up the ladder, but you must be very, very aggressive.
- Great hotline for direct assistance to the bankers.  Very reliable.
- Very thorough training.
- Excellent HR team!
cons:
- Sales, sales, sales, sales, sales.  This is a numbers job.  While they do watch service scores very closely, if you want to move up on either the teller or platform side, you had better have numbers.  This is an issue because...

-  Some bankers may work in a slower branch.  The branch may have lower goals, meaning the branch is held at a lower standard, but the bankers are held at the same expectation as the banker's at our busiest branches.  It doesn't seem to make sense.  I worked at a branch like that for 2 years, and I struggled with keeping up with our busiest branches' bankers constantly.  Now that I'm at a busier branch, I see both sides and frankly, it is not fair to the slower branches.
 
- Pay is not very competitive, especially for an inner city metro location.

- This is a very young company.  My district manager, service manager and branch manager are all under the age of 30.  The lack of experience shows greatly and, unfortunately, makes it harder to seek guidance.  They tend to just spout numbers at you.

- So much to do, so little time.  In addition to sales activities, you must perform operational duties (daily at some branches), account maintenance, monthly training and file maintenance, among other things.  This can get difficult on the busier days, and you find yourself buried in papers, and this is how errors happen.

- Ethics?  I've been encouraged many times by upper management to use dishonest sales practices, just short of crossing the line of the bank's ethics policy.  This is not fair to the customer, and I cannot name how many times I've had to clean up the mess someone else made.

pros: offered good benefits. had a good training program and support. opportunity to move up quickly if desired. time off when you want most of the time.

pros: They are very organized as in there alot of internal 1-800 numbers and websites for different departments. There are lots of  heatlh benefit choices, bring a notebook and a calculator ask a lot of questions during the yearly presentation. A little known benefit you get use accurred volunteering time to focus on a charity of your choice in addition to the official corporate volunteer week. So you can get paid to volunteer for a week, a month or more. There is an internal website with volunteer events to choose from. Volunteer to help other groups so you get experience with other systems and tasks. They have a decent corporate cafe with themed dishes. There is a really good Indian chef that comes in once a month. Their taco salad and Friday rooftop BBQ is pretty good too. During the holidays they have musicans perform in the museum. They serve cake and punch for the company's anniversary. My coworkers were always on the hunt for free food. They espcially liked the food gift packages abandoned in the kitchens around the holidays. They would attend career development meetings and get on email lists just to scope out the offerings at these corporate sponsored events. So there are plenty of free resouces, software, extra paid weeks off, self improvement classes and access to good food if you know the right people at this company.
cons: An internal recruiter once told me that they only pay 80% or so of the listed salary for a open position. Why? So they is room for pay increases once you are hired. You must stay in a postion for at least a year before you can transfer. Hiring managers appear to prefer outsiders to insiders. Lots of positions are prefilled before they are posted online, as in they know who they are hiring for a role but the Staff Mgmt system generates a opening when there is none. S.F. is ground zero for lay offs at the moment. They lay off there and then turn around hire in cheaper  and more business friendly states like Ohio and S. Carolina. Apply for open postions in any location, if they like you they will let you commute but your payrate may be for another "zone". A coworker once warned us to be careful of what location you work at, telecommuting or working in an isolated office can hurt  your career. As in It's hard to prove yourself if you are not in the main office making connections with decision makers. The best way to move up is to move to Charlotte, make connections, or apply out of state. Ask good questions during meetings if you want to get noticed and build your brand image. Choose your manager well to make sure they will support your career, otherwise you will be in the same postion for 10-20-30 years. review_title: It's what make you make it.
pros:
You learn how the banking world and finances work.

cons:
This isn't a job for someone in their late 20s unless you enter the company as a banker or higher.

They also create "Dictator" managers instead of the "Hands on, help my team out" managers. 

Starting out wage raised from $12.00 to $13.50 which it was only raised to match their competitions wages at entry level positions. This raise did not effect anyone higher than tellers. It was also given during the big scandal bust of all those reported fake accounts made.

Every branch doesn't follow the same ruling, so what you learn at one branch can be wrong at another or they just don't do what you learned at all. So the training is not interchangeable from branch to branch.

review_title: Only review you need for Sioux Falls Area, no opinions just facts
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Sioux Falls, SD
pros:
Wells Fargo is a great employer, depending on what you are looking for as a career.  If you just want to make a basic salary, no plans on moving or management, this is a for sure for you.  Pay checks are always on time, don't bounce and just being an employee gets you discounts with other companies.  

The only real winners in Sioux Falls are IT backgrounds.  They are in high demand here.  Here is how you win if you are IT, start in WF, spend 2 years here... leave for a different company, come back after 2 years you will be paid very well.  This is the only job category that it is possible to move up easily.

Your first step up will come very quickly.  Example you will move from a Banker 1 to a Banker 2 within your first year.  Which seems like you are on the right path.  But....
If you want to shoot for the stars, and really move up... make your stay short, 1-3 years in Sioux Falls.  Get your feet wet and move on to another city and you will see more opportunities for advancement.  I'm not talking about moving to Fargo or Omaha, you will have to move to St. Louis, Charlotte, New York, Denver... something with actual variety. If you have any ambition of moving up... you cannot stay here, you have to move on to a bigger market.

Benefits are cheap and with BC/BS it is accepted anywhere, Amount of PTO you get at Wells Fargo is unmatched  (You get 4 weeks to start then 5 in your 3rd year). 
6% 401K match... you wont find many companies that will be this high.
Co-workers are fantastic in any area.
90% of the managers really care about you.  Odds are you will get a good one.
Once you get to management you made it.  Your pay will be great and your workload can go to zero if you have a good team.  Often see them walk around or leave for two hours at a time because their is nothing for them to do.
Senior management are smart and drive the company forward.  (get to their cons below) Don't just listen to the media about the CC fraud.  Those people were absolute crooks and should be in jail.  WF has cleared them out (hopefully) and has made great efforts to make things right.  Those individuals represent a fraction of a percent of the employees here.  They were the bad egg that needed to be thrown out. 

This next part is for a smaller group, and i don't mean to offend anyone.  Just trying to give you a one up on everyone.

If you are a part of a minority group, and you are a good employee... you have a leg up.  Sioux Falls area is so plain vanilla, and WF has been on a huge diversity kick, if you are not part of a majority you will be sought after.  For initial hire, promotions, leadership groups, you name it.  Again i don't mean to offend anyone by this comment, and I may have, I apologize, just giving you information so you can make your choice to pursue WF as an employer.

WF is a huge company in almost every city in the US.  You want to move and stay with WF... you have that opportunity.

Maternity/Paternity leave is now 4 months... yes guys get it too.

Accommodating to people with disabilities.
cons:
PTO - Some departments it is very hard to use PTO, most areas in Sioux Falls are call center based so you will have deal with a waiting list for popular days off (holidays M, F, Sat, Sun,)  Good luck with those requests as it is not based on a local level only, you factor in other call centers around the U.S, so you are competing against everyone for the day off.

Advancement - very little opportunity.  You are playing the waiting game, doesn't matter how hard you work, how educated you are, or whatever extras you do... you are waiting for someone to retire, move, or take a different job.  We are not talking about 1-2 years, it is more like 5-6.  Sure they will open up new positions every now and then, but they are not advancements... you may see a 1-2K bump in pay but it is essentially the same job, but with more things to do that your manager does not want to.
Once you reach management you are set, but getting to management is close to impossible.  They will hire from outside the company instead of hiring within for management.  If they do hire from within, you are competing against 20-30 other applicants, and most of your co-workers.  Some managers don't care to learn what their employees do, they are just there to manage and if you get one of them they will let you know that.  Your team lead is always a better option for questions.
Getting hire for a team lead position is just as difficult.  This is most always hired from within but again you are always competing against (depending on the size of your department) 20-50 people for the job including most of your co-workers.

Pay - the later you start the better. You will see new hires making more than you.  Once you are hired you are stuck with the pay, if you are a top employee you will be asked to help train new hires that are making $1-2/ hour more than you.  Bringing this up to management is pointless.  They will tell you there is nothing they can do, wont even make a pitch to HR for you saying you deserve it.  Remember, senior management (corporate) get bonuses based on how much money they make/save the company.  They would rather put $100 in their pocket than $4-5000 in yours.  They are located in another city, and don't have to look you in the eye every day so they feel no guilt. 

WF knows this but doesn't care, you will be paid 20% less to do your job here in Sioux Falls than it cost in other cities.  Not because the cost of living is higher, Sioux Falls cost of living is just as high as most major cities in the U.S.  Look it up you will be surprised,  it is because they don't want to pay you what your cost of living actually is.   They move jobs here because we work for less.. maybe that is our fault.

You are expendable, unfortunately.  They will hire a new person to do your job, loyalty does not always get you anywhere.   Call center environments are just like that... next man up.

Most departments have a points system they use for unexcused absences.  If you are tarty or miss too many days you can be terminated.  This would make sense right??? but they take it to the extreme.  I have seen at least 50 fantastic employees get terminated because their child got sick too many times and they had to miss work because school/daycare will not allow the child to attend while sick.  If your manager is one that follows the book exactly, you will be on a verbal warning in your first year, if you have kids that get sick from time to time.  They will constantly remind you of your attendance status.  This also has driven 100 or more other good employees, that I have seen, to seek a new jobs because there is no flexibility in their policies.  Managers don't seem to have to follow these rules, they can come and go as they please... they don't practice what they preach.  If you are in a call center, they go off the time you log into your phone, so they have a record down to the second of when you started your day.  Parents/Guardians with children, may want to look elsewhere... the extra $1 an hour would not be worth the stress to join WF.

review_title: Personal Banker I - Good entry level position
pros:
• Building great rapport and extended relationships with customers who specifically ask for you. Very rewarding and flattering feeling when you are the best person to assist someone, in a customer’s eyes

cons:
• Difficult to deal with people in negative situations

• Many company policies did not make it easy to resolve issues. Very stressful at times because of this

• Micromanagement is present in many areas. Some day-to-day practices just seemed like extra work and a waste of time. Prevented me from providing a truly organic customer experience

• Salary is sub-par until you are promoted

In many cases, Personal Bankers are not given the authority to solve a customer’s issue by themselves alone. Much of my time was spent jumping on the phone to different internal department specialists to solve issues. This was very helpful in a lot of cases, but there were also many cases that I’d have to reach out to a specialist for an issue that could have been easily fixed by myself alone - had I only been given the authority. Sometimes those internal phone calls had me being transferred around and sitting on hold for 30+ minutes at a time - all while the customer is staring at me waiting for an explanation for the hold-up. Very awkward and stressful at times — not to mention confusing and irritating for the customer.

This job is more of a customer support role than anything. It takes the right kind of people-person who can effectively deal with negative situations and problems. Sometimes it involves having to struggle to find a feasible solution that is within unclearly defined company policies. Managers are there for support, but some situations can become very stressful.

review_title: Have a high tolerance to being tied to a phone all day trying to sell to angry customers, then this job is for you!
job_title: Phone Banker in El Monte, CA
pros: Great benefits package with many options, 401k with matching.  Free coffee and hot chocolate, and vending on each floor.  Cafeteria on site.  Offers benefits even to part time employees.  Job security, if you can truly tolerate your position and want it, and can upsell.
cons: I was hired as Customer Service when in fact, it was really a sales job.  95% of the calls you receive are complaints, mostly with customers who are overdrawn and angry about the overdraft fees.  In addition to telling them they (probably) aren't getting many, if any, fees reversed (which is understandable to those who don't bother to keep tabs on their spending, and actually think the bank is supposed to do that for them) But to make matters worse, you are then expected to upsell, oops I mean "refer" those angry, hostile people over to next level sales for some other product they either really don't want or ultimately won't qualify for. (Example: Person who takes Direct Deposit Advance at 120% interest, and then has to keep taking them over and over because they've extended themselves and it's an endless cycle.  You recommend they take out a line of credit or credit card. Most know when they won't qualify hence taking out a 120% APR payday advance.)  Training was okay, although you are talked down to as if (or just in case this is) your first job.  Once you are on the phones, you are stuck in a dark cubicle all day every day taking these negative calls, with no real time for comeraderie or to even say hello to your fellow employees.  The word monotonous does not even begin to describe the job.  You felt guilty even going to use the restroom if it wasn't break or lunch because your supervisor is alerted when you aren't taking calls, so that plus Q.A. monitoring basically means you are micromanaged electronically and tied to your desk.  (Interestingly, there was a class action settlement recently from another department for this very infraction.)  Like most sales jobs, supervisors are promoted based not on how well they can manage people, but how many sales they made.  You can be a great salesperson but an awful manager and vice-versa.  Those are two separate skill sets.  I got along fine with my manager, but most did not like her (behind her back.)  Had it truly been a service job, without the emphasis on sales, I could have probably tolerated it a little longer, but as it was I faced burnout after only 2 1/2 months with the company.  And that last month I had to talk myself into not walking out during break.

review_title: Very well put by: Wells Fargo – “Solution Slinger, widget wonder.”
pros: 401K was pretty good and if you can kiss ass and perform the "Cons" wells you can move up easily.
cons: The problem with Wells Fargo retail bank is the whole idea of "two and ten." I get sales and I'm all for being aggressive but the fact of the matter is, that banking is a relationship based business and selling a bunch of "widgets" doesn't work. Based in an affluent neighborhood getting 2 checking accounts per day can be next to impossible. Really we have come to the point where we have to sell "internet checking accounts," "travel checking accounts," and don't forget the "bill pay account" None of these lead to customer loyalty which is ultimately what banking is about. The fact of the matter is that Wealthy clients will stay with a bank based on customer service and rates, not having eight products which include online banking, bill pay and a debit card. I have seen more money flow out of the bank due to low rates than I have seen new accounts open. Management encourages poor behavior by rewarding those who game the system. The only problem with this is that I wonder how much money this bank loses due to the fact that checking accounts get opened and closed on a quarterly basis. If someone loses a check, guess what that's a new account even though every banker knows they transfer account. Having trouble with overdrafts. Let's close out your old account and open up a new one so we can start with a clean slate. Lost a debit card, let's close it out and order a new one, solution. You're in college and and your broke, have you thought about opening up a bill pay account. review_title: Low Pay, Unrealistic Working Conditions, Awful Management
pros:
There were a few pros about working with WF. One of them would have to be the personal connections made with local business owners and employees for those businesses. Due to my work ethic, I was able to branch out from WF and use those connections to find a job that utilized my capabilities. 

The next would be their health insurance for full-time employees. Full-time or Regular employees are those that work over 30 hours a week. They also offer a pretty good tuition reimbursement plan, but you have to stay with Wells Fargo for a year after your last reimbursement, or else pay it back.

They hire freely and openly. If you're looking to get your foot in the door at another Financial Institution, but haven't been able to do so, this is a good starting point. Wells Fargo can't compete for real Financial Institution talent, so they have to train everyone on banking rules and regulations. After being there a few months, you can now approach other Financial Institutions for jobs and be seriously considered.
cons:
Where to begin. First off, unlike any other bank in existence, WF believes you have to stand your ENTIRE shift, and sometimes those were 10/11 hour shifts if you worked open-close (usually 7:45-6:45/7PM). There is something about standing that WF thinks makes it too "impersonal" when working with customers. Although several customers used to ask why I wasn't sitting. That always bugged me, I'm okay with standing for my shift, but when it is 10 hours with just one 1-hour lunch break? (Yeah, don't ask for your 15 minute break required by law, you will be laughed at)

Second, management expected you to do more than what you were paid to do. Including taking on part of their job. I wasn't there for more than 2 months before I was training a new teller. The Lead Tellers didn't want to train the new people so it was the other tellers who had to pick up the slack. After all my unofficial management and training experience, I applied for the Lead Teller position, only for it to be given to the manager's friend.

Third, their "commission" is ridiculous. It's based on quarters, and I would be lucky if my "commission bonus" was over $200. That was meeting the quotas and reaching "Gold" for several of the Quarters. This is the reason they pay so low, is because they promise commission. I was embarrassed to tell my other Teller friends, working at the other two Big Banks (Chase & BofA) how much my hourly was because chances were they were making $2-3 more an hour, not including their commission.

Management is weakly trained, and have unreal expectations. Most managers I encountered had no inkling of Management Philosophy and how to lead a team. Their decisions were poor and unfounded and drove people away from WF. Wells Fargo mostly promotes from within, but only using the buddy system. The people that got promoted knew the hiring manager and were friends with them. It was never based off of qualifications, because the best employees always left for better paying jobs after being ignored for so long. It ended up being a redundant cycle of nepotism promotions, which can be very discouraging, as you can imagine.

Human Resources, both regional and national, will always back up management and find a reason why the employees were the ones at fault. Even after a letter and a formal complaint was signed and sent to Human Resources. The follow up was to send a HR Manager from a different region to have a sit down with the employees, and promise resolutions, only to deliver nothing.

review_title: I tell people. Teller. Get it? I'm funny.

If you're not, those above you will put forth the effort to help you improve, as long as you show a desire to do so. if you don't wish to improve, you shouldn't be working there anyway. review_title: It's a call center for a large corporate bank. ● Not much different then any other large corp.
job_title: Inbound Phone Sales Specialist I (S A F E ) in Shoreview, MN
pros: Their vision and values. Culture & Diversity. Promote from within atmosphere. Good people.
cons: Work/life balance. Unfortunately the service side (Phone Banker) call center departments are too quickly refering products over to the sales side. Customers are typically being misinformed from the service side or being offered products solely off of System Generated Marketing offers - which do not guarantee said offers even with prequalified offers/direct mail offers. (That due to federal&bank guidelines we can't discourage anyone from credit, even if say customer states they just declared bankruptcy, or other legitimate financial concerns) This causes customer disgruntlement due to negative effects it can have on their credit.  **system marketing doesn't line up with company's vision and values of helping everyone succeed financially // high turnover in service side causes bad referals to continue to be a problem. Not Acknowledged by Higher Ups : they treat the service side phone bankers as if they're supposed to be entry level fast food workers in that perspective. Their in "The army trenches" as one supervisor stated when un-empathatically discussing the issues caused from that sides turnover. Versus trying to find an actual resolution. Once/if you realize or run into this potential perspective from supervisors. You may unfortunately reconsider their Vision & Values in Practice when it comes to how they see different departments. ** You can easily be disqualified from incentives/commissions, even if you greatly excel over the metrics needed. The "generous" Vacation Time/PTO is hard to get accepted/approved unless in very short periods of time. (Day or two). Which is also tied into sick days, absenses, etc. So you're forced to use it if you do happen to get sick or have emergency situations. So don't use it all up. (Use it or lose it PTO btw). Even if you're doing the best supervisors are required to micromanage their teams and coach you on something, which normally means sacrificing something else in the process for metrics. Bringing in max profits over the entire dept? Still not good enough. You're spending too long on calls, even if you're bringing in 10x as much as the next person doing Proper Needs Accessing and building actual relationships. Plain and Simple; it's a corporate call center first and foremost. And don't be tricked by the term "Inbound" Sales Specialist. This job is essentially the same as retail sales job. Sifting through candidates, either setting up Junk Online Services and Billpay and dealing with plenty of upset customers on a daily basis. You may get lucky to Actually help someone with a credit product, debt consolidation, equity use, etc. But majority of your calls will be Minor Services that Service should take care of unfortunately. (Which would probably reduce their churn over if they'd be compensated for doing so.) . I'd recommend choosing retail over a call center if available, since phones allow/encourage ppl to be a lot more rude. And no, you cannot hang up on people. For those new to call centers.

But, nothing is done about it on a local level because they are making their boss look good, so they turn the other way.  It is EXTREMELY difficult to make morally correct decisions AND be successful at Wells Fargo as your career progresses. I do feel like I would have been "reassigned" to another position before long if my branch continued not to exceed goals.

job_title: Vice President in San Francisco, CA
pros: After over a decade here, I have to say that the friends you make here make it a great place to work. If you work long and hard enough, you begin to accumulate some tenure–based benefits, like extra time off. You also establish your network across a very large matrixed infrastructure that allows you to still get things done, or at least know who to call. The company isn't truly "customer centric" they want to be, and are investing in the processes and insights to eventually get there.
cons:
You may come to Wells Fargo with competitive market pay, but expect to get 1% to 1 1/2% pay increases every year, if you are lucky. Maybe 2% if you are a stellar employee and work 60+ hours a week, AND your boss really loves you and is willing to give you more comp at the expense of everybody else on the team. 
There are a lot of pockets of incompetent managers who are promoted because they delivered one big thing, they schmoozed the right senior manager, or they fooled somebody when coming in from the outside. You may find yourself stuck under one of these people and need to quickly move to another department in order to salvage your career, which I have had to do a few times. They also tend to play favorites in a very obvious and shameful manner, as is the case and the new innovation group, which is unusual for such a large policy-driven company. This drags down morale and often drives talent out of the company. 
One term you will hear all the time at Wells Fargo is "Boomarang." Those are the people who finally left for a couple of years so that they could come back at the level and pay that they had earned while working here – sometimes for over 10 to 15 years. It's a good place to work for a couple of years to pad your resume before moving on to a more egalitarian environment.

Yes. Script.  The steps of SHINE represent smile, handshake, introduce yourself, and so on. I can’t even remember now but you’ll be required to remember on the job which made it extremely mind clouding to juggle a robotic script while being a human at the same time.  I think a lot of my customers could sense the insincerity in the way we threw pitches at them and it would create a strain of energy within myself and how other employees interacted with one another. If someone can make it through 2-3 intense interviews, I would think that the new employee’s ethics and character would be permissible to allow for individual growth.... but NO. Might as well hire anyone off the street with no customer service background, character or integrity because well, the script will get them in line with our vision!  Prior to even working with WF, my family (who left banking with WF) would be frustrated with the phony over zealous “here to help” robotic mentality they portray.  It’s a smoke screen.   Let your customers shine in their special ways and in their God given gifts and if you see anything that is unethical then realign the mentality of the employee. Don’t clip the birds wings before you see how far they spread! Unfortunately WF hires these amazing people on board with the company to just surprise them with scripts and breathing down their backs, it is insulting as well as ridiculing. cons: Depends on team. US counter part team will transfer useless work to Indian teams which they don't like to do.

job_title: Personal Banker in San Antonio, TX
pros: Benefits, wells Fargo is dedicated to employees and customers. So much growth !
cons: Low level management can be jerks and snakes. But higher level management is amazing. But HR is there to listen ! Depends on your manager at the branch and bankers available, you might or might not have any saturdays off for months at a time.

review_title: Wells Fargo loves sales persons ONLY...if you can't sell you'll be miserable.
job_title: Registered Personal Banker in Houston, TX
pros: It looks good on your resume and you can learn a lot from working there. Occasionally you will have a good manager who will support your growth in the company. If you are really good in sales then they will love you to death. If you meet goals then you get to go on trips and through out the quarter there are several different prizes you can win. The benefits are good and you can make a lot of connections.  They offer to pay for your school. Your coworkers become you family.
cons: Managers nag a lot. They will bring down your morale if you aren't up to their expectations. The pressure is incredibly high. Managers have a habit of breathing down your neck and making you feel really low. There is little support from most of them because they are never there to assist you when you need it or they micro manage you to the point that it becomes counter productive. Wells Fargo creates a very greedy enviornment and personality. If you mess up don't expect the company to help you, you are at their disposal like a drop of a pin. There is little stability in the job. It is almost like they are ready to get rid of you with the littlest mistake.

review_title: A great career opportunity for a team player
job_title: Credit Manager in New Castle, DE
pros: The company is great for anyone under 30 years old, especially college graduates. Entry level - Credit manager is a sales/customer service position handling real estate, auto and personal loans/lines of credit. Every employee has an abundance of responsibilities and quickly amass experience in customer communications, data analysis, management and other skillsets. The company gives a nice base salary but the monthly bonuses have potential to match the base salary. Wells Fargo has a nice benefit package that gives employees the benefit of up to 20 personal days per year. The company is great at awarding high performing employees with reward dinners and trips.
cons: At Wells Fargo the base salary is fairly small compared to industry standards. The bonus structure is very rigid and is based upon not only mortagages but other product/unit/volume sales as well. A bonus payout can vary up to 100% if dependent on one variable. The company promotes an independent work environment but fails to empower employees to much extent. Wells Fargo has a rigid structure to solicitaction, and processes that basically ensure that each is employee is doing the same thing at the same time. Wells Fargo needs a better compensation structure, and create more diverse work opportunties outside of the home office.

review_title: If you are a glutton for punishment, Internet Services Group for Wells Fargo is for you.
job_title: Senior E-Business Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Stability, great paid time off benefits (~20 days), great people (peers)
cons: Depends on the group, but in Internet Services Group, it has extremely low morale, incompetent people are constantly promoted over more deserving folks, far too many politics, bell curve review / pay increase & bonus structure doesn't reward a strong team of people, Senior leadership for the most part have no leadership skills and are very out of touch with their customers as well as their employees.

review_title: A great company to start out with...but you're just another number as time goes by.
pros: For getting started out in the financial services industry, it offers a great training program and environment to quickly learn in.  You experience 4-8 weeks of training and then the rest is on the job training or more like "learn as you go"  Also, the benefits package is one of the best that I have seen and the 401K match is very nice.  It's a multicultural company with people from many different ethnic backgrounds.
cons: Your schedule is basically 6 days a week because of the extended hours.  The sales goals are ridiculous.  It's nearly impossible to achieve your bonuses and that is even with working very hard every single day for a quarter straight.  If you are lucky enough to reach your bonus, it's very small and not worth the effort.  In smaller cities, the opportunity for growth is limited with the main positions being, teller, banker, store manager.  If you're in the bigger cities there are more opportunities.  The pay is average compared with other banking jobs but it's hard to get raises and promotions and I've seen people get promoted because they had high sales numbers when that was only because the banker was "gaming" and doing things unethically but then got promoted.

pros: It is a job in this economy.  Outside of the benefits, there are no other reasons to work for Wells Fargo.
cons: No formal recognition, the management team doesn't know what they are doing and are constantly berading team members about sales.  We are selling our perverbial butts off in a down economy with customers and no credit...DUH.

pros: The standout reason to me would be their benefits package. As soon as you start you have 160 hours worth of paid time off for the year (sick days are included). Their 401k plan isn't too bad (up to 100% of 6% contributed to plan, 100% vested after 3 years). There are multiple departments to choose from which create an assortment of different job areas.
cons:
This may vary from department from department but I found that it seems very easy to pigeonhole yourself in a certain job with little to no advancement within your business group. Those who were fortunate enough to get out of my department seemed to only migrate to 3 other career paths. Those who found 'advancement' within the department receive new job titles but still manage to do the same grunt work they tried to escape at their old position and get maybe a 3% pay increase. If you want to work within the various technology related groups you are more or less confined to California, Arizona, Iowa and Minnesota unless you have to have the option to entirely telecommute. The pay for most jobs seems to fall below comparable jobs within the industry but Wells Fargo says the benefits fill that void (which to a certain extent they do). 

Working in a tech related job lets me see how the various business groups we support operate. At times I'm baffled at the ridiculous procedures in place that hinder not only our group but those we support. I find myself apologizing to customers for things that are out of my control yet can't express my sympathy due to the nature of my job.

There also generally seems to be many individuals who do not have any type of post secondary schooling or those who did obtained degrees from diploma mill type schools. This is not to meant to offend but it would be comforting if at least the management had more worthy credentials.

review_title: Not a bad place to work
job_title: Web Developer in San Francisco, CA
pros: The benefits were great, the coworkers easy to work with, and the work/life balance was wonderful.  The projects were actually very challenging, if somewhat dry.
cons: Communication from senior management seemed poor to non-existent.  The projects we worked on were VERY dry.  There wasn't much room for creativity or out-of-the-box ideas.  One would say that banks are expected to be that way, though.

pros: Provides excellent training, networking opportunities, and plenty of opportunities to grow within the company. Wells Fargo definitely employs good management that is capable of recognizing potential successors and achievers.
cons: High turnover rates for retail positions. Office politics have a stronger influence on performance evaluations the higher you climb up the corporate ladder, but this seems to exist amongst most if not all corporations.

review_title: Only useful for gainful employment.  That's it.
pros: The life insurance is good.  They take less irresponsible risks when it comes to loans and credit products compared to other banks.  They do seem to be interested in diversity in the workplace.
cons: The goals are out of touch with reality.  It takes an unreasonable amount of work and effort to do well in all of the categories you are evaluated on.  As you work on one area, you tend to decline in another one.  And the compensation you get for the work is very low relative to the amount of work you do.  Even if you are a top performer they could care less about keeping you.  If you leave, their attitude is "Oh well, maybe the next one will work out."  You get very few company perks like you would at other banks.  And it is very unstable.  They change their policies every day, LITERALLY.  And then you could get counted off on quality assurance scores, hurting your potential for payout, as if you were supposed to know that this and that policy changed yesterday. Punishing people for not following policies they have not been informed of is ethically wrong... period.  It is a fixed game to make sure no one makes too much money by staying too long.  The health insurance is terrible.  Even for the higher cost options you really don't get much.   The management only promotes people who are young and cute, if you know what I mean.  The customers are not treated well.  We are encouraged to sign up the customers for products they don't understand or need.  This only harms them in the long run.

review_title: Earning a living in the mortgage industry
pros: In the current mortgage climate, Wells seems to still care about the consumer and not just the bottom line. The benefits were the best I've had in the 18 years in the mortgage business. Seems to attract good people.
cons: Just the mortgage business in general is a very difficult environment right now. A large percentage of people don't qualify for a home loan and those who do are prone to wander if the rates drops even a tiny bit. Hard to keep people happy.

review_title: OK place to work, but don't expect hard work to be noticed
pros: Good benefits including many healthcare options and non-traditional benefits like paid time off to volunteer, backup childcare, legal services, etc.  Also the campus is nice, there is a big gym and free parking.
cons:
There is a giant disconnect between legacy firms, not only attitudes between employees but also at a firm-wide level.  Where you originated will determine your pay, corporate title and how you are treated.  Wachovia bought A.G.Edwards, and that is apparent.  Wachovia folks have higher salaries, less work, and corporate titles (and with them, reserved parking spots, while the A.G. Edwards folks trek it out to their cars every day).  The Wells merger has not made its impact yet.  The company has been so focused on mergers that hard work goes unnoticed.  Also, the cafeteria is not very good and it is expensive and there are few alternative options within walking distance.  And finally, enough will all of the meetings!  This company is too big for its own good.  Nothing gets done because 20 people have to be on board first.  And 3 of them are on PTO this week, and 2 are traveling next week....
Also, there are supposedly a lot of job openings, but the requirements are very extensive (even the people in those jobs don't meet them).  College degrees mean nothing here, they just want you to have 10 years experience already for the job you want.

review_title: I dreaded going to work very day I worked for the company.
pros:
Pay is better than minimum wage.
Benefits offered by the company are fairly decent.
cons:
"Motivation" often consists of threats, usually involving loss of your job, even if you are performing above standards.  These threats are often issued as a blanket statement to the entire "team", frequently at meetings.
Sales goals are extremely aggressive.  Be prepared to make every interaction you have with a customer about finding a "solution" for them ("solution" being the company jargon for banking product).
If you wish to advance in the retail side of things, be prepared to completely sacrifice your life to this company.  Store managers seem to be expected to put in 60+ hour work weeks.  Other managers can expect 50 or more hours weekly.  Bankers and lead tellers can also expect their work weeks to routinely go well over the 40 hour mark.  Pay does not seem to reflect these demands at this level.  Additionally, the company seems to be expanding business hours at their retail locations on approximately an annual basis.  Anyone who still believes in the myth of "banker's hours" really should not even consider this as employment.
Evaluations for an individual's level of customer service are arbitrary at best.  Customers are called after an interaction with an individual bank employee and are asked to rate their interaction with that employee.  Great in theory, but in reality, unless you receive a perfect rating on every aspect of the survey, you have completely and utterly failed.  The rating is also only supposed to be rated on the service given by the particular employee- not the customer's feeling towards the company, another location, another employee, the current light in which banks in general are viewed or any other factor.  The simple fact of the matter is if the survey is given by a customer who has any problem with the company whatsoever, they have found their outlet for their frustrations, and what they think of the service you gave them is totally irrelevant.  As an example, a survey was given for a teller who corrected a problem created by an error made by a different teller at a different branch.  The end result?  The teller correcting the problem received a very low rating due to the customer's frustration the problem ever happened, though when queried by management, the customer said he was very happy with the service provided at the time of the correction.  The result for the teller?  Meetings and counselings to correct the problems with the service she provided.

review_title: Don't be fooled, you may have a good experience but a some point you will gave a bad experience and it will be miserable
pros: Time off, if you can get it when YOU need it.  Benefits are good.  The possibilities are endless if your willing to brown nose, step on a few people and your boss likes you.
cons: First of all don't be fooled and if you work there and are happy someday that will change, trust me. Upper management is all about numbers.  For the most part they could care less about you as a person. Received no praise or recognition when I did do something good. As a manager all I heard about from my manager was meeting my sales goal. My sales goal increase were between 11 and 26 percent.  Most of them were 20 percent or more.  When I did hit my sales goal my annual bonus had nothing to do with hitting my goal, but my managers did.  I didn't get a raise and received a 3 on my performance review.  Wells Fargo is not a place for your individual characteristics to shine.  Upper management wants to clone you to do EXACTLY what they want.  One month I exceeded my sales goal by 25 percent and was written up for not following and embracing "the process.". So if your hitting the numbers but not doing it their way you'll hear about it.  The really don't value their people or their customers.  If you have a 26 percent increase in this economy at some point your going to have to sell a product that someone doesn't need.

review_title: Overall a stable company with consistent expectations.
job_title: Home Loar Processor in Beaverton, OR
pros: good amount of time off, great lower level managers
cons: Lower pay than industry average and lack of a clear recognition and rewards program. They work you like a horse and tell you to do more with no overtime and consistently increase your workload to the point of burnout.   Lack of LOTS of training but is too general to be useful.

pros:
Highly competitive environment
Recognition for high sales performers
Benefits & Company programs
Paid Time Off
Tuition reimbursement
Customer Service driven
Great systems for tracking
Extensive training
Quarterly & Yearly Recognition for top performers
Weekly challenges to win gift cards $5.00-$25, etc.
Incentive Pay based on sales: Tellers can get up to $3.00 per solution if they make 150+ referrals for products & services; Service Managers up to $1925 per quarter plus WOW Service Scores= $200/month for best scores.
cons:
High pressure to meet goals *sometimes unrealistic*
Constant coaching to 'improve' without much praise for job well done
high turnover/staffing issues
Systems for tracking- monitored for every behavior (sales, customer service, balancing, etc. - very micromanagement)

Management says to coach up or coach out
Leadership has hidden agendas / politics (know the right people..)
Lack of communication (get this report to me by 12 noon today, I need it for a call...and it's 10 am)
Lack of teamwork and support (everyone looks out for themselves, cya)
Low morale due to high pressure
