Regional guidelines are higher than corporate guidelines: you have to get Level 3 (out of 4) Performance (Sales) to keep from being written up regionally while getting INCENTIVE pay and may lose your job while earning incentive. **Politics help here***
Stores are constantly pressured to meet 150% of goal on a weekly basis.
Customers unhappy with Wells Fargo fees- take out frustrations on staff.

review_title: Nearly 10 years and the stress became unbearable
pros: About the only good reason I can come up with to work at Wells Fargo is to take advantage of their training. Many competing banks chose their new hires from employees who were trained at Wells. I believe that is because it is the strictest and most harsh sales environment there ever could be.
cons:
The whole company may not be like it is in River Cities Arizona, however I gave nearly 10 years of my life to that company and all I got in return was stress caused illness and the lowest self esteem ever. The rigorous sales environment is over the top. It is a constant; by the minute focus on sales. What is even worse is the goals are made at the state level! As we all know there are different demographics throughout each state and to ask a banker in a small town to achieve the same goals as a banker in a big city is exorbitant. 

Management literally holds your security in your position over your head every chance they get. When you make decent money and have a home and a family but suffer through being threatened to lose it all each and every quarter (sometimes more) it get so overwhelming it is hard to take. 

The only qualification you need to have to advance in the company is good sales numbers! PERIOD! Does not really even matter how you got them. Also doesn't matter how much management experience you have to become a manager; so long as you got the numbers! 

Basically that is all Wells Fargo is about! Numbers, numbers, numbers and at ANY cost! BEWARE!

review_title: Solid company with stable prospects but not much adventure
pros:
Work / life balance
Provides a stable employment opportunity
Leadership and management genuinely care about the individual employees
Not too demanding
cons: Wells Fargo has an implied "no firing" policy so there tends to be a lot of dead weight around.  Also, because the aspirational goals of the company are modest, the most capable and driven "A-type" employees don't land here.  Colleagues are solid but not exceptional.

job_title: Personal Banker in San Francisco, CA
pros: Steady hours, descent pay, good vacations benefits. Wells Fargo is overall, a great bank with good products.
cons: Way too high and unreasonable sales goals. Its all about numbers. Numbers, numbers and more numbers. Thats all the company really cares about. They pretend to to be super nice to customers and care about how their weekend is going, when its all a fake act, when indeed there's strings attached. Managers literally make you feel as though your not doing your job if god forbid you, miss sales one day.

pros: A job with Wells Fargo will get you into the financial services industry, even if you don't have a college degree. Most of the rank and file employees are good, honest, hard-working people who go above and beyond for each other and customers
cons:
Where Wachovia Bank was known and respected for their excellent customer service, Wells Fargo is slowly eroding that reputation away in the Northeast. Relationship banking has yielded to transactional banking, where it's more about sell, sell, sell than actually taking care of customers and their needs. Micromanagement is out of control - it's not uncommon for store managers to be on conference calls six times a day. No thought, concern, or respect is show by middle management to rank and file employees - store managers are called at all times of the day, from 5am to midnight,  over vacations (one was even contacted while at her other mother's wake) for regular verbal dress-downs. During the 2011 blizzard, for example, employees were expected to report to work despite the fact it was a State of Emergency in New Jersey. Some employees drove an hour or more through blizzard conditions to sit in an empty store for 5 hours - a complete waste of time, and blatant negligence towards employee safety! Unreasonable expectations are driving good people to underhanded methods while middle management looks the other way. When attention is called to these unethical practices, middle management throws the rank and file under the bus to save their own hides. Experienced personnel from the Wachovia days have largely fled to other institutions by now. Wells is now hiring younger and younger employees with less experience, paying them less, and working them to death before throwing them away like trash. Morale is at an all-time low, but those who stay live in fear of losing their jobs. 

It's an absolute tragedy to see so many good people unhappy. Wachovia was once a premier company, but ever since the takeover by Wells, it's a slowly sinking ship, one that has seen some of the best employees flee, while the rest wait grimly await their fate.

review_title: Great place to start for someone who would want to begin their career in the banking industry.
job_title: Store Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: One of the greatest banks to work for.  One can get promoted easily if he or she is a great seller in the branch.
cons: Times can be difficult when there is no traffic at the store.  Retail Banking Division is highly competitive.  Bankers and managers will be pressured on a daily basis to achieve their daily, monthly, quarterly, and annually sales goals.

review_title: OK place to work, can be frusteratingly beurocratic, and profitability is increasingly at the employee's expense
pros: Well known company, 401K matching is generous, good PTO, there is opportunity for advancement within Retail (but it's near impossible to get our of retail into other parts of the company), $5000/year tuition reimbursement for business classes is great
cons:
The thing that makes me the most upset about the changes that have occurred in the last couple years is that the company is making up for reduced revenues by cutting employee benefits. Case in point: They got rid of good healthcare this year and went with cost sharing plans which shifts the burden to the employee. The old plan had a $100 out of pocket ER copay and the rest was covered. I had that coverage for 3 years and never once needed it. Under the new "cost sharing" plan that went into effect on Jan 1, which by the way I pay exactly the premium for as last year, I now also had to pay $1300 out of pocket for a simple ER visit. Literally every time I go to the doctor I have to pay the copay, and then on top of that I am charged 20% of any tests or procedures the doctor does as well. 

The Retail/Community Banking line of business, which is the largest and most visible part of the company,  is run by a bunch of slave drivers with unrealistic expectations who  have convinced themselves that every time a customer is unhappy about something, 100% of the blame lies with their personal banker or teller, despite the fact that the employees who have direct contact with the customer are powerless to do anything other than regurgitate the beurocratic policy coming down from above. The business model has become much more focused on generating revenue through fees than it used to be, and it is nearly impossible now to help the customer avoid fees. This makes customers upset when they look at their bank account, but management has convinced themselves that "it's not fees that make customers unhappy, it is the service they receive when they come in"

review_title: Good compensation, Horrible Support, Very Stats Focused
pros: They take really good care of their employees as far as pay, medical, 401k, credit discounts. The other phone bankers all don't like their job but that's a call center for you and it creates a fun environment because they do things to make you forget how bad the work actually is. The more you try to promote a fun-balanced workplace the faster you will move up. They are also one of the most innovative companies i have worked for. They spare no expense to make sure you have what you need. They spend an average of $10,000 to train in their reps so you will know more about banks and bank regulations then you ever wanted to, 7 weeks of it to be exact.
cons: Supervisors are very very anal about your performance metrics. If you aren't constantly appearing as if you are trying to improve, they will let you go without warning. The reason i left Wells was because the call center i was located in(Shoreview, MN) constantly had technical problems with their computers, this would make your performance metrics appear a lot lower then they actually are, now this happened twice right before i was to get performance bonuses. I ended up not getting about $3000 in bonuses due to this because according to them, even though they agree the metrics were incorrect, they wont change them and you miss your bonus. Several others i worked with left for this reason and what do you know they have been sued for this many times before. That being said, if you are having trouble finding work and dont mind being watched like a hawk and nagged at every moment and can just put up with that like i did(to a point) this is a good job.

job_title: Sales Associate in New York, NY
pros: Big company, good benefits, respectable/ reputable firm. Good decent peers & co-workers.
cons: Micro management by unqualified folks who claimed their positions on merit with the company  rather than knowledge of the field. Professionals perhaps (not all), but when unqualified people start micro managing, business tends to be counter productive. After being with 1 company for 9 years I joined Wells with my usual positive calm demeanor, less than 12 months later, I resigned. My four co-workers who resigned prior to myself had the right idea. Was a  shame, all of us liked our position,yet  we all left for the very same reason, a completely inept manager. 5 out of a team of 7 young, professional sales reps in the NY/CT market left within 1 year of this woman becoming manager. She took the job because her previous division within Wells was eliminated. They actually hired her because she was with Wells for many years yet had no experience in her knew role. Trickle down effect was eminent. The environment is ruled by fear rather than ambition. To see management yes every level above them was quite pathetic. It's a culture where you need to tell your superior what they need to hear. There is a level of disconnect to reality. Merely puppets that will say anything to maintain their job. I suppose that's why it was it's so much easier for the sales reps to depart. We didn't live in fear, couldn't "drink the cool aid" & as young experienced professionals knew we were employable elsewhere. Management, some being unqualified, had to yes their superiors. They were insecure in realizing they knew less that their reps.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Bradenton, FL
pros: A ++++plus stores...and great hours
cons: EVERYTHING! they preach ethics and taking care of the customer but the truth is they could careless about you the employee or the customers. The benefits use to be good but are now horrible, the corporate environment is even worse. If you want to be a Banker in the state of FL avoid wells fargo like the plague!!!Your bonus is not achievable and the pay sucks for the amount of old people you have to deal with. Upper management is a jumble of rejects with no sense of direction or realistic goals for its employees. They hire any joe blow off the street to handle millions of dollars on a daily basis.

pros: Management is friendly and approachable. Okay pay.
cons: Although the management is friendly and approachable, they don't really coach you on how to improve your performance. Senior Management keeps on hiring people whom they worked in their previous company instead of grooming someone from the inside. No constant communication from my supervisor unless I initiate it. They don't give credit to your achievements and take credit for themselves.

job_title: Teller in West Saint Paul, MN
pros: They have reasonable benefits and pretty typical wages.  They have outlined career paths for employees to follow.  They promote from within.
cons:
Here is one of my Examples.  While I was a customer of Wells Fargo(before employment), I went in to a local branch to apply for a small personal loan.  The "Banker" I worked with was super friendly and asked me all sorts of questions.  I revealed to him that I was going to use some of the money from the loan to invest in a business venture.  That made him super "interested" and he recommended I set up a business account with WF.  He said there would only be a $125 monthly transfer from my checking to savings to keep the account free.

I told him I wouldn't have the money to do the transfer's unless I received the loan.  He looked at the loan application and said that he was 100% sure I would get the loan and I would have the funds within 2 business days.  So we opened the Business accounts.

3 days later I had heard no response about the loan.  So, I called and left a voice mail message asking how everything was going.  No Response.  I called daily, and emailed him daily for 5 days in a row asking what was going on.  No Response.  I ended up calling the 1-800 number for Wells Fargo and speaking with a personal banker who explained to me that the loan had been declined the day after I applied because I wasn't currently employed.

So, I just left it at that, but couldn't believe how rude the original Banker had been not to call me and let me know about the issue.

about a 2 months later I went in to a branch to deposit money in my personal checking account (which I hadn't used in months) and found out I had been receiving fees for the Business account....   



Now, as an employee of Wells Fargo at a small branch location I am learning that helping the customer is not a priority.  It is only a priority to appear interested and concerned with a customer in order to lure them into signing up for products (which they might not need) so that My Branch can make a few extra bucks.

I do not bank with Wells Fargo anymore

If I wasn't required to have

job_title: Operations Manager III in West Des Moines, IA
pros: Awesome PTO (4 weeks to start) allows for tons of time off, company matches 401k contributions $1 for $1 up to 6% and also contributes 2% of salary as profit sharing depending on company financials although this is almost a certainty given $15 billion + per year in profits.  Lots of stability for high peformers as the company doesn't get rid of you if you're valuable.  Lots of upward mobility potential.  Good annual bonus potential (10-20% of salary) once in mid level management roles.  Annua raises are very low (1-2%) since the recession in 2007....but higher performers generally get alittle more.
cons: Honestly....this is the epitome of corporate america.  It's a machine and the bureaucracy and red tape kills your ability to be efficient.  Hundreds of emails dominate your day and picture yourself in cubical warehouses on never ending conference calls if you're in any type of management role.  The government has created so much regulation, audits, and oversight on banks that it makes for absolute craziness as a bank employee trying to get anything done.  Everything you do has to have 800 controls and quality assurance/compliance checks in place that it creates an environment that discourages innovation.  Senior management is so afraid of negative public perception that e in a mere hint of reputational risk in any process makes them freak out when the reality is that all big banks are being sued every day and no one really cares.  Wells Fargo is literally too big for its own good.  It pays well (comparatively speaking for des Moines Iowa)....which kinda traps you into staying....... but its so mind humming that you have to continue trying to move into different positions every 18-24 months to keep from losing your mind.

pros: Benefits are decent and competitive.
cons: Management is very disrespectful to employees, making them stay late if they didn't hit sales numbers. Talk down to managers and employees. Pressure for sales has employees opening other accounts for themselves or multiple accounts for one client, therefore they aren't growing the business at all. Goals are unrealistic, I've been in this business a long time and have never seen anything like it. Leaving after 2 months with company. So many employees are unhappy and stressed out. They were once a great company but have become pushy sales all the time.

pros: Large company, lots of areas to move into if given the opportunity,  strong brand. The wealth of information within the employees due to their combined experience is the best I have ever seen.
cons: Poor future goals planning at the individual level, the people who do all the work get lost in the shuffle, inadequate training, minimal opportunity to get a raise beyond 1%.

review_title: Great company to work for in IT (as a financial service provider)
pros: Lot of talented and friendly people to work with.  One of Fortune's "most admired" companies in the world.  The company provides great benefits and lot of opportunities to grow within the company.
cons: Getting promoted (in terms how soon one wants to get promoted) can sometimes be challenging, however there is a strong culture of promoting within for senior leadership/management positions.  Salary (for IT) is less compared to other technology companies.

review_title: An unethical manager can ruin it for everyone and will likely not be dealt with
job_title: Personal Banker II in Sandy, UT
pros:
- 401K plans match to 6% and occasionally 8% with discretionary profit sharing
- You get to provide helpful financial solutions to customers
- If this is your first real job, there's lots of promotion opportunity within retail
- Other banks respect Wells Fargo sales training

cons:

pros: Good benefits (but not like they once were). Opportunity to work at locations throughout US. Over two years I did not see any attempt by the former Wachovia group I was with to come in line with the WF vision and values. In fact, it was just plain wacky. I and the teammates, with whom I moved to the new group, were continuously baffled by much of the mismanagement we saw from the old Wachovia culture. The old Wachovia management stripped us of responsibilities from our usual workload to the point where we became no more than robots without any hope (or desire) to advance in this group. There was no development, although we were regularly told there would be. Many people left this group. Shame on the management team for not being aligned with Wells Fargo values.

review_title: Wells Fargo - Where Profit Matters More than its Employees
pros: Worked at 2 branches. Great/friendly staff. Have made some great friends. Great work flow; everybody does their part. Smooth operations, systems for teller transactions are generally error free. Depending on who you work with you can learn fast. PTO and health benefits through the bank are great and easy to enroll in. Bonuses are nice when you reach sales goals.
cons: A few months ago I transferred as a teller to a location in SF. I moved to the city and I wanted to be able to work in the city so I wouldn't have to deal with the teeth-grinding commute on the way back (up to 2 hours to cross the Bay Bridge). I was fortunate enough to get a referral from a friend and I was able to get things going pretty quickly. I went in and personally introduce myself to the branch manager and the private banker; 2 really nice guys that seemed thrilled to have a transferring team member. Now this is where things went south. I was called up by the recruiter to discuss when I could start and what my starting salary would be.. For whatever reason she asked me what starting wage I'd prefer. I asked for 16.00 so we could negotiate. She told me '12.50' which from what I understood was the starting wage for a new WF Teller employee. I had been with the company for over 2 years. On top of that she talked back to me like it was some sort of joke that I would be asking for anything more. "Being an employee for 2 years doesn't suffice for a wage higher than $12.50" she tells me. She was condescending and talked to me like what I was asking would have people jumping through hoops. I caved and took the 12.50 starting wage.. because after all I cut my commute in more than half and I can establish a relationship with my new branch in hopes to get a promotion. 6 months down the road and I apply for the PB1 position. My sales this quarter are number 1 compared to others at the teller line. I get a recruiting call from the same indifferent, condescending "recruiter" pretty much telling me that I can't even be considered for a promotion because I didn't comp for Q3 which was the time I transitioned between branches; A BRAND NEW POLICY THEY JUST STARTED GOING BY WHEN THEY SWITCHED DM'S A MONTH PRIOR. She basically said that the one quarter I didn't comp in my entire WF career was the reason they couldn't promote me. At this point I am seeing too many red flags with this company. So in these two instances I have learned that Wells Fargo saved a few thousand dollars on NOT sending a new hire to training and putting me (an employee that has been with the company for over 2 years) on the same wage, and that the policies that are rapidly changing are making it far more difficult to move up in the company.

review_title: The managers don't have a clue
pros: The managers and employees are grossly under trained in the loss mitigation department. We are expected to underwrite files while covering an inbound phone line, with mis-routed calls galore. Then are reprimanded when our work isn't done, yet the phone rings all day long non stop
cons: Yes above is the pros of the job, as that is the reason for job security. The cons are non competitive pay or bonus for the position, people I come to care about get fired for made up compliance violations, and smart people are held down as the incompetent managers have a blood thirst to hold the little power they have

pros:

-Pay is decent, 401K matching (after one year, up to 6%) is great.
cons:
-Sales approach is ridiculous. After speaking with tellers and personal bankers from other banks, it is clear that -Wells Fargo has the highest sales goals and the most stressful environment.
-Quarterly bonuses are determined half on your sales, and half on your "wow." (Any customer you help could be randomly selected for a survey based on their experience, and your customer service, on a scale of 1-5. If an employee receives anything below a 5, the survey is considered a failure and the whole branch's bonus drops.) 
-I'm going to reiterate, this "wow" piece is a serious con. The managers don't want us to tell our customers they could receive a survey, so even if you go above and beyond for a "grouchy" customer and they give you all 4's on a survey, the whole team gets disciplined and micromanaged.

job_title: Personal Banker II in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Lots of room for advancement if you are driven. Insurance is ok (but has been increasing in price, with benefits going down each year).
cons:
The sales pressure is unbelievable, bankers are required to do a financial priorities worksheet, as well as fill out a four screen profile on every single customer, regardless of if you saw them two days ago or not. Then you must recommend a product to the customer, and to make sure you did, you have to have a "mid-session review" with your branch manager (i.e., they check to make sure you are pushing a product on every single customer and will send you back to do so if you haven't). Then there is the customized summary that must be printed in duplicate, initialed by the customer, with their phone number included. These need to be turned in every night. Oh and most include the date and time of your next appointment, every single time. The point is, there is an expectation that ALL customers need a new product, a follow up appointment, and a full financial review (and a sale) with every customer, no matter if they have time, have just done that the week before, or need a product. The sales goals are so unrealistic that bankers end up having ethics issues, or they can't meet their sales goals and lose their job. If you are good at product pushing, many ethical transgressions are overlooked by management, until you have too many that it can't be covered up anymore and HR gets involved. There are ethical bankers to be sure, and successful ones at that, but they are the ones that work tirelessly to hit their goals, harassing friends and family to open accounts. Those individuals are rewarded with an ever dwindling incentive check, and the expectation that the next quarter, they will do even more. June 30th you might be on top of the world, the best of the best, but a few days into July, with the slowness of traffic due to vacations and the holiday, you are subjected to "coaching" regarding your sales performance. There is little to no reason to excel in your position, as you simply become a target for ethics violations reports from disgruntled co-workers, or are held to standards far above what is considered the minimum goal. Branch managers are not immune to this sort of pressure either,---the increased sales goals and sales pressure appear to come from the district and market levels. 
Overall, it's just a frustrating company to work for. There is no real sense of "a good days work done", because you really have no control over your own success. The constant sales pressure is stressful, and too often people leave work feeling utterly worthless. I've witness far too many conversations with the banker in tears, and have watched good people, hard workers, leave.

review_title: Not bad, but not the best
pros:
Most folks at WF have been there for life, and I think that's telling for how great it once was. I don't think that it's horrible, but they're definitely in a tough place and that makes it challenging to be the best employer they could possibly be. 

But being there for life also means there's a lot of collaboration because there's a sense of family. Lots of friendly people who truly care about each other and their customers, and ached when we learned about the sales practice issue.

There's also a lot of room to move around WF. We have a great learning & development department that you can register yourself or have your managers nominate you for, and the classes are very beneficial for developing leadership among other tactical business need-to-knows.

A lot of groups are also going through "Workplace 2020" where we're transitioning from cubes to more open floor plans. Half of the group likes it, the other half keep fighting it off, so this can be a pro or con depending on your preference and job.
cons:
It's crisis mode. Lots of focus on compliance or putting out fires, that you might not immediately get to engage in the "fun" part of your job, or at least, not as much as we used to pre-crisis. 

The pay and benefits are also adequate. I don't know how that'll look if we keep going down this downward spiral, but you can expect only a 2% merit increase every year. You generally have to move around to get that pay raise you want and deserve.

Reorg after reorg. I know it's necessary, but it's getting tiring too.

Internal communications sucks. We oftentimes have to read the news to really understand what's happening in or to the company. 

Not a lot of consistency. Some departments/floors have snacks, some don't. Some have ping pong tables, some have billiards, and some have nothing but cubes upon cubes.

cons: Corporate changes are taking place and many with just have to adjust from a system and income earning they have become accustomed to!

review_title: Company's ethics will test your personal moral meter
pros: As far as jobs go, it's not very stressful. Bankers hours. In at 9, out at 5.
cons: Management says one thing, news headlines say another. The culture and ethics aren't as squeaky clean as they'd have you believe. With $4 billion in cuts on the horizon, work morale will remain at an all-time low. Work hard to show your worth, get severed because of "business decisions." There's no incentive to excel (and when you do, raises and bonuses are in the 1-3% range, and there is no "cost-of-living" adjustments).

pros: Decent benefits and office location is ok and ??  Most people are well educated and professional but not all; egos get in the way in management related circumstances.
cons: Too many Chiefs and NOT enough Indians.  Workload is uneven and training is lacking expect for banking regulations that don't apply to your position.  Wells Fargo talks the talk but does not walk the walk - fake management staff.

pros:
You can get hired fairly easily since not that many people want to work for them right now.  My hope is that a promotion to a higher pay grade will be easier for me here than elsewhere.  Decent PTO as well.  I work with a pretty good group of people. 

The job itself is pretty easy/straightforward, if monotonous.  Some of the people I get to meet are interesting.
cons:
There is no option to get bonuses or incentives for anything, so your base pay is basically all you will get to take home.  If you catch a fraudulent check you can get $20 sometimes after tax but it takes months to hear back, if at all.  There are supposed to be customer service bonuses as well and we all work really hard to get good secret shopper ratings, but it depends on 2-10 random people who come in every week and say whatever they feel like and you need to average 95% for the whole quarter to see any money.  A lot of the time what ruins our score is someone getting denied for a credit card or something, which we have no control over.  

At my branch also scheduling can be really inconsistent and we rarely get 2 consecutive days off, which I know can be hard to get anywhere but it does wear on you.   Also while the PTO is good, the way that they make you schedule it means you can't take that time off the way you want to.  Generally all their scheduling stuff is a bit of a disaster- they have this system that we have to go by that takes averages of how busy we have been in past years on that date and calls for particular staffing based on that, and it is almost always wrong.  So we are more or less scheduled for several months in advance but don't see the schedule ourselves until the Friday or Saturday before the next week.  

Full time is considered 30hr/week, which is good because it gets you full time benefits but it's very hard to get up to 40hr as a teller if that's what you want/need.

Also there's supposed to be a lot of career development coaching and stuff like that which I just haven't really encountered, even though that was a pretty big draw for me.

Since WF just got a big tax break entry level wages are supposed to be going up too, but there's a lot of vagueness about how much and when.  

The hardest part of the job is having to be "on" and smiling and making a lot of extra effort for customer service while also not having consistent time off, having few good options as to how to take paid time off, and having the only bonus opportunity depend on random people's response to a 5 question survey.  

I know it seems like I have a lot of issues with this job but I guess where I am with it is kind of frustrated and disappointed.  A lot of the things I just mentioned as cons were the things I specifically was looking for.

review_title: Not a very good place to work
pros: Great place to work for local folks. People are working here for  more than 6-7years and are happy. Can be a good place if you get a good manager!
cons:
It is a great place to work for people of the same region.
If you are an outsider, people will treat you like an outsider. 1.Language-
They will talk in their own regional language, be it any kind of professional environment. Be it a meeting, or a discussion, at times they completely ignore that there are other people who do not understand a single word of their language, but they will continue to talk in the same language, unless asked several times.
2.Management-
The hierarchy of this company in india is such that nearly 90% of the mid-senior management is from the same region and they do not prefer or promote the “outsiders”. The management is so conservative or i should say threatened that they will make you struggle for the smallest of the things, whereas their preferred peoples will avail all the privileges of being in this company.
3.Transparency-
There is no transparency amongst the team members. Nobody will tell you anything unless asked. Even after asking only some special people will get the answers and they will thus inform you, if requires.
4.Confidentiality- 
If you think your manager will be preserving the sensitive information, you are wrong. Many times you will see resumes lying on the desks of managers, who dont even bother to keep them safe. People refer those resumes to update their own,sometimes keep them without even informing the manager. Manager is least bothered, he even checks the KRA/ star trek with people peeping into his system. Promotion/ratings etc are so important and confidential but people do it openly here.
5.Female-
Not sure about Abroad, but here in India, people really dont treat women as equal. There is no involvement in any kind of decision making. Typical male dominated company. I would never recommend a women to work in such an environment.
6.Diversity-
Here they think diversity means Girls/Guys ratio. But thats not welcome here. I mean when people are actually hired and start working, they wont be considered as equal.

pros: If you are fortunate enough to ingratiate yourself with someone in management with influence and pull, you might do quite well here.
cons: Extremely toxic atmosphere rife with workplace bullying, racial and sexual harassment, and mean-girl attacks. If you are African American and speak of racism or racist policy, or racist optics, you will be gaslighted and eventually pushed out. HR works for the company and not employees

review_title: Poor leadership, Allowing a negative work environment makes it hard to develop a teamwork culture.
pros: Select staff make it pleasant, handful of employees make it  pleasant and  enjoyable to come to work. To much gossip and talking behind others back.
cons: Leadership doesn’t follow through with creating a healthy work environment. Even when they have first hand witness of poor behaviors. Leaves others feeling discomfort.

review_title: An overall decent place to work but call centers are not for me!
job_title: Online Customer Service Representative in Birmingham, AL
pros:
Great benefits, especially dental
18 days PTO
Holiday pay
Quarterly incentives
Multiple pay increases, although very small
Achievements are noticed and rewarded
cons:
The constant abuse from customers and the repetitive job itself is what drove me away from this place. Many people are able to tolerate it, but I simply can’t. I did not feel like I was growing working there. I did not feel that I was gaining any valuable experience other than customer service experience. At the end of the day, I always felt like nothing but a “customer service representative”. Constantly being belittled, cursed at, and abused by customers while trying to maintain your composure will eventually take its toll on you emotionally. It’s just not worth it. I began to dread going to work.

There isn’t a lot of support from supervisors, team leads, and CSR 3s. Before they introduced the Skype feature, I remember having my flag up for more than 5 minutes waiting for help only to be ignored, and had to then fend for myself. The Skype feature is a great add-on, but it’s always backed up that at times I’ve waited 10 minutes for help, which resulted in the customer hanging up because they were on hold too long. There needs to be more support!

The call center I was located at in Birmingham is unprofessional. Coworkers gossiping about other coworkers; coworkers showing up to work dressed inappropriately; and the lack of diversity. 

They’ve gotten rid of sales practices but there are still metrics that we have to meet and at times they are just simply unattainable. Too much pressure placed on handle time and Southern 7. If I get a 5/5 on a call, who cares if I did the Southern 7. That customer was satisfied!

Worked at Wells Fargo for almost 2 years and never got a weekend off, except when using my PTO; at least one weekend a month is acceptable.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Rock Hill, SC
pros: If you have a decent manager that has your back, the job can be rather enjoyable, with lots of opportunity for taking on more responsibility. Due to 2016 scandal, WF is less sales focused as it used to be from a policy standpoint.
cons: If you have a bad manager, or if your manager’s manager is terrible, it can negatively impact your ability to move up. In that situation, the only thing to do to keep getting promoted is to move laterally to another location or leave WF for another bank. Very much a retail oriented job.

pros: Lots of nice people working there as a McJob explaining 2 stars versus the earned 1 star.
cons: Low pay, unorganized, too many managers who send/forward a million of the same emails to appear productive. Horrible mortgage support system. Reputation deservedly awful.  Training non-existent teaching material which doesn't apply to role. Backstabbing very common - money wasted on extravagant leases and parties instead of generating income.  Too many cons to put down, rather spend my time writing a novel.

pros: Great benefits, telecommuting is an accepted part of the work culture, easy work for a high salary, opportunities to move internally (though not necessarily upward), average workers are usually friendly and willing to impart knowledge, community support, valued volunteering/charitable work, nice mailman, D&I initiatives, adherence to scheduled meetings
cons:
Insane levels of self-aggrandizement. Ill defined culture - the old guard is slow to adapt and employees' morale is hit every other week with a new scandal in the news.  No trust in the senior leaders who are left over from the old era. A lot of talk, but no visible action. Superficial transparency with "feel-good" messaging. A lot of self-congratulatory behavior for ... minimal work.

Worst office politics I've ever seen; favoritism, a lot of mean-spirited gossip, and professional backstabbing to climb the corporate ladder. So many instances of nepotism. Constant re-orgs all over. Consultative recommendations are ignored by those who think they know better (so a lot of going around others to get what they think should be done, done).

Not a challenging job at all, especially for the incredible pay.  People spend more time saying they're busy than actually being busy. Felt like I professionally stagnated even though I took a higher-level position in accepting a job at WF. Super specialized jobs, resulting in the aforementioned lack of challenges. A lot of people seem OK with the culture of complacency, as it's a great way to accrue retirement savings with little to no work. Not everyone is complacent - there are plenty of awesome, nice, motivated team members, too.

Several layers of management, which means it takes several weeks/months to get anything done. Very silo'ed org structure, with a lack of consistency in procedures and processes even within divisions.

Poor public perception of the company - it's all anyone wants to talk about when they find out you work there ... or they just give you a lot of side eye. Made it difficult to take pride in the work I was doing or to feel that I was advancing a socially responsible mission.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Orlando, FL
pros: Pay, lots of learning and growth potential, very professional setting.
cons: Weird PTO rules . If you have a certain day off one year you can’t have that day of next year. Can’t have more than a week off unless you can prove your going out of the country even if you have multiple weeks of PTO available and the PTO hasn’t already been taken. Cannot have a day off that also has a holiday falling in that week. When requesting a single day of PTO it cannot be a Monday or Friday or Saturday.

review_title: Great learning experience for fraud detection, but THIS IS a call center - be warned!
job_title: Financial Crimes Specialist in Charlotte, NC
pros: Clean, calm, and well-appointed offices, break areas, parking, etc., excellent learning opportunities for skills development in fraud detection and customer service, job security (provided metrics required are maintained).
cons:
Call center (can be a negative for some),  PTO is honored, but not always available (they decide when you can use it, and cite "business needs" for refusing to grant certain days off); lack of formal training (several tests and quizzes in training were expected to be completed and passed in one hour with no time to read materials; we were told to "keep retaking until you pass;" found this highly disturbing that this was a required activity before allowing new hires to man the phone lines and take actual customer calls! Possible compliance issue with training of new employees.)

Unreasonable schedules - on certain hours and days available - as of my time of employment there, one could not work Monday through Friday - one weekend day MUST be worked into your schedule. Furthermore, these schedules were not even open for rotation, or even an employee-suggested "two weekends per month" idea where one could have at least one to two weekends off per month.  Employees were told to go as far as asking for weekends off 6 months in advance, as everyone was vying for weekend time off here and there, and availability disappeared very quickly - tough luck for people who can't make definite vacation plans 6 months in advance.

VERIFY in writing with HR, before taking this position, if you have requested time off in advance, that you have planned before taking the job offer. I've seen HR "lose" time off requests made pre-employment by new associates, telling them that if they take the time off, they will be written up for doing so.

As with any job, competition between employees can be healthy and increase productivity, but with the metrics required in this position, you often see employees attempting to sabotage or "tattle" on coworkers to "eliminate" the competition. Same goes for advancing in positions here to team lead, team supervisor, out of the department, etc..

Be aware, regardless of what HR may say in regards to confidentiality, if you have a problem with a manager or supervisor, they can and WILL tell the manager or supervisor the confidential information, often resulting in in-office confrontations of employees who call to make confidential complaints and grievances.

And finally, as with all call centers, verbal abuse and threats to you will happen over the phone by angry, disturbed, unwell, and unstable customers and callers. There is still disagreement (with no solid answer) as to what defines verbal abuse and which threats are considered "real" threats in order for you to disconnect a call without being penalized by Quality Control. Know that before you decide to do this 5 days of every week of your life!

review_title: USED TO BE A GREAT COMPANY TO WORK FOR
pros: Health insurance benefits were great, this is a great starting job if you are a college student and if banking is new to you.  They have an excellent training program for bankers and tellers.  There system for processing transactions, payments, is far advanced compare to most banks and credit unions.  My managers on the teller side were great.
cons: The branch manager changed every 2-3 years, high employee turn over rate, the sales expectation went up when I first started working there just to hit minimum in quarter back in 2006 was 40 then over the years they changed it to 180.!!!When it comes to sales they are very aggressive.    I worked my heart and soul into this company and stayed stuck at the same position for 8 and half year.  They don't give opportunity to employees that have been there for a long time it is always given to the tellers that are there for less than a year.  After constantly being surpassed for a job promotion I felt that there was no opportunity for me and all of my years of working hard were time wasted.  After I left so did half of the branch either they were terminated or done because the branch manager changed.  The lawsuits don't surprise me especially with how aggressive they were with sales it is common ethical sense to make better decisions but this company will terminate people if they don't make their sales goals.  They say they are pulling away from sales but I know there is still a branch goal that they are expected to meet.  I won't mention names but people have promoted here opening accounts with out the customers permission or informing them to close an account and open another one and they are still with Wells Fargo getting promoted I think the CEO's of this company and the managers that promote them need  a course on ETHICS!!!

job_title: Senior Private Client Associate in Pasadena, CA
pros:
The company itself was fine--The Private Bank division is another story.  
So many different things to do that every day goes by quite fast and it is not boring. You build great relationships with clients as you get to know them very well.  Great resources to assist clients.  Nice celebratory events and short work days before a holiday.
cons: The manager makes a difference!!  They make or break the office environment and culture.  Associates are treated as second class citizens compared to "producers" meaning bankers.  Definitely an elitist mentality compared to the rest of the company.

review_title: Great Benefits but Don't value loyal employees
pros:
-Good Benefits- 401k and matching 6%, Health- all type of plans from low to high deductible, HSA- employer contribution of $800 if you do health activities, 16 hours of volunteer hours,  tuition reimbursement, generous PTO time plus 3 days floating holiday
-Lots of opportunity for internal promotions and they love to hire within
-Located everywhere, generally flexible on locations near home
-Direct managers are accomodating and supportive
-TOP dollars awards for department
cons:
-Pay for internal employees. They do not value loyalty. A person working in the role for 10+ years will never see any more pay then their annual "cost of living" pay which is below the market, they give you 2% yearly. If you get another internal job offer they can't raise your pay more than a certain % (normally no more than 10%), whereas if you were an external candidate, you can come in with the mid pay and surpass the loyal employee who has been doing it for more than a new person joining. 
-They advertise the mid pay on all their openings yet do not pay anywhere close to that amount. Because everything is considered a "lateral" move to upper management when it's not. Like coming from a regular staff to becoming a manager of a dept is considered lateral so they don't have to pay you the mid or anything more. They need to reasses what lateral means. 
-Poor senior management communication
-Too many levels of management to get an approval
-Too compartmentalize, there's a person for every single thing, so you get a lot of, "we don't do that" and then transfer to another department and then the same thing happen. Home Office does not take any accountability.
-Lazy and incompetent home office staff located in St. Louis.
-Uses offshore India and Phillipines, language barrier and makes a lot of mistakes, and don't understand some things. 
-Complaints or suggestion system for "excellence first" goes no where.

review_title: Wells Fargo, what a great place to work.
job_title: Store Manager in College Station, TX
pros: This is a company that encourages team members to learn as much as possible and there is constant conversation around my career path. As a manager it is a feather in my cap to have one of my employees promoted. I really would encourage anyone with a drive to apply and start their career or second career with Wells Fargo, if you work hard, the sky's the limit. The benifits package is as good as I have seen in the market and that includes four weeks of personal time a year. As well as the prestige of working for a Fourtune 50 company. So that is why I would recomend Wells Fargo Bank to everyone.
cons: This is a hard one for me, because I really don't have a lot to say that is negative as far as Wells Fargo goes. I guess the first thing that I would say is that there are managers that become so obsessed with sales that they run off good people and they can even put so much pressure on the employees that they resort to unethical behaviors, which IS NOT what Wells Fargo is all about. Sometimes upper management overlook a questionable  behavior in exchange for a sale. There is a lot of pressure to make sales numbers so there is a lot of stress on an individual. I guess that is what I would say the downside is to working for Wells Fargo.

review_title: Wells Fargo, great for a new career, endless opportunities, fabulous benefits and lots of fun
pros:
It’s easy to find out why so many people like to work for Wells Fargo. In the banking industry, there are many competitors offering the same products with slight variations in them. It truly does take the people to make it different. The Wells Fargo vision is second to none, and although it seems like it doesn’t always trickle down to everyone working on the sales floor, the ideas being implemented from up above are based on great values and good behavior. 

For starters, Wells Fargo is an ideal place to begin a new career. As a student coming out of high school or college, there’s almost something for everyone at Wells Fargo. You’re sure to find something that fits your strengths in a company that has over 80 sub-divisions in it. 

It’s a good manager’s duty to recognize your strengths and your talent and help you choose the right career path. Whether its private banking, investments or insurance, it’s real easy to find an opportunity and move within the company.

In the Twin Cities area, there are many “poacher banks” that steal away Wells Fargo employees that come out of training or have a bit of experience. It’s simply because Wells Fargo’s training program is truly exceptional. The automated systems, the wide variety and the size of the program itself are pretty amazing.

Because a majority of your day is spent at work, having friendly people that care to work with is important. Fortunately, I’ve witnessed many friendships made through the Wells Fargo environment. 

Finally, the health benefits, and retirement plans are also top notch. Wells Fargo does have excellent health, vision and dental programs available for full time and part time employees, something that you don’t see to often with even some of the other larger companies. Dont forget about the 20 days of Paid vacation you start with as a new employee or even 25 days that you can qualify for in the management level. Tuition reimbursement is available for full and part time employees as well! There are a lot more great reasons why you should start with Wells Fargo, but to get more information I'd stop in your local bank and talk to a manager about it.
cons:
One of the downsides of working with Wells Fargo, like any other company is that if your manager lacks the talent and capability of helping his employees develop, you can become complacent and even bored with your job. A good manager keeps his employees challenged, and unfortunately I've witnessed some managers not being able to do that. 
Although a lot of benefits are offered for team members in regards to retirement accounts, health benefits and etc, I wish there was a larger discount on home loans, auto loans and some of the other products available through the bank.
Depending on which part of the company you end up working for, on the banking side at least I know that with all the different systems, programs and various software in place, things can definitely get confusing. Having a go to mentor is always helpful.
The environment can also get a little too sales oriented as well. Team members forget they have to take care of the customer and start concentrating on hitting their numbers and projections.
Although most incentives and bonuses are achievable and realistic, I do believe there is some room for improvement when it comes to dollar amounts.

review_title: Fantastic Perks, Boring Work, A Few Fun People, Safe Place To Be A Lifer
job_title: Applications Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Perks, 5 week vacations (25 work days, includes some holidays), financial compensation.  I enjoyed my stay at Wells Fargo, which was all of 4 years.  I enjoyed working with my teammates and it was fun at first, but then it dragged on.
cons: Politics, boring work, older employees aren't too exciting... ;)  Our VP was not very competent although he had other VPs to compensate for his weaknesses.

review_title: Even a laid off individual thinks the company is doing a good job.
pros: Management tells you what they need from you and then leaves you alone to accomplish the task. They do not micro manage.
cons: Was laid off because the company merged with Wachovia Securities and they needed to cut expenses and people. Even though I am laid off the company itself is a good company.

pros: Great benefits. If your lucky enough to work with great people you will be happy then they will change management on you!
cons: Very high pressure sales environment, most management is under qualified seems you will get promoted to anything you want if you know the right people at the top. Does not always fire those who are unethical just moves them on to another branch.  Feels like the sales are benefiting the company and not the customer.

review_title: Objective promotions.  Great career growth potential.
pros: Wells is a great company.  I have been challenged and been able to grow and improve greatly in my personal sales during the past 3.5 years I've worked here.  I've gained fantastic training and management experiences I wouldn't trade for anything.  I've been rewarded with good monthly commission.  This is a job that you have to earn.  It's sales and I think some of the credit managers forget that sometimes.  A lot of new hires feel entitled when they haven't yet proven themselves.  They don't last long.  No job that doesn't make you work for it is worth doing.  This is not a company for babies.  This is a company and a job where when the going gets tough, the tough get going.
cons: Sometimes managers don't do as well as they should in managing expectations.  Some credit managers come on thinking that earning VCP (commissions) will be a snap.  No, you have to work for it.  I don't have a problem with that fact, just that some new hires feel a little lead on.  I tell people that if you've never done cold call telemarketing before that this job will feel like it.  I have done cold-call telemarketing before and to me this job feels nothing like it.  However if you treat this job as though you are a cold-call telemarketer you can do very well.  The moving package is okay although not as good as it used to be.  I don't like that our pension plans disappeared last year...not sure how that's going to figure into my eventual retirement plans.  For 2009 there were several very heavily weighted portions of all us managers' reviews that had to do with company performance and not individual or branch performance.  These measures actually made it mathmatically impossible to reach the highest rating, even if one scored perfectly in every single area that they could affect directly.  That would definately be a disconnect between upper management and sales managers.  It was quite a demotivator.

review_title: No advancement within my position, though great company
pros: Great company, great support, great people, awesome benefits... I would highly reccomend it to someone who already had their career in motion.
cons: I had a hard time getting direction from my supervisor. She was very nice and always willing to talk, but she would never tell me what she wanted and then would get mad when I produced something that didn't fit into the guidelines that she didn't give me. Go figure.

job_title: Systems Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good benefits.   30 days PTO for me now, pay is above average, stability.  Lots of internal lateral moves.
cons:
Post-Wachovia merger is proving to be more reminiscant of 'Office Clerk'.  Lot more arrogance in the trickle down management edicts.    Encountering a lot more plain down & out RUDE folks from Charlotte.   So much for the southern hospitality NC folks are supposed to be known for.
Adopting the wachovia model for certain practices -  
Communication seems to be a dying asset also.

review_title: Collections: more pressure to get the money than help and educate customers.
job_title: Overdraft Collections Representative in Beaverton, OR
pros:
-Good pay
-Nice benefits
-Paid time off
-Nice people
-Supervisors cared about your progress
-Always able to take more training
cons:
-High pressure to make numbers
-Verbally abusive customers
-Very high stress phone calls
-Customers aren't educated on how their accounts work so they take it out on you.
-You're taught to just transfer the call to another department if the problem isn't strictly about collections.

review_title: Areas within Operations are run like sweet shops others allow you some possibility for growth
pros: Large Company with decent benefit package
cons: Not many possibilities of expanding in your career, many areas are very departmentalized and don't allow you to cross-train and expand your knowledge in other fields.

review_title: Great way to learn the basics of the industry
pros: They offer very good benefit package.  Good career starter jobs.  Quality training. Opportunity to transfer and sell a variety of products and services.
cons: Out of date solutions.  Quotas on leasing equipment when the trend is away from countertop equipment.  Merchants get huge price increases six months after accounts are signed.  Cumbersome boarding process.

review_title: my experience working with at wells fargo has been great so far
pros: team members are helpful,polite and has a very relaxing work environment when there is no work and the benefits are not bad either
cons: if you are an interim worker,you can be laid off at anytime with up to sixty days notice,even there is no work to be done ,you have to go to work till the end of the sixty day notice;which is frustrating

review_title: A great place to work with the right attitude and managers.
pros: It is a great place to start a career. There are so many opportunities for somebody that really knows sales and customer service if you want to work your way up from Teller or even an entry level management position. This is not hard to achieve with the right attitude and determination to succeed. The work itself is easy, 90% of your customers are either regulars or in a good mood in general. The hours are great, time files by, benefits are great but somewhat expensive. Generous PTO, all major holidays off. BONUSES.
cons:
It is clear to me after hearing horror stories from others about their branch, that your outlook on the job will have a lot to do with your managers, sales/CS skills, your general attitude, and location. The managers at my branch are amazing. They mean business, but treat you like a human being and with respect they laugh and joke have fun but are serious about their job. I don't have a manager creepin' over my shoulder all day. But they do give us a lot of feedback on our performance EVERYDAY. If you can learn to see their feedback as coaching in order to make you more successful, their constant coaching will not bother you. I worked in call centers so this type of feedback and performance improvement approach is not unfamiliar to me. 
     They set sales goals pretty high, but are not COMPLETELY unattainable. In sales, you don't always have a good day, they know that, you know that, so don't let high sales goals bother you, just do your best and keep trying. If your managers are "micromanagers" I am sorry, but I don't have them. 
     They tend to promote people with sales skills and don't really look at their leadership abilities as much. This is because people with high sales make the managers look good and in turn basically reflect your overall performance. Managers that make promotional decisions will naturally choose to promote those who produce and make them look good. High sales is how you get recognized by not only your direct managers, but with upper managers you hardly see. Unfortunately, this may put people into management that lack leadership ability and don’t know how to handle pressure from the Big Shots. They are unable to turn it into feedback that a line employee can embrace, benefit, and develop from. This is not the fault of Wells Fargo as a whole, but a reflection of your managers’ leadership capability. 
     What I can say is they do not provide much SALES SPECIFIC training. They talk about how to offer products, but then say that you don't need to know too much about the products, just enough to get them over to a banker. Which is cool, but there are still some necessary things about sales that are required to be successful as a teller that they don't teach. 
     Your customers will always say "I don't have time"… well you need to convince them that they do have the time and that their time spent is worth it. Unfortunately, this company does not do very well in teaching you how to do that. I've had to use my previous sales experience in order to be successful at this. Typically, the tellers at my branch ask questions like-- “Has anybody told you about this?” “Why don’t you have an account?” “Why don’t you want to start an account?” “This will really benefit you cuz it’s awesome”-- while these are great attempts at offering products, they are in no way successful. 
     Oh, and you have to stand on your feet ALL DAY and be really careful with your money handling. If you don’t have experience in handling money, be prepared. Just take your time and be thorough. Training  in general is lacking compared to the results they want out of tellers. They’d rather constantly coach then fully prepare the person before they hit the floor. To me it’s ineffective.

review_title: Overall, a fair place to work part time while attending college.
pros: This part time job offered decent pay, flexible hours, good support from management, reasonable bonus and incentive structure, excellent benefits, time off, etc.
cons: Lots of sales pressure, sales quotas, constant micromanaging, rude/harassing customers, nepotism, other favoratism and other things that were not proper workplace subjects.  Little room to advance at the retail store level.  Had to get too many things approved.

review_title: Wells Fargo Home Mortgage - Default Reporting (An Amazing Operation)
job_title: Business Systems Consultant IV in West Des Moines, IA
pros: Having witnessed the processes and cultures at many different  Mortgage Servicing Companies  (Chase, Citi, Bank of America, etc), Wells Fargo stands far above each in terms of culture, automation, customer focus, and proactive resolution of issues.    Default servicing (resolving discrepancies of loans that are late, in foreclosure or bankruptcy) has many inherent challenges.  Those challenges are magnified with dependencies on outside entities such as Freddie Mac, Fannie Mae, Ginnie Mae, Private Investors, and Attorney Firms.  Given the universe of potential issues and points of failure, I’ve been impressed by the processes, controls and genuine desire of the servicing team to ensure the accuracy of all the mortgage details.  I see a great deal of team recognition, compensation, and advancement (promotions) within default reporting.
cons: I am only familiar with the internal effort to ensure the accuracy of Mortgage details.    I do have much exposure to the loan analysts and specialists on the "Front Line" who have direct contact with customers.  There does seem to be a minor catch-22 for employees who remain within the same position for more than 5 years.   If he or she takes a new internal position, there seems to be a company policy that limits the cap the maximum salary increase for the new position at 12% the salary of the old position.    For many incremental promotions, this isn't an issue.   For those rare circumstances where an employee jumps both "job families" and "levels", this can result in a rather large disparity.  Good managers have mechanisms to offer mid-year adjustments to accelerate compensation in cases like this, but the oversight and scrutiny on the business justification is rather burdensome.   Some employees who have been with Wells Fargo for many years may find it easier to leave for 6mo and return, if they like the company and want to dramatically adjust their income toward the mid-point for their job families.
