review_title: Wells Fargo Financial:Great place to start a career, but not to finish it.
pros: Wells Fargo Financial is a great place to learn how to sell. New employees with zero sales experience get great sales training that transcends to other industries.  Management does encourage growth, and when you do well they make sure everyone knows about your success. If you move, there is usually a local Wells Fargo Financial branch to where you are going. Some of the best benefits in the industries. This is primarily a mortgage company, so to get a competetive base salary plus commision potential allows for less stress than other mortgage sales jobs which are usually 100% commission.  Also, if you are not happy at Wells Fargo Financial you can always look to transfer within the Wells Fargo & Company families to find a better fit.
cons: As a sub-prime consumer lender, sometimes you can feel bad about what you are doing. We help a lot of our customers, but at the same time some of the loans we do really aren't good loans and will eventually hurt us and our customer. Also, management sometimes wants us to do what's best for the company as opposed to what is best for the customer. This seems counter to the company's goal of "making good loans that improve our customers' financial situations." Also, there is a lot of pressure to hit goals, and that pressure sometimes leads to some employees in the company doing unethical things to get business booked.  Also, our personal sales goals are usually unrealistic and are given to us too late to make an impact on how we plan to reach them.  No cost of living raises, and performance based raises are very difficult to acheive.

job_title: Operational Risk Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Wells Fargo has great benefits and my managers have always been very flexible when I needed to work odd hours, etc.  Immediate managers seem to care about their people and helping them.  Wells Fargo has something like 80 different lines of business, which means there are plenty of places to go if you decide you want a change but don't want to leave the bank.  A lot of employees have been here for many years, and it's easy to grow a network of contacts over time if you stick around long enough.  There are a lot of training opportunities available, if you can get your management to pay for it.
cons: Most senior management is often out of touch with what is really going on.  There seems to be no logic behind promotions and titles.  Someone who has worked here for less than a year can be given an AVP title, while someone who is a recognized contributor and has worked here for 5 years is not nominated.  It's often very easy for a slacker to hide among real contributors, and benefit from the group's achievements.  There are a lot of redundencies in work efforts.  A project is kicked off, work is done, and then the project is canceled for some reason.  A year later, we kick off again and have to re-do everything.  The "sales culture" leads to people who make a lot of money for the bank getting the most recognition, while the people behind the scenes who made it happen operationally are overlooked.

review_title: Be prepared for a hard sales environment
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Pleasanton, CA
pros:
Looks good on a resume 
Lots of bonus potential
Big company has a lot of advancement potential
Lots of jobs to be promoted to if you can perform
cons: Sales is purely number driven there is very little attention paid to sales quality.  Be prepared to be stressed out by the sales environment.  Products are arbitrary and provide little value to customers.

review_title: Sure, you can advance quickly...but you have to be our favorite OR you have to flirt your way to the top
pros:
-My service managers are amazing, caring people
-My co-workers are hilarious
-Decent pay
-Wonderful benefits package
cons: -The sales culture conflicts with the service culture being pushed by the company

pros: Great benefits even for tellers. Bonuses paid based on how much you contribute. In my branch there are great people - so much so that we often hang out after work just because we all get along. Many customers are fun to see, and there are some perks associated with having small business owners/managers as customers (free food, mostly).
cons: Obnoxious policies regarding how to greet customers (Say 'Welcome To Wells Fargo! My name is ___. How can I help you today). Saying the same thing gets old after a while. Very stressful at times balancing high sales pressure with "moving the line" when we get busy. Meaningless coaching by the managers regarding sales and customer service ("What product are you going to work on this week? How are you going to change your approach so that you sell a credit card next time?). They have recently started incorporating teller surveys (something brought over from Wachovia) rating you on your interaction with a customer. It's a good idea in theory, allowing you to know how you could improve your customer relationship skills, but in practice it turns in to something that just has to be done. It feels like the managers are just going through the motions, and must find something to cite you on, so they can provide coaching and do their job. It doesn't feel like it's improving my sales or customer service - both of which I am doing well in.

review_title: A good place to work but a little close-minded
job_title: Investment Banking Vice President in Charlotte, NC
pros:
Emphasis on work / life balance for everyone - they expect you to turn off your blackberry on PTO
Flexibility in determining work locations
Teamwork is more than a buzzword here
cons: Insular culture that seems to believe the Wells Fargo way is "perfect" and cannot be improved; it doesn't feel very open to new ideas.

pros: The benefit package is solid. The people you work with are fun to be around. Solid collections experience, WF auto collectors know the business of getting a payment from habitual late payers.
cons: Managers are the real supervisors.  Assigned sups are glorified Collectors with titles.  None of the supervisor receive professional training outside of the department, very few had college degrees beyond Associate status.

pros: Relatively mindless job to do.  You are given a script for everything that you do, and all you have to do is repeat what you are given.
cons:
You are given a script for everything that you do at Wells Fargo.  When it comes to taking calls, scripted.  When you ask for assistance, scripted.  When anything needs to be done, scripted.  Everything that you do at Wells Fargo is scripted.  They are running a robot factory over here.  They do not want us to be human, but machines.
The goals that the company expects of its employess is ludacris.  They expect you to do a sale for like every third person that you talk to, which is absurd.  There are more accounts being closed on a day to day basis because these accounts that are being opened are trash.  We are lying to clients to get sales, and it isn't fair to them.  We tell them to open an account for having an overdrawn account.  What kind of logical sense does that make.  We tell them to apply for a credit card because they can't keep money in there bank account.  Once again, what kind of logical sense does this make.  If they cannot keep money in one account, why open another.  Why offer them a credit card, oh wait, so they can max it out and then we can take them to collections and gather the money plus iunterest plus fees from them that way.  it just isn't fair to our clients.
I know when I go someplace or call a business, I ask for assistance with a problem and that is it.  When people try to start cross-selling it gets a little annoying.  I might call in for some help on my phone.  They will assist me, resolve my problem, and that should be it.  A lot of times I am asked, well told, about products that Ic ould honestly care less about.  If I really wanted to learn about products that I wanted to buy, I would have called a salesman.
Wells Fargo needs to keep there focus on customer service and not on customer annoyance.

job_title: Business Banking Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great benefits, great senior leadership (CEO, CFO,etc.).
cons: Retail banking at Wells Fargo is a true grind.  All they care about are numbers and sales.  Managers will look the other way when people are doing unethical things to get sales as long as they don't get caught.  No interest in developing good, long term employees.  Extremely hard to get out of retail and they don't teach any transferrable skills unless you want to be a used car salesman.  I think if the executive level management knew what was going on in retail they would throw up in their mouths.

pros: 401k matching is a little big higher than other companies I know of.
cons:
I was shock that Wells Fargo does not follow the Federal Holiday paid time off. We work on President and Columbus day. 
Extensive training, but not very useful.
Company is very unorganized; for example just the other day, I called customer service and was transferred at least 6 times only at the end, the operator said there is no assistant at the time and disconnected the line.
Very high turnover rate; not enough staff which leads to very irate customers.
No raise.
It's all about meeting sales goals.

review_title: Liked when it was Wachovia better
job_title: Personal Banker in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Good corporate structure, very generous vacation time from the start, fair pay scale, secure job
cons: Upper management doesn't understand what can or cannot be done at a branch level in order to make goals. Wells Fargo likes to micro manage everything, Wachovia was way better to work for from a sales view point.

review_title: Good learning experience, little upward mobility
job_title: Client Service Consultant in Menomonee Falls, WI
pros:
-Paid sponsorship of Securities Licenses
-Great training programs
-Good learning opportunity
-Fast paced work environment
-Coworkers
-FREE LUNCH EVERY DAY
cons:
-Big Brother is watching.  Every call monitored for potential review by internal and external sources
-Little to no growth opportunity outside of call center 
-Boiler room like setting occasionally
-No fixed schedule, rotates quarterly

review_title: Only a good job for people who are excellent in sales
pros: If you do a great job in sales, and I mean great, they will treat you well and offer praise. Ability to advance rather quickly is there, due to the high turnover within the company. PTO right away is one of the perks of the job and they offer a variety of benefit packages that fit the individual.
cons: Micromanagement at it's worst. If you don't like having someone stand over your shoulder all day, this isn't the job for you. They call it coaching, call it whatever you want but it's uncomfortable and usually results in a criticism over why you didn't get your customer to open 9 more checking accounts. Most of the customers you see are regulars and have been asked these same questions weekly, so it begins to feel like you are harassing them. Management doesn't care, they have quotas to make for the day and it's the tellers job to make them. Needless to say, every single day is stressful. You will have someone peering over your shoulders all day, asking why you haven't opened more checking accounts, etc, etc. Tellers have a script to follow with customers, and although they tell you to make it your own, you begin to feel like a robot. The bonus for meeting your sales goals are minimal, so you end up asking yourself at the end of the day.. "what's in this for me" because surely you can make the kind of money you make at Wells, anywhere else. In fact, most banks pay more. The stress isn't worth it, for me anyway. The training is decent but not great. Oh one more thing, hope your feet are made of steel because sitting down is frowned upon in a major way. They peg you as lazy if you take a seat, so get some good orthopedic shoes!

review_title: Hectic... Pressure filled, had anxiety everyday I came to work..
job_title: Personal Banker I in Nashville, TN
pros: Wells Fargo has a long tradition and has been around since the 1800s.  Big bank with a lot of branches.
cons: Very tough bank to work for.   I felt like everyday there was so much pressure on me to produce.  Profit proxy and solutions are the main feature at Wells Fargo.  Each bank product you sell has an assigned profit proxy and that what makes up your goal.  Basicly Wells Fargo accounts for profit for the year. avg profit for all account and services opened.  Each district is different.

review_title: Have to be in the correct "click".
pros: It is a job. Co-workers are developing a great sense of humor. They do hand out memos with sound financial advice.
cons: Since Wells Fargo has taken over, generally salaries have dropped 20%. Memo,  last week. No more EPO, PPO, HMO Healthcare benefits. Only HSA or HRA accounts. No details will be supplied till 2 weeks before open enrollment for 2012. Making numbers does not  guarantee a raise.

review_title: The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly
pros:
1. Anyone can work here, degree or no degree. 
2. Advancement ability in the retail side is great.  The typical career path is from Teller to Lead Teller to Service(Operations)Manager.  Or on the sales side, Banker to Licenced Banker, or Manager, to District Manager. 
3. The benefits and 401k Match are wonderful.  Lots of PTO as well. 
4. Seniority when requesting time off.
cons: 1.  As of 2012 they will be changing the healthcare benefits.  Changes do not look appetizing.

review_title: Dissatisfied with job growth and placement after merger integration
pros: Location, ease of travel, benefits still exist but not as expansive as peer companies.
cons: Company management is slow to incorporate changes that come from non-Wells Fargo legacy employees and to develop an integrated and expansive communication strategy.

review_title: An emotional roller coaster, and an immediate results driven environment in the retail banking sector.
job_title: Business Banking Specialist in Calgary, AB
pros: Wells Fargo has a great brand name reputation.  Its a great place to start a career in banking.  A sales/results driven environment.  Opportunities for career advancement and professional development if you show capabilities of becoming a rock star performer.  Excellent tools for learning and development. Solid benefits package.
cons:
The retail banking environment is micro managed depending on the branch manager you work for.  Some branches have a cut throat sales environment where some bankers are driven to make unethical decisions in regards to offering products or services sometimes without customer consent (ie: Many customer complaints "I came in to order a new debit card, and now I have 4 that were mail to me. Or, customer comes in to open a checking account and is almost forced to open a savings account to "complete the package").  

Some retail branch managers, coach by telling not by showing, and have no clue of how credit works, and most likely could not live up to the sales quota goals they push us to do.  For example if you do not hit your daily goal between 9 - 6, you are forced to stay until 7 to make additional sales calls to hit your numbers without over time pay.

job_title: Client Service Consultant in North York, ON
pros: Stable place to work (operations, service), decent pay, good time off, low pressure work environment in non-sales roles. I enjoyed my co-workers.
cons: Under-qualified over-paid managers, promotions seem to be mainly based on tenure for many areas, status quo thinking, defensive middle management that appear to be solely concerned with keeping their jobs

review_title: My expereince has been horrible for the last 6 months. Managment are like robots and do not care about you.
pros: Love some of the people I work with.
cons:
Horrible to work for:
Micro managing
Doesnt care about the employee. 
They make you feel like you are replacable, and are never good eneough. 
The systems that they use are dinosaurs. They are about 15 year behind the times with software

review_title: You must overly exceed the numbers to avoid from being treated as if you are just a number
pros: The benefits and salary are competitive at Wells Fargo. Schedule is great for retail bank team members. If you enjoy staying busy and are up for the challenge of handling escalated customers you will enjoy this job. If you have a team that is willing to pitch in, or a manager willing to put in the effort to turn it around, you can do great things. The Paid Time Off is great. I believe Wells Fargo as a whole is a great company, the Retail Bank's vision just seems to be going in the wrong direction. I believe it is achievable with the right people in the right roles.
cons: You have to put all of your own needs and goals aside to give to your team if they are not somewhat self sufficient. On top of trying to live up to the expectations a teller already has in their job role with Wells Fargo as far as sales go, as a Lead Teller you will be expected to be the "Super" Teller. If you aren't achieving higher sales numbers than your team, you will be coached (aka, micromanaged) constantly no matter how much you contribute in any other way. Wells Fargo seems to have turned the job around to where instead of training service driven and knowledgeable Tellers, we are now number pushing "Sellers".  You won't get acknowledged by management for going above and beyond for your customer, but for whatever product you can squeeze out of them, you will be praised.

job_title: Personal Banker I in San Dimas, CA
pros: Easy job, great training, fun work environment for the most part.   The job was simple and products were easy to understand.  Working at a branch with walk ins was the key to success.
cons: Constant pressure to do sales.  Cold calling was encouraged if you were slow.  Leads on cold calls were usually terrible, however, some were okay.

review_title: Be Sure to Bring Your Family's and Friends Assets
job_title: Financial Advisor in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Well known, household name. Wells provides a wide range of finacial products.
cons: If you join Wells Fargo Advisors as a Financial Advisor in Training, be sure that your friends and family are committed to transferring their assets to Wells during your apprenticeship period or you will be out the door.  Wells does nothing to provide you with the support you need to build a book of business.

pros: Good vacation time, flexible work schedule, decent 401k matching
cons: Health insurance options are terrible and expensive, HR really limits managers on what they can do to keep talent from leaving.

review_title: Difficult to advance and more concerned with tight numbers rather- hypocritical!
pros: Somewhat flexible hours with self-management of paid time off. Starting pay is okay but not great. Generally hire good people with similar intent. Bring job opportunities to smaller communities.  In some career, you leave the job at work and can go home without the baggage of work stressing you out.
cons: Hours are flexible at the start but once you get a set schedule, its hard to change. Same goes with the pay, you get set in your pay schedule when you are hired, but yearly pay raise are ridiculously low and it gets blamed on the economy, whereas its probably just the company. There are people who have worked with the company for 30 plus years and experience very little pay increases. Some advancements don't actually give a pay increase and you are just expected to lift the heavy load for the rest of the team/company. Extremely large bank that has multiple areas that causes many issues and could be avoided if it were better organized.  The most difficult is advancing your career, it may be different at retail sites, but non-retail is micro-managed and overall performance isn't really taken into consideration. If there was a time where you were on a warning or one month dropped below expectation, it would be highly inspected when you were going through interviews. Getting numbers is huge for this company--as a fast growing giant-- sales are first and helping those that get sales is second if not equal to first. If your not in retail ( which is heavily sales based) the speed at which you can help those in the branches is entirely crucial. If this is not done, there are consequences. I believe this company has the right ideals on the surface, but counteract those ideals when it comes to expectations. For example, WF is highly visionary when it comes to providing the "WOW" experience but gut you when it comes to how quickly you have to get the customers out the door to get another one in for a sale. You have to become the wolf dressed in the grandmothers clothes. You have to think of ulterior motives while putting on the happy-faced mask otherwise your sales/numbers won't make it. You can't think like someone who just likes to be helpful and is a people-pleaser. WF wants you to be the latter, but it doesn't work that way in the front lines. For those of you who have worked in sales, you know what I mean. Benefits are horrible now. They used to be decent, but were recently changed. Vision is good but medical is terrible and expensive and little options to really change.  Also, they feel that making sure you are appreciated as a employee is important--however, in the end you are just an employee number without a name.

review_title: Low pay, little growth, stable job, "Mortgage Assembly Line"
pros:
-If you get hired on as a permanent employee, its very stable unless you mess up REAL bad.
18 days PTO to start
cons:
Pay - they pay you below midpoint (Wells Fargo's "competitive market price") which is usually 30-40% less than what other companies are paying for the same position/work.
Pay Raises: pretty much non-existent. Top tier performers are lucky to get a $0.10/hr increase..

Advancement - Yes, managers have a list of favorites on who to promote. Lots of politics. However, even if you do get promoted after 2 years or so, keep in mind you're still paid 30-40% below industry standard in your NEWLY promoted position..

Lack of care for employees - Overtime is actually Mandatory, so you don't have a choice when they say you will work 50 hrs a week. Of course they pay you, but sometimes family > extra money. The chairs are not healthy for our backs and necks, but management simply says "Bring your own chair"...

Work: This is boring. Have to hit production/quality goals every day, not sales, but still numbers to hit. Bad for your eye health, physical health, and emotional well being after working 10 hour days...hey, better than being a personal banker at a retail store I guess...

review_title: Easy Place To Work, Not Fulfilling
pros: Work/life balance is great. I get tons of time off, and have never had an issue leaving early, scheduling vacation or getting in an appointment during work hours. Health benefits are very good (you have to like account based health benefits to see it like I do). 401(k) Match is very good (100% full match on first 6% of your salary) and there has been an annual profit sharing bonus of 2% for all employees each of the past few years. The firm trips over itself in so many ways, but despite this there is still good money to be made. Career opportunities are there if you want to work in the home office or be an FA. This is an EASY place to work.
cons: The biggest issue is large pockets of employees are scared to try anything new. Getting a CA registered is like pulling teeth. Upgrade the computer operating systems and you have years of co-workers complaining they don't know how to use their equipment (Really? It's Windows. How hard can it be? It's been around for 20 years). Our software doesn't do everything it should (don't worry, each year I'm told updates that will fix everything are on the way). I don't believe our financial products are the best, and this company is very much focused on selling products and not providing the best for customers. The managed product lineup continues to change every couple years, which is embarrassing to tell a client. There is some cross-over between business units which causes confusion among customers (more than one online brokerage for instance, with different pricing and fees between them - e.g WellsTrade and Access Online). Customer notetaking systems are not always used. This is a big problem among FAs who are no longer hungry (they built their book over 20 years and are just coasting, not looking for growth). Career opportunites are lacking if you work in a local branch.

job_title: Collector III in Basking Ridge, NJ
pros: 6% off 401K is matched, and up to $5,000 a year is provided for in tuition reimbursement.  A lot of Saturdays are required of you, but there is overtime pay provided for it.
cons: If you take a job in the Dealer Services division, it is hard to leave for other divisions of the company.  Also, expect to work nights and Saturdays, with little consistency in how far in advance you will know which Saturdays are required for you in a given month.

job_title: Accountant Non Exempt in San Francisco, CA
pros: Start out 4 weeks PTO (vacation and sick), 5 weeks after 10 years. Decent health care benefits and choices, flexible work schedule, informal office attire (except people who deal with customers), older worker friendly, encourages cultural diversity (only 20% white in our group of 100 employees), women-friendly, gay friendly, gives 2 weeks per year for you to particapate in charity work.  Good severance packages.  .
cons: Most office workers look depressed all day, going through the motions, Half the day of spent complaining about management or the company in general. Very, very low salaries, especially for non-exempts.  Extremely autocratic, Thinking out of the boxes punishable by warning.  If you're at staff level 3 (or lower-generally no MBA or CPA if Accountant), chances of promotion none.  Slave wages-$10/hr for tellers, $40k for entry level accountants, 1-2% average annual raises, almost no promotions for staff employees (one promo in my group in 10 years). Only "bonus" for non-exempt employees (90 % of company employees is 1-2% 401k contribution.  Doesn't hire temps. Little permanent hiring opportunities except for low level positions. Since they flaunt their trillions, and as a percentage.  Think of office atmostphere as exactly opposite as what they portray when you walk into a branch and the "suit' is so friendly.

review_title: A good stepping stone for a future higher paying career
pros:
Big company name to put on our resume. (Good resume builder)
A lot of opportunity to move to other departments if you have connections
cons:
Lower pay than all competitors to my knowledge
Yes men and incompetance is how you move up
worried more about fluff stuff than actual sales and performance numbers
If your making large bonuses, you will be under the microscope

review_title: SALES SALES SALES!  It's all about SALES!
pros: Your fellow employees who are committed to doing quality work and yoru regular customers.
cons: Ridiculously high sales goals that are based on antiquated ways of banking.  Customers do everything online or via their phones and the ATM these days.  Traffic and teller transactions have dropped by half year after year, but our goals go up year after year.  Our vision and values say Wells Fargo wants to help every customer succeed financially, however, in reality Wells Fargo wants everyone to open another checking account and another one and another one.  Or as Oprah would say, "You get a checking account!  You get a checking account! And you get a checking account!"  Wells Fargo makes money hand over fist every quarter and year after year (thanks for all those emails to remind me just how much the company makes and how little I make Mr. Stumpf) and Store and Service Managers receive annual bonuses and profit sharing despite not making these daily/monthly goals.  Clearly, those goals are inflated!  75% of the stores in North Carolina have not hit their goals.  There is a reason for that.   Ethics are a serious issue at Wells Fargo.  When you lead with fear, intimidation and tremendous sales pressure, team members will resort to unethical behavior to get out from under the pressure.  Fear will only get you so far.

review_title: Wells Fargo Home Mortgage is a good company to work for you have decent benefits and a fair wage.
pros: The people, passionate about helping people get into homes. In Cleveland, we did it right. We had great talent and they worked hard to make the benchmarks and close loans.  In a big company you have good benefits: eye and dental, and a fair match on 401K.
cons: Too many laws changes, so much especially in the last 3-5 years. It causes a lot of internal changes, checks balances. It's like the basics have been missed (encrypted security, solid structure, vision to the entire team) we were the last to convert to our own system. They still don't have banks in Cleveland (crazy) and there's been a presence here for over 25 years.

review_title: Great Place to work when wanting to give back to  the community
pros: They have so many volunteer events you can attend and get to know people, they offer exceptional training in customer service and hands on learning in different fields. They promote quickly based on hard work rather than tenure. You can build a solid career that you can earn self respect every day.
cons: oh well, when working with finances, there will always be some con's, but the pro's far outweigh any; as with any career, you get out what you put in.

review_title: Large institution with a community feel
job_title: Relationship Manager III, Vice President in Denver, CO
pros: Service commitment that is in line with my values.  Job description is in sync with my career path and focuses on client satisfaction and client retention.
cons: Consistency standards for processes and within departments that continue to struggle with change.

pros: Wells Fargo offers great benefits and will match what you contibute to your 401K up to 6%. It's very easy to balance work and family life because you can always take time off when needed and even WFH for emergency type situations (if you have a laptop). 18 days of PTO for new FT employees. The company supports diversity and also encourages everyone to volunteer. You can take time off during the work week for volunteer events.  If you're too stressed or bored with your job, the company supports buidling your development skills to prepare you for a different position within the company. There are usually plenty of positions to apply for. Wells Fargo does annual reviews that focus on your performance and also focus on skills that you would like to develop. There are tons of online courses that all employees have access to so you have the opportunity to learn something new whenever you have down time.
cons: People move around the company a lot so you constantly have to interact with new people on a project who do not have the same level of expertise as the person who was replaced. There are no bonus opportunites for non-exempt employees. No perks ever. The office environment is very quiet and boring. (This may only be for Wells Fargo Home Mortgage. I used to work at Wells Fargo Bank and there were actual perks and team outings there). It doesn't matter how hard or how long you've worked with an application or team, you will never get promoted. You just have to wait for a position to become available online, apply for it and go through the whole interview process as if you were someone from outside of the company.

job_title: Marketing Database Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Good work-life balance, lots of opportunity for growth and movement, vertically or laterally.  With economic recovery, our division is definitely expanding.

I'm a technical (mostly) worker, and looking to switch industries, so take my review with a grain of salt if you're really into FS.
cons:
Big company, can lose career focus if you stay fixed on the minutia and company processes.  Benefits have degraded down to average.

I'm a technical (mostly) worker, and looking to switch industries, so take my review with a grain of salt if you're really into FS.

review_title: Wells Fargo Advisors- Your experience depends on the department in which you are working.
pros: Wells Fargo Advisors headquarters is in St. Louis and is distinct from Wells Fargo Bank.  If you are in the right department, advancement is relatively easy because management will identify talent and look to promote or recommend to other areas.  There are a lot of opportunities to meet leadership as long as you attend events and network.
cons: After many, many mergers, the company is chaotic and filled with terrible managers, particularly in the Operations areas.  Once in the operations areas, it is very difficult to get out.  Good managers are hard to find and bad managers can easily make your life miserable.  There is a clear preference for people who went to certain schools and can schmooze with management.  The perception of doing a good job often has more to do with if you agree with your managers than actually performing well.  This company is slow to accept and understand the importance of technology and the IT department is silo-ed and poorly integrated.  Any attempt to bring the company into this century is met with serious resistance- for instance, the company was still faxing (in 2012!) and the aging management failed to see a reason to stop.  Since I left, there has been new CEO.  Perhaps she will provide a better culture for ALL employees, not just some.

review_title: Great job, but... the SALES are crazy! Dog eat dog world!
pros: Amazing team! Everyone pretty much becomes your family brothers, sisters, brothers you name it.  I really enjoyed working with my team. Seeing your customers that bring you food and gifts is always a plus. I had the most amazing manager in the world! I can't speak for other branches, but mine was so helpful and really wanted to see her team grow. I loved volunteering for events and the company parties we had were always fun! We were professional around customers, but acted like kids in the break room, I always had a good time. I loved my PTO days!!! The pay was also not bad! I loved my team, but the sales are the biggest CONS!
cons: SALES SALES SALES will drive you crazy and stress you out!!!! Sometimes I would come home and have dreams of work! That's how bad it was, they definitely gave you everything you need to learn and be successful, but after 4 years I couldn't be as successful as I was in the beginning. Each branch pretty much sold to the same customers everyday and they were pretty sick of hearing the sales pitch day in and day out. This company is the MOST aggressive in sales. The quotas are always changing so if we do good, they make the numbers higher to get and if we do bad we get a write up and then your job is on the line. When you do good, you are recognized though EXTREMELY, which is what I liked. Overall its not a bad company to work for, there are so many room for growth. Just make sure when applying, that your ready to dedicate your life to SALES, its the companies main focus. You will also be competing against your co-workers which then turns into a dog eat dog world. Constant arguments with your peers about whose is whose customer and whose sales is whose sales. Sales start to become territorial for each banker and can frustrate the life out of someone. One second your fine and making jokes with your co-workers, the next.... your in an argument and hate each other.  They will drill the life out of you when it comes to that. You will always be scared to lose your job because of it! You will love everything else about this job, besides the sales. You will know what I mean when you apply.

job_title: Store Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: world class training, non stop challenges, lots of opportunity for advancement, decent pay, good benefits
cons: a dog eat dog world.  if you are at 100% of goal the question you will get asked is ""how are you going to get to 110% of goal?"  if you are at 110% of goal you will be asked "how are you going to get to 120% of goal?"  it can be exhausting to work there, nothing you do will be enough,  can lead to burnout.

review_title: The Teller Experience at Wells Fargo Bank (Arizona)
pros:
Overall, I can't say that there was any aspect at Wells Fargo that I perceived as unfair. As a teller, you work in a fast-paced sales environment. This workplace has a serious focus on communication skills. After nearly three years, I really saw an improvement in my overall social skills.

The customers at Wells Fargo were by far my favorite aspect of the job. As a bank teller, I was able to come in contact with a wide assortment of individuals. The overall experience on the teller platform was one that I could easily recommend to any individual pursuing a career in sales or finance. 

Sales goals are relatively easy to meet, and compensation is fair. The benefit of PTO is a welcomed feature. I immediately recognized the human resources department as a top notch facility.
cons:
The only problem I ever had with Wells Fargo was with management. I will always recognize my former branch manager as one of the most competent and hard-working individuals I have ever met. She truly cares about the service that the bank was providing to its customers. She had high expectations for her employees, something that absolutely translated to a great working environment.

However, my service manager was extremely incompetent and unprofessional. This is entirely case by case and I am sure that other branches have a great branch manager-service manager tandem. My former service manager frequently used bully tactics to increase sales, something I struggled to accept. One huge aspect that Wells Fargo focuses on is service. My former service manager made it nigh impossible for us to provide satisfactory service to our customers. She would hover over our shoulders in order to witness an offer. She would high jack transactions and whisper in our ears of all the offers she wanted us to make. This frequently made our customers uncomfortable, as if something was wrong with their transaction. When it came time for me to submit my letter of resignation, my service manager handled as if it was something personal against her. This is entirely unacceptable.

However, the aforementioned scenario is entirely case by case. There are truly some incredible leadership figures throughout each branch.

review_title: IT ALL DEPENDS.............on what dept you're in and who's your manager..
pros: I have been in 4 depts in 8 yrs.- one dept I was in twice.  ONE out of 4 depts was awesome! Management was great, treated well, paid well, bonuses (the first time I was in the dept.)  Large employer locally, several corporate locations in metro area. One thing you can count on at Wells Fargo-constant change.
cons: The 2nd time in the same dept, doing the exact same job-was hired in $5/hr less than the first time.  Management had completely changed in the dept even though I'd only been gone a year.  There is a definite gap in pay from the average worker to the supv level and manager level. Most average workers are working 2 jobs to make ends meet. This is a world-wide company making millions! Not any different than working at Walmart, I think. They lay people off constantly & then rehire only to lay off again.  Managers are promoted without management skills. My mgr has no skills at leading anyone. You can get stuck in a bad position in a bad dept and not able to move for a year. Managers are told to promote your career growth & development. Most managers say they'll help you and/or make promises to help with no real attention to actually helping you grow. Inter-dept promotions are by who your mgr likes not merit. Nit picky about time, where you are, what you're doing, if you are working or not - instead of realizing they hired professionals that will get the job done. Perhaps that's become a problem for WF due to all the laying off-not getting quality people? Treat people like cattle and not a valuable resource.  Again, depending on your dept-but most depts are this way.  I'd say majority of the people working there would say "it's a job" not a career.

pros: Overall I think this company is good to work for because it can give you many opportunities to grow if you are willing and able to take them. I worked as a Teller for 3 years total, with a break in between for 4 years for college, and have seen people "move up the ladder", typically being a Banker in less than 1 year. Job as a Teller is relatively simple considering your 3 main tasks of Customer Service, Sales/Referrals, and Balancing, but does not come without some stress. Anyway, here are the Pros. Bonuses, if you exceed your Sales goals which is not that hard since there will be times when Bankers will help you sell which is nice. Good pay, I think typical for a Teller is around $12.50, which isn't bad since most are Part-time and the job is pretty simple. Hours, part-time is the standard for new Tellers averaging 20-30 hours a week and a 9-5 job. Generally fun people to work with, although there are those people that either have an attitude or power trip. Sundays you have off, unless you work in an In-Store like Albertson's or Vons or something. Main holidays off and paid for. Managers will help you move up if you show an interest. 401K.
cons:
Customer service is hard sometimes since most people wanna be in and out with little interaction which can be difficult since you need to give Perfect customer service. Wells Fargo only accepts perfect customer service and will count against you if you don't give perfect service. They pay a third party to conduct random surveys of customers on Tellers and if they don't give you all "5's" then it might as well be useless. This makes Tellers a little on edge.
A lot of gossip can go on since there isn't any personal space.
Can be difficult to meet your sales goals if you're not constantly asking people for new accounts.
Mangers and Lead Teller are grading you on your interactions with customers.
Hard to multi-task if you're focused on balancing, sales, and customer service all at once with the expectation to have the customer in and out. 
Rules seem to change every so often with regard to either procedure or customer interaction

review_title: Help Retail Employees get out of retail
pros:
Very diverse company, I think we do a great job of having all different walks of life, age, religion, gender, sexual orientation, etc, in all of our lines of business. 

PTO (Sick leave) I experienced first hand how amazing Wells Fargo is regarding sick time and keeping your job. I never felt pressured to come back to work before I was ready and getting paid 100% of my pay check is great for the first 4 weeks and after I received 65% of my pay for an additional 22 weeks or so. 

Management - this differs obviously depending on the type of management you are under. If you have a great and understanding District Manager that will help alleviate the sales stress. 

Sales - Personally I have never been pushed to sell anything that was not in the best interest of the customer but that could be because I am apart of a great district and I have a great store manager. We go above and beyond to do whats right for our customers. 

Work/Life balance - Great, I never have to take work home and I speak/hang out with my coworkers, including my store manager, outside of work by choice.
cons: Its very easy to move up as long as you are doing all activities required in your job description. BUT its not easy to get out of retail. Many of the positions outside of retail banking are just dreams for most of us inside of the branches. It would be great if more positions were available inside of offices, etc.

review_title: Good place, only if you are Salesy and Pushy and lack ethics
pros: Good benefits. And you have the potential to earn a lot of extra money, IF you are good at selling to people.
cons: They are very pushy with their "Sales Goals" and I watched as it pushed people to make unethical choices just to add a couple more points to the board.  They will tell you, it's not sales, you are finding "Financial Solutions."  But really, you're just a teller and a vast majority of your goals are based on the luck of who walks in the door.

pros: Great people, fun team environment during meetings. Good benefits package - if you can ever coordinate your schedule well enough
cons:
Agonizing, high pressure sales. Customers literally come in and tell you to your face not to talk to them because they know you are just going to sell something. Managers and bankers would hover behind you and push their way into your customer conversation in order to make a sale. Managers micromanaged and had the requirement of 3 sales conversations per hour, which seems easy but not when every customer knows your game. 

Best of all, they get you to do all this BS by promising a "bonus" if you achieve at least bronze level in sales, but after working hard and being humiliated by screaming customers (feeling obligated to sell to them even though you knew they didn't want to hear it), the bronze level payout is $1 for every sale, which equates to about $70 minus taxes.  So after a full quarter of sales driven anxiety, I had like $45 to show for my bonus. 

Also - although Wells Fargo likes to promote from within, you pretty much have to do sales intensive, customer facing work for FIVE TO SEVEN YEARS before you can move up into the back office. It would be great if you don't want to go to college or something, but I had a business degree and I still would have had to go through that many years of sales stuff before doing anything of value.

One more thing - they hire you on as an hourly employee and pay you scraps, but they treat you like they own your schedule and you are expected to be there full time every week.  I was hired at 20 hours and still couldn't get time off to get below 36-38 hours.

pros: One of the best things is some of the people you work with including some managers.
cons: Bonuses are difficult to obtain.  Large branches (level 3) and small branches (level 1) have the same goals and these goals are increased slightly each quarter.  As a PB1, your requirement is 6 partner referrals, 100K in loan volume, 18 credit solutions, avg 7.5 products a day, and 450 profit proxy (an arbitrary dollar value assigned to each product).  These are the numbers to meet the "threshold" however this is not what you need to get a bonus.  To earn a bonus, you have to get even more with additional requirements. The maximum payout in a quarter is about 4K; however, less than 1% will make that.  Around 33% will make a payout of $250 to $1800 (majority of it is in the lower end).  The rest will not make anything.  These numbers are based my East Coast experience.  In a typical day, you are rewarded with constant statements of "what do you have for tomorrow" and "encouraged" to get your family members to open accounts.  In addition, branches open on Saturdays require their employees to work 3 out of 4 weekends in a month while branches closed on Saturdays allow their staff off every weekend. Please don't assume there is over-time pay for working on the weekends.  An employee is given incremental amounts of time  off during the week to ensure you don't have overtime if you work Saturdays. Most (not all) of the Branch Managers are not qualified to be in their role.  The unqualified managers obtained their position because of politics or their sales ability.  They have very little management experience and therefore don't always abide by professional standards.  This includes the way they speak to employees/ customers, unfair scheduling, and favoritism.  Unfortunately, some of these individuals become upper management and the Company gets a little worse.  Finally, there are opportunities for advancement as long as you want to stay in retail banking. Its better than what I can say about other companies.

job_title: Business Advocate/Personal Banker in Baltimore, MD

We have to also deal with death certificates, power of attorney, legal dox, notary, beneficiary, estates, trusts. Very complicated legal accounts that are stressful as is handling death related paperwork on a daily basis. It's a downer of a job, really, it's not what I thought at all.

review_title: Beware of the call center trap
job_title: Inside Sales Banker II in Charlotte, NC
pros: Wells Fargo as a company cares for their employees. Anyone with less than 3 years wi the company, starts out with 18 days of vacation time. You earn a base salary with the opportunity to earn bonuses and commission. People in NON-call center jobs seem to be very happy.
cons: The compensation analysts figured out a way to make it where no matter how much you sell, if you take too many phone calls, it reduces or cancels out your commission. But since customer service has a transfer-to-sales quota, you end up with a ton of calls that weren't supposed to transferred to you, which runs your number of calls up, and lowers the conversion rate for the products you get paid for. So basically, you're making the bank money, but you're not getting any of it. To earn a sizable commission, you have to do things that aren't in the bank's best interest, such as sell a secondary deposit account to someone who has already demonstrated they can't manage the account they already have. The QA is extremely picky, yet you need a 90% QA for the month to qualify for commission. The contact center is VERY difficult to post out of. They may promote you from level 1 to 2, or 2 to 3, but very few are released to go to a position within the company that isn't in the contact center. It's probably easier to quit, then apply for what you really want. Be prepared to work every Saturday, until you win a M-F shift in the shift bid (which will take at least a year, but probably more), work until 8 or 9pm, and not have 2 consecutive days off.

pros:
I am currently a Lead Teller at Wells Fargo Bank, N.A. 

It should be noted that this review is better suited to individuals who are looking for a job to support them through their pursuit of an undergraduate degree. Working for a company like this (or any company with a large corporate structure that provides a professional service) will provide you with invaluable professional experience. 

Wells Fargo taught me how to manage time, stress, expectations, coworkers, customers, etc. You will meet all different types of people and be thrust into all different types of situations. Although the job is not difficult nor does it require any type of skill specialization, you will develop a certain level of professionalism that wouldn't be possible in a different industry. You're not showing up to wait tables during evening shifts at a restaurant or bar-tend for kids your age--you're servicing professionals and handling sensitive financial information. Speaking about any of these things in an interview with potential post-graduate employers will make them look at you as if you're made of diamonds and gold.
cons: The room for growth for someone who isn't fully committed to the company is highly limited. If you want to make retail banking (or any arm of a commercial banking entity) your career, you must wholly dedicate yourself to the cause. This involves all of the standard office politicking, unwavering enthusiasm, adoption of the company culture, and a general belief in the importance of the job you're doing. Even with all of this, a company the size of Wells Fargo employs over 200,000 people. Upward movement can and WILL stagnate unless you are an absolute stud who LOVES banking. If the latter portion of that sentence does not describe you, keep your expectations realistic.

Also people are always great, like on every team there are at least 5 great people. And for recreationalists, they do not drug test and have really lax policies. You can't come to work high (though I know a couple people who successfully could because they are such big smokers) but you can have a drink at lunch  or go to a concert and and enjoy yourself. Other companies are really strict and bring your personal life into it. Wells Fargo is very much "If you can do the job well, your personal life is not a concern". On the flip side they also have great programs where if you are struggling Wells Fargo employees as  a whole have a well funded system to assist people in need if their personal lives are unmanageable.
cons:
Call centers suck. Oppurtunities for growth are slow to obtain and haave a definite ceiling (some high performing smart people with their MBAs are stuck at low paid supervisor levels and the execs/junior execs/site managers are kept at their roles for 20-30 years, not a job for a decently educated ambitious person). I'm unaware of other positions with Wells Fargo but I do know that once you are in a call center position with them you are not getting out. You can switch from customer service to home equity of collection to disputes, hell some people work their way from customer service to Executive office leads and make 70k but they are still taking calls from customers complaining about their toaster or some friggin thing. If you start in this job and stick to it, no matter how good or smart you are, you will not make it past team supervisor. You need to go to a different company to get any worthwhile experience after a couple years on the job.

Low paid and slow (to an larger degree than other conservative monolithic banks) to change even the worst policies. Upper levels wont even listen to site managers or smart junior execs, so at this level you can have as many great ideas as you want and they will end up in the same round file. Cure cancer and Wells Fargo wont pay the idea any mind.

Finanally, the customers are already angry at someone else if they call you so they will often come to you at their worst.

pros: A lot of pros at Wells Fargo. They have great benefits that not only benefit you individually, but your whole family. Wells Fargo is a company that is willing to invest in you and they coach you to succeed. They want you to continue to move up.

review_title: Wells Fargo, not the place it used to be... RUN!!!
job_title: Personal Banker in Los Angeles, CA
pros: If your looking for a "first" job, its a great place to work because of their sales training, and you ultimately are working in somewhat of a corporate environment. You will be paid well, especially if you don't have a degree, but believe you me, it is not a place where you will make a career out of. Just a good place to learn how their is a lot of drama, poor management, and none existing bonuses. Those are the pros!
cons:
Lets face it, Wells Fargo = RETAIL. Which is fine, but not when it comes down to dealing with peoples finances. 
When I first started WF in mid 2004, it was nothing to how it is today. I left in 2006 to move, and when I came back to WF in 2009, I left after 3 months.
The fact is, the managers are puppets, they literally know NOTHING. They tell you not to game (which is cheating), but the only way to move ahead is to do so.
Employees they hire now are classless, and have no education, nor background. Personally I hate working with stupid people, and especially having stupid managers.
The company will be the next Enron... Just watch...
The only reason WF did not take money from the government, or the only reason they are still up and running is because of Warren Buffets billions he holds within the companies portfolio. 
If it was not for him they would be no where right about now.
If you are wondering if working for WF will bring you new opportunities, growth, lots of money... Think again. You may need to actually think about working for IN & OUT burgers, they will give you the respect you need unlike WF.
WF has changed, and all they care about is screwing with peoples lives, money, and lieing to their customers.
Free checking?!?!? lol no a thing of the past... WF will slowly begin to crumble, and that's because of their overwhelming turnover rate, and hiring some of the most stupidest people on the face of this planet.
So dont be caught up in the hype. There is room for you to grow in this world and be successful, WF is not the place, unless its your first job.

job_title: Database Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: The best things about Wells Fargo are: Flextime, casual dress, benefits. There are many opportunities for lateral career moves; so this is a good place for younger workers to work their way up from lower paying jobs to medium ones.  People are generally nice.  Wells Fargo has consistently worked to create a positive atmosphere for diversity and the best measure of that is that the company does recognize that it still needs to make improvements in that area. Now among the top 4 or 5 largest banks in the world, Wells Fargo continues to grow the business with long term goals in mind rather than seeking short term profits. In summary, Wells Fargo is a perfectly okay place to work.
cons: The company is experiencing growing pains from the 2009 merger with Wachovia. A new company culture is still forming. There are a lot of extremely talented mid-career employees who are not reaping the financial benefits of their hard work and there are not many opportunities for advancement. At times the workplace begins to feel more like working at a government agency with a tendency to focus more on process than innovation and managing towards the average as opposed to the exceptional. The company certainly enjoys the fruits of the labor of high performance work and creativity but generally, although certainly not always, treats all employees, the average and the best, alike.  Starving for the right tools, information, data, and clear management direction, the work environment sometimes feels like a grand Darwinian organizational survival of the fittest game without the necessary extinctions that should go along with it. Finally, employee compensation is slow to approach market averages.

I mean, talk about not making the world a better place. Best case scenario, my work helps one of the largest companies in the world provide services to other enormous corporations which in turn are able to make more money for themselves- aka making rich folks richer, all while poor people are getting poorer and the unemployment rate is at a post-great depression all time high. 

Whoopdy-do. Also, the people in this company (in my experience) tend to be fairly professional and boring (otherwise they wouldn't be there), which makes the whole office that much more stifling.

Unfortuntaley, I can't say that many people are looking out for the customers best interest. Service issues are avoided in an attempt to spend more time on sales. Wells Fargo is just too big of a bank, the various departments do not work well with each other, as much as they advertise relationship banking, it is very difficult to deliver the personal touch when the various other departments are constrained to working and operating in their little box. Subjectivity and common sense are abandoned on so many occasions and instead the customes are subjected a very robotic, impersonal, and frustrating customer service process. For example, it took me several hours to get a credit card approved because the customer ( who had over 100k in avg balances) had an old savings acct charged off her 60 cents. This was the result of a bank error in the first place, but I had to talke to about 7 different people before I could get anywhere, and unfortunatley this is standard practice. review_title: Work here if you desire to work for very large companies
pros:
Wells Fargo is one of the few US employers in which lifetime employment is still possible.  I know many people who have worked here for 20 or 30 years; some from entry level to retirement, all within this one company.
There is the general banking way, and there is the Wells Fargo way.  This bank is more conservative than its peers. This risk-averse approach has served Wells Fargo well during the Credit Crisis of 2008 and its aftermath.
Senior Management consists of almost always Wells Fargo lifers.  CEO John Stumpf and his predecessor Dick Kovacevich are probably the best in the industry.
cons: One in 500 in the US labor force works for Wells Fargo.  This is one of the largest employers in the world.  Companies of this size move slowly and one cannot get anything done without going through many layers, both vertically and horizontally.  In other ways, you would spend half your day communicating/convincing others on matters that do not require meetings in an efficient small company.  There are 84 distinct businesses in the Wells Fargo family at the last count; the culture varies from business to business, some good, some bad.  Please do not assume Wells Fargo is all the say: Research the specific business and the reputation of its middle management in charge of that business.

review_title: Government should stay out of business
job_title: Home Preservation Specialist in West Des Moines, IA
pros: Most positions at in the Wells Fargo call centers/collection centers/Home Mortgage area have a bonus/comission/incentive plan for almost every position, so those that work the hardest or do the best work are making good money doing what they do. Most entry level positions give employees the abilitly to make $35,000+ per year, and after 1 promotion (which will take atleast one year) coupled with an incentive plan you can make $45,000+. Wells Fargo has a good vacation setup where on day one you are eligible for 4 weeks of PTO and 6% matching 401K plan.
cons: No such thing as sick time so PTO gets used for vacation as well as sick time. The hours can be weird in jobs at the call center/collection center/Home Mortgage area. Schedules that include working a full day on Sunday is not uncommon. It seems like promotions are given to people with experience rather than ability. The government really made it tough for management to keep people happy and keep the work environment consistant. This is NOT Wells Fargo fault but jobs and job titles were changing all the time. No chance to get comfortable in almost any Home Mortgage positions as with new laws coming out, the procedures within the job changed as well. The management style that I experienced was reactive rather than proactive. Wells Fargo is a good place to learn and to grow if you have no formal college education and they give you the opportunity to earn a fair wage that would be comparable to a college graduates salary but with the good comes the bad and with a company with over 275,000 employees, its easy to get overlooked.

review_title: Learn how to deal with pressure!
pros: Wells is a very stable company that's located all over the country.  It provides more than adequate training and tools to help make the employees successful.  There are a ton of advancement opportunities and the management team works with you to achieve your next level of success.  The starting salaries are generally pretty competitive.
cons: The company is very sales based.  It doesn't matter what position you sign up for, you will have a hefty sales goal and not a whole lot of reward if you achieve it.  Regardless of where you work, what your traffic is like, or whether your short staffed or over staffed- every person in your position has the same goal.  There is a huge emphasis on making sure we do what's right for the customer and giving them a WOW experience, but sometimes doing what's best for the customer isn't sales related- and Wells doesn't like that.  You're expected to cross-sell EVERY SINGLE person that sits at your desk, regardless of why they sit down.  We are consistently signing "acknowledgements" letting us know that if we don't do something right, we'll be written up.  You aren't supposed to live in fear, but the pressure to perform and not get written up is so high, that the majority of the people who work here can't sleep on a consistent basis and are completely stressed out.  Maybe it wouldn't be that bad, but they took away a LOT of things we got sales credit for- so now we have to do much much more for the same numbers.

pros:
Your entire job experience depends on where you work and who you work for.  Management is very decentralized, so many decisions are made locally/a few levels above you.  
PROS:
-Lots of room for advancement, though it becomes increasingly difficult the higher you get.
-Wide domestic reach and decentralized HQ, so finding a corporate/non-retail job not in San Francisco or Charlotte is relatively easy.
-Relatively stable for the 4th largest bank
-Many employees have pride in their job and the company
-Decentralized management means slightly less bureaucracy in decision-making
-Ability to work a flexible schedule or from home, BUT it depends on your manager/group
-Favors promoting from within, though competition for many jobs is very tough as there's a lot of talent out there
-Generally diverse employees in every respect, though there are definitely more female employees
-Fairly generous PTO policy, but the rest of the benefits are standard 
-Upper management generally feels more accessible than other companies
cons:
CONS:
-The company is so large (270k+ employees) that "making a name for yourself" is almost impossible.
-Since it's so decentralized, the wishes of senior executives often don't trickle down (i.e. "People as a Competitive Advantage" is often just a saying and not put into practice in my experience).
-Salaries/bonuses and raises tend to be on the lower-side, but is also very dependent on your manager and what group you work for.
-Cultural differences still present from Wachovia, so if you work in the East not all of Wells Fargo's ideals are practiced.
-Lower & Middle management frequently lack the skills to manage
-Company advocates training to become better/learn new areas, but people rarely do and you have to push for it
-The post-2008 banking world has made WF more fiscally conservative and layoffs are no longer unheard of
-Due to decentralized management, you cannot expect the same culture, expectations, viewpoints to be shared by a manager somewhere else (i.e. 1 might let you work from home, then another might not at all)
-Sales positions have aggressive sales goals
-Equipment/offices are hit/miss, some are very nice, some horrible.  Some have tons of empty offices and space to stretch, some have you jammed in a small cubicle. You also might get a new laptop/Blackberry, but oftentimes the internal software/systems are very outdated
-There are recognition programs in place, but they're often ignored
-Horrible medical care plans (1 HRA or 1 HSA is all you can choose in 2012)
-Decentralization tends to create gaps in responsibility, so sometimes you don't know who to turn to for help (i.e. there is one number for Tech Support, BUT tons of other ways to get tech support that sometimes you don't know which to choose)
-Finally, I've been fairly objective in this review but I was recently fired for very minor reasons after 15 years with WF and several WF policies and possibly the law were violated.  Another example where too much power is given to lower management circles, as no 2nd objective party was aware.

Bankers get in trouble for transfering to other departments for assistance even if the call is NOT related to the position that we were hired for.     Sales Sales Sales,  If you dont like or are not good at sales this is not the place for you, Wells requires you to attempt a sale on every call no matter what the customer is calling for.  I believe the company has good intentions for the customers but have not perfected the sales / service line that needs to be walked in order to achieve sales but still maintain the level of customer service that wachova did.

review_title: Great vision and values, not great entry-level culture
pros: Wells Fargo executives know what they're doing. The company's stock price, customer satisfaction levels and revenue are great. The company treats every employee well as far as benefits go, but that was DRASTICALLY cut beginning of 2012, so not as true anymore. Great company to be in at senior levels, and great company to invest in.
cons:
1.) Customers are generally getting unhappy about the constant changes in fees. Lots of complaints weekly. Oh, well.

2.) Rampant cheating of sales incentives, often not in the customer's best interest.

Despite the ideal that CEO John Stumpf strives for in his words, the structure of the incentive program rewards cheating. To meet sales goals, I have seen every single employee I've ever worked with bend the rules against the customer's best interest in order to boost their sales. I'm sure I've even done it unintentionally. There is a risk of getting fired if you don't meet goals, and even if you don't worry about meeting goals, I assure you your managers are worried they'll get fired if they don't meet goals, so be prepared to get tought talk from management.

The company will fire people, too, for cheating, but it's too easy to cheat. I've seen every single one of the tellers and bankers I've worked with break *some* rule, whether intentionally or accidentally, in order to get a sale from a customer. Usually it's misleading the customers about account minimum requirements or telling them to open up "secondary checking" accounts and then later closing the original account so the banker doubles-up on credit.

They tell you up front from the start that the retail positions are sales positions and that you have sales goals to reach, so I'll give them points for being transparent.

review_title: Great company if you aren't in sales role.
pros: They promote a lot from within. They also have great vacation and holiday time. They don't pay the best compared to other banks, but there are a lot of really amazing benefits.

pros: Wells fargo is a good company to start off at the co-workers are very frendly and treat you as family and and that you can learn lot about banking

pros: Good benefits and great teammates. Wellsfargo is a really strong bank.and offer great products!

These are NOT all manager's though, most have great intentions and are qualified.

review_title: Worst experience I ever had (15 years in the banking industry)
job_title: License Personal Banker II in Coral Gables, FL
pros: The only "Pros" at this company are the HR benefits. (Which you will get at any other financial institution)
cons: The product pushing at WF is horrendous, no customer service at all, I would actually feel bad for customer since the service was so bad. Management was inexperience, sarcastic, unprofessional and disrespectful, all that matter for upper management is production. Additionally, no money to be made, goals are unattainable and commission are very poor.

pros:
Great opportunities to advance
Good benefits
Great training programs
Team environment
Reasonable PTO allotted
cons:
Highly sales driven company.....extremely high sales goals
Your sales performance is huge deciding factor on whether you're promoted or not, whether you get a pay increase, or in some cases your manager might show more favoritism towards those with higher sales numbers.

 I personally had great managers , but I have heard and seen them show more flexibility towards those meeting their numbers. 

Even if it's a very slow customer traffic day, Wells Fargo still expects you to meet your daily sales goals as a store and your individual goals. 

Oh and whenever they have audits , it's super stressful! You have to study for store audits year round almost. It's a huge deal, because if the store fails, your manager looks really bad and they could potentially get written up themselves, demoted, or even fired. So therefore, you will also be made to feel the pressure of the store audits as well.

Also, I was a top performer. Always met or exceeded my sales goals, always came to work, stayed late if necessary, came in early if necessary, was a team player and all that good stuff. Well, whenever they did the yearly reviews, I got maybe a 0.30 cent raise. So they are a low paying bank compared to other banks or their competitors. I started off making barely over $10 an hour and I had more than 5 years of experience before. When I  tried to negotiate, HR Recruiter said that they expect you to make up the difference in sales compensation. You only get paid for sales quarterly at the earliest.

Besides SALES, SALES, SALES, AND MORE SALES, WF is not a horrible place. Again, they have very extensive training, good benefits, and at some locations flexible schedules. If you're in school, must managers will work with you when you're part-time at least.

job_title: Assistant Vice President, Store Manager III in Westchester, IL
pros:
Exceptionally up-to-date technology, they are a company that "listens" (or tries to) to their front line employees. Upper management is excellent, they have great visions and goals, excellent reward programs, trips, incentives for top performers. 

Pay is good. Benefits are on par with other institutions, excellent tuition reimbursement program. Fantastic amount of PTO provided. Top company for LGBT communities, minorities, women, etc. They are very focused on diverstiy.
cons:
There is a disconituity between top leadership and mid-level management. Ex. a new system rolled out that was a difficult transition for many employees. Top level leadership had the vision of the new system being a tool to assist bankers with improving the customer experience, but the only way the company was able to measure use was through completion statistics. Regional managers therefore set ridiculous goals for usage of the system. Coaching was around "why weren't you 100%), rather than focusing on the completed transactions and how they went, and how they helped the banker and customer. This created a very negative attitude toward the new system on the bankers part, and they frequently "fake" the completion without actually following the process, simply to get regional management off their back. This just equals no improvement for the customer experience, with more busy work for the bankers- not the vision that leadership had set forth. 

Sales, sales, sales. That is really all Wells Fargo cares about. There was a recent scandal in California because bankers were cheating to make their sales goals. This was a year after I left, but I was not surprised in the least- I had employees who transferred from California (where all of the top regions in the company are located) and I was stunned by their practices- what they thought was normal protocal was actually flagrant violations of the company's code of ethics. The pressure is intense, and the focus is always on quantity, never quality. Likewise, customer service scores are measured on a pass/fail basis- either a score is perfect or considered a failure (despite the customers giving a rating of 1-5), which is very discouraging to employees. 

There is a major disconnect between each market. This, on one hand, could be a good thing, as the company believes in letting managers "run their own business." For me, I was in a market run by a very strict leader who saw no room for fun and was entirely focused on exceeding all of the company's goals and ranking #1. This is not necessarily true for every market of course, but I know there are a lot of significant differences between markets. My RM required pantyhose to be worn year round- even in the dog days of summer- where other markets were much more lenient. It all depends on where you are. 

Lack of opportunity to grow. Each line of business is like it's own company, and they like to promote from within. This makes it exceptionally difficult to move around and try different areas of the bank, without taking a huge pay cut and starting at the bottom. 

Maternity leave (STD) is awful and paternity leave is non-existent.

review_title: Amazing Experience for 1-2 years, Then Get Out

review_title: Bankers butt is a real thing
pros:
The training was extensive (1 month) and paid. They even paid for a hotel and meals because I lived an hour + away from the training center. 
Pro and con - you get to sit most of the day. 
I really liked my coworkers. The manager was approachable and chill for the most part. They bought us cakes on our birthday  :) 
The system was easy! 
Weekends off is a major bonus. The hours were pretty great too. My branch was open Saturdays but we closed early. 
I would only recommend this job to a friend. It was easy as long as you can count.  The money is not that great, but not horrible. I started at $11.00
cons:
Numbers, numbers, numbers! 
I worked as a teller in a branch in Northern California. I was paid a base wage plus commission quarterly. I saw my coworkers sell credit cards to college students with $20 in their bank account. My manager mastered the art of the plastic smile and could tell you your dog died with a smile on his face. There are different levels of commission for sales and customer surveys and it is capped. When you reach that, there is zero incentive to sell. When I moved, I worked with the recruiter for 3 months to find a transer 50 miles away. I gave up after 3 months and 5 interviews. Apparently my number weren't good enough, even though I maxed out commission for selling and customer surveys for 1 year. I would probably still work there if it weren't for that.

review_title: Decent salary and benefits, limited upward mobility

cons: Difficult to move up.  Although there are some really good leaders, often management is cool, removed from staff,  and not exactly supportive. Learning and development opportunities are not adequate or accessible to everyone.

job_title: Personal Banker Ll in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Like a Visa debit card, Wells Fargo is everywhere you want to be.
cons: A Banker's performance is evaluated on how closely they follow " the road map." pros: Standard benefits, 401k match after one year, profit sharing of 1-2%, vacation days, most national holidays paid to be off, no Sundays, encouraged diversity inclusion, 1 paid volunteer day/per year, paid training
