review_title: Several opportunities but not the place for professionals
job_title: Mortgage Document Specialist, Team Lead, SME in Denver, CO
pros:
Due to it's size, there are many opportunities to switch fields or locations. It is a great place for entry-level work, a place to get your foot in the door. I was hired as a contractor, but a month later, myself and everyone else in my office was converted to WF full-time staff. The company has been around for a long time and not only survived the housing bubble burst but thrived from it. You won't have to worry about the company being acquired and losing your job due to "synergistic money-saving opportunities." They provide excellent benefits including the usual healthcare, 401K, etc. but also great discounts on products (meaning bank accounts, mortgages, anything else they sell).

I worked with some fantastic and passionate people. The longevity and size of the company means there is always an answer to be found, and there are several wonderful tools available to help you do your job. We worked late twice a week and dinner was always provided, then on Fridays we got a free snack, like dilly bars from DQ. I'm pretty sure I gained at least 20 lbs in the year I worked there.
cons:
As with any large company, there is very little visibility by the people making the important, impactful decisions, and the lower rung people that those decisions affect. Also because of its size and corporate atmosphere, it is impossible to get a truthful response from management regarding the future of your position and/or department. I worked in mortgage refinance, and within a year, we had opened a new office and closed it back down. No effort was made to find other positions for us within the company, not even for those managers who had relocated to help open the office. There is absolutely no loyalty and being great at your job means nothing.

Due to some recent policy changes in HR, it is nearly impossible to fire someone, which may sound like job security, but if you care about your work, it means you will work with people who don't care, can't operate the software, and/or have bad attitudes. Additionally, HR is very strict when it comes to meeting the criteria in a job posting. If your resume isn't quantifiable in a way they checks every single box, they will automatically toss it out.

review_title: A good place to work for a while
pros: The benefits are getting even better, The pay is slightly above the average minimum wage. No working outside but on rare occasions. The company does a lot of volunteering.
cons: All the stores operate on a set goal based across the united states. While they say they are trying to get away from sales pressure to it employees, This reality check to the company still has its upper management caring more about sales numbers and still talking about it multiple times a week to beat a dead horse. The stores still have unrealistic goals set to never hit payout or bonus which are a huge part of the promised earnings to be had. Also the staffing is bare bones. So if someone gets sick, takes a vacation, or is loaned out to another store, everyone pays for it by having to produce more. Management doesn't care if you are short staffed they only care about why you didn't hit a number goal. Even if you are a great worker with a great attitude and customers love you, if the upper managements ego isn't stroked you are going no where. Don't ever work in a slow or smaller local community store because the ranking or goals for individual performance are only set by the performance of the bigger stores. So you will never hit your goals in a small town community bank. My last thing. This is a great job for single people who have little to no responsibility. But for people with families there is no work life balance, it is all work balance with no life. You can work other places with less responsibility for more money. The cultures and values sound good on paper too bad no one is applying them to their work or the people they manage. Upper management only cares about their bonus, or the freebies that only they get because the people who earned them aren't getting anything but pins to be worn for flair.

pros: you get stable income, co workers are good and supportive , you get 3 and half week vacation.
cons: If you are working as a teller, its all about sales, if you are not performing well in the sales the management will keep force you to sell all the time. which is not good for a long term if you are not a sales person and looking something else in life. This job is those people who enjoy talking to people and do more sales , otherwise you are counting cash your life time.no promotions

pros: Some management were great, some team were also awesome, 401k plan a good benefit, health insurance options were also good in my opinion reasonable as far as cost, better salary start compare to other companies, encourages great customer service to employees to provide great service to customers, nice awards events for top producers, has good HR department with fast hiring process, love the quarterly training modules to update banking policy changes,marketing is also good to be used as great resource to gain new customers

review_title: Left after 13 years at Wells Fargo corporate
job_title: Senior Communications Consultant, Assistant Vice President
pros:
- Excellent 401(k) package with 100% company match up to 6% of your annual total compensation.
- Excellent PTO allowance with additional accrual per years of tenure (I was earning 28 days of PTO per year when I left).
- Generally respects work/life balance, but depends on manager/team/area. My managers always protected work/life balance for our team.
- As a company, Wells Fargo generally tries to encourage diversity; however, see my related point about diversity under "cons."
- Awesome 24/7, in-house support for tech and HR issues.
- Good tuition reimbursement program (I used to to achieve another degree while still working full-time).
- Lots of employees trying to do the right thing and make a difference.
cons:
- Too many departments are currently (Q4 2018) operating in an "everything is an emergency" environment, which is stressful and toxic. Many salaried employees are expected to work around the clock because leadership has poor handle on the workload and refuses to hire additional people to manage it.
- Intense wage stagnation despite record-breaking profits quarter after quarter. Anemic annual raises are never commensurate with inflation and may not even cover the annual increase in healthcare costs.
- Company is unwilling to promote top performers without a business case justifying why the department requires that higher-level role. Promotions NEVER happen on merit or years of service. I was a top performer every year I worked at Wells, and my manager and I had to fight hard for the ONE promotion I ever got, five years ago.
- Moving up (or laterally) is difficult because the company is unwilling to consider transferable skills when hiring, even with internal candidates. If Wells were hiring for President of the United States, they would only hire someone who had been President before.
- Healthcare package gets worse every year (more expensive for less coverage).
- In private/closed-door spaces, I personally witnessed former executives (direct reports of the CEO) laughing and making dismissive comments about the importance of diversity. They clearly didn't care that I, and other support staff, was also in the room with them. Although these individuals have since left, how much hope can a rational person have that the culture "at the top" has truly changed?
- Difficult to work for a company portrayed (rightfully?) by the media as so morally bereft. Difficult to continue defending Wells to family and friends.
- In my department, leadership was unwilling to define the scope and responsibilities of my team. Because of this, we became a dumping ground for menial items unrelated to our jobs, which was absurd and demoralizing. This was the main reason I left.
- Leadership, as a whole, is oblivious to what is happening in the trenches.

review_title: Used to be a nice place, but...
pros:
When I first started:
-Flexible hours (could work 9-5, or work a 4-10 schedule)
-Managers expected results but treated us like human beings
-Work culture was fairly balanced
-Managers were transparent in departments goals and expectations, which made it easier for us to work and obtain (we consistently met 97% SLA monthly all over the country).
-Entry level pay was fairly competitive

When I left:
-Team came together, but it was due to us relying on each other to get through the day.
cons:
By the time I left:
-They laid off our sister site with little warning, despite our departments doing very well
-They strung contractors along for well over two years before they got frustrated and left; they were dedicated and reliable workers, and new contractors were a mixed bag.
-In my last year, we changed over multiple managers; I believe our immediate manager tried to shield us from a lot of things, but upper management pressed hard, which trickled down to the Processors
-Micro-managing. We were only allowed seven minutes the entire day to use the restroom. As the bathrooms were on the other side of the floor, one visit took 3 1/2 minutes, running. 
-Work environment became toxic, and by the time I left, the turnover rate had been rising.
-Managers no longer were transparent; goals changed frequently without warning, and upper management became obviously disdainful of the Processors when we didn't meet 100% SLA (our team worked with appraisers all over the country, and most of the time if a report didn't come in on time, it meant the appraiser had trouble or just didn't bother doing the report).

As my former coworkers told me, my department no longer exists as it used to.

pros: Good benefits and good team members
cons: Not all management is good.Bad managers will write lies abut you to stab you in the back while at same time tell you to your face: I am here to support you. Their real goal is to push you out of the company...even though you're doing great work.

review_title: Some good, some bad, but don't expect any sort of professionalism
job_title: Private Banker III in San Jose, CA
pros:
A great job when you're in college and just starting out; I had tuition reimbursement for some college costs, and I worked in a retail environment, which allowed me to work part time but still gave me medical benefits (although that's no longer offered to part employees, this was over 6 years ago).  Moving up within the branch environment is easy as long as you don't mind sales and are aggressive in asking to move up the ladder.  

The other positive is you may get end up in an office where the management and staff are great; there aren't many offices that are like that, but like at any company, the people you work with will be a mix of good and bad, and there are some managers that will try to mentor you and help you move up, so it really pays to choose your location carefully.
cons:
Unfortunately, there seems to be more negatives than positives working for Wells Fargo.  The sales culture throughout the company is aggressive, with a tunnel vision towards production numbers, with no concern regarding the appropriateness of the sale to the client.  It doesn't seem to matter if the customer doesn't benefit from the loan, acct, etc; nor management seem to worry much about the overall revenue impact (for example, bankers are sell equity lines, credit cards, etc to customers that state clearly they don't want to have or use them)- incurring set up costs(appraisals, back office underwriting, etc) that are paid by the bank, with no revenue being generated.  The only focus is on the quarterly numbers of new accounts opened and loans generated.

Within the wealth management group, there is still an aggressive focus on sales; the investment managers, brokers, and trust team members are paid primarily from fees and revenue that they generate on an annual basis, so there is a strong incentive to keep all clients in accounts that charge annual management fees as a percentage of assets, even when the accounts aren't actively managed- trades are only executed a handful of times a year, so a client would spend much less if they paid per transaction, but again, this is strongly discouraged.

Team members are not encouraged in any way to take ownership of the company- there used to be an expression "run it like you own it", that is no longer used.  The entry level to mid level managers are underpaid and overworked, and typically don't have much experience, so there is very little direction or mentoring, it's very much learn as you go, and if your sales numbers drop for a quarter, expect to have your job threatened, even if you've performed above standard for years prior.

And finally, office politics are a huge issue; gossip and backstabbing seem to be everyday events, especially as you move up to and past the VP level.  Talent and results become less and less important, but who you are "friends" with becomes more and more important as you try to grow a career here.

review_title: Wells Fargo is an Awesome Company, Wells Fargo Financial is not
pros: Honestly, if you don't mind analyzing what you are actually selling, then you will enjoy this position. The people are great, and everybody works together. But you can't assume that because you wouldn't take a product, that the customer won't.
cons:
This is definitely a sales job, which is great. However, you are selling loans with outrageous rates. Some customers could not get a loan anywhere else, but most can. You are basically selling the fact that and installment loan will get paid down faster than a revolving credit card, even at a higher interest rate. But this installment loan also puts a lien against an asset, which we know Suze Orman's opinion on that. And honestly, the only reason we show the customer that an installment loan can get paid down faster is because we assume they will lower their payments on their credit cards as the minimum payments are lowered. 

I also want to note, when I took this position, I was told we were helping people, and that the average credit manager earned around $1500 in commissions per month. You don't actually help many people in the respect of financial advising, but you help a slim few.  Basically, by helping you are only meeting one of a few possible criteria, but this doesn't mean you are actually mathematically helping them. And as for pay, I was promised the commission numbers prior to the introduction of the FHA loan. Prior to that, the top credit managers would earn on average a few hundred per month. Many did not earn an commission at all. The FHA closings will help for a while, but with the climbing rates, it will get harder to sell the FHA now. I also had a few customers back out of FHA because of the fees.

job_title: Credit Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: There are good products like the HAS, the credit insurance, and FHA refinance loans. There are bonuses for referrals to the bank for checking accounts and customers get a free $50 and you get $25. The breaks are consistent-10 minutes in the morning and afternoon and hour at lunch. If you miss a break they pay you for an hour of work. Base pay is 36k in CA and lower in other states where cost of living is lower. This is a good first job for anyone out of college to learn about finance while getting paid. The training is decent and there are a few travel opportunities. The vcp is there if you sell an fha loan but not at what you think. The most vcp I've seen ever is 16k for a manager who sold a record-setting 6 FHA loans.
cons: There is pressure to sell all products, not just the ones you think are fair. We are told to just sell the benefits of the product regardless of whether we think the customer should take it. I have to sell 20-30% credit cards to customers who can get half the rate at the bank.  Our auto loans are no better. Even at 100% loan to value with a high credit score I see 13, 14%. I hae seen auto loans at up to 26%. The most frustrating part of the job is how rarely we can help someone, how rarely they are approved, and how rarely they take it even if the first 2 apply. They told me I'd be on the phones max 3 hours a day when I interviewed, but it's more like 5-6. You have to work overtime and on Saturdays if you are not producing in a month, regardless of how well you do other months. The micromanagement here is so high. I would rathar work for lower pay at a place where customers come to us, and we have to sell, rathar than selling over the phone.

pros:
Nationwide footprint makes it easier to relocate.
Career opportunities/opportunities for advancement and the tendency to promote from within.
Strong company with tight controls on operations.
cons:
I'm seeing a trend where good, solid, hardworking, ambitious and talented team members in retail banking are pushed to their limits and many of them are feeling extreme stress due to the twin forces of extremely aggressive sales goals and a reduction in staff to reach those goals due to budgetary constraints.  Store management in particular is being asked to practically perform miracles.  I know many store managers who are leaders within their market who have grown to hate their jobs.  These are previously extremely engaged, extremely productive and loyal to WF people who are feeling stressed and very unhappy.  If the economy were better, they would be leaving for better opportunities.  It's just not worth the stress.  I worry about the future of this company if they don't try to retain their best people.  Unfortunately, I know people all around the country that work for WF who all feel this way.

Luckily, I scored a position outside of retail, though I'm feeling the constraints of a reduced workforce as I am expected to do the work of two people.  I have very poor work/life balance.  The demands on my time are high and it is taking a toll on my personal life.  I enjoy doing a job well, but at the end of the day, I work to live, not the other way around.  It would be nice if WF recognized that I need that balance to truly be the most effective employee I could be and one that felt some loyalty to the company.  

I don't hate what I do or hate the company, but I can assure you, if I had the opportunity to make the same pay with a normal 40 hour work week, I would take it!

review_title: stressful but not enough opportunities to learn new skills and knowledge
pros: they offer good benefit plan, very generous on vacation days, nice working hours,rarely do over time, and well known company for its success in the past
cons: lots of  sales stress, too much that make the work meaningless sometime(not benefit for its employees, the company and their customers),poor personal development, poor senior management, lack of communications

review_title: Growth over time through several bank positions but didn't enjoy the work environment.
job_title: Personal Banker II Registered in Twin Falls, ID
pros: Wells technology is unparalleled.  Their employee training is superb.  Vision and Values are spot on but this leadership does not trickle down to the front lines.
cons: Staying after hours to make sales calls.  High-pressure sales environment.  Poor sales managers make up for inadequacy by increasing stress and pressure; but this does not work effectively.

review_title: A HUGE waste of my time
job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in Fort Myers, FL
pros:
- After 5 years of working with the company, I was one of the top paid people in my area.
- Wells Fargo is a good company that has made solid business decisions, leading to financial success.
- A good amount of PTO after 2 years with company
cons:
- I had 6 different managers in 1 branch in less than 1 year, even they are all leaving the company
- Management is too young & inexperienced, they don't know how to keep good people
- I worked 73% of my Saturdays the last year, after being promised my "work/ life" balance would improve (yeah right)
- Goals are a moving target, ever changing and always unclear

pros: Great culture, many opportunities for advancement and community involvement.  2up managers are always willing to take the time to listen to ideas and are open to suggestions.  Most business lines take feedback seriously.
cons: Some Wachovia culture still exists, pushing blindly for numbers without any concern about if they're genuine or not.  Must be willing to accept slightly lower pay for stability and job security.

pros: Health Insurance, 401K, & Tuition Reimbursement, and profit sharing are all available.  Vacation time is adequate. There are incentives for meeting and exceeding goals. A 200-600 bonus is paid every quarter for over 80% perfect customer satisfaction, based on Gallup polls.  I have heard that other branches are somewhat better than where I work..
cons: The health insurance is not good.  For tuition to be reimbursed, you must stay employed at Wells for a year past when your tuition reimbusement is paid by WF, and if your semester ends in December, it will more than likely be paid in January. Vacation time is picked by seniority and it is VERY inflexible company. Do not expect to take a three day weekend or take off a Saturday to go to a wedding if that is not your alotted vacation time that you have picked in January for the ENTIRE YEAR. Also, who decided that pefect scores 80% of the time are a good way to alocate bonuses when A.) Nothing is ever perfect and can be improved, therefore most of those polled are very unlikely to give perfect scores--most people, including myself think it is implausible and therefore necessary to at least give a very good vs. excellent rating to give the survey more validity and B.) When customers are closing there accounts in droves relating to WFs policies and procedures which also cause extremely long wait times, do you really think that they will not take out any of the adimosity on the surveys?. Ridiculous.

review_title: They work you hard but you learn banking inside and out if you're good.
job_title: Premiere Banker in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good for outgoing, strong sales and work ethic people.  The company likes to promote from within and reward success.
cons: They work you hard and expect high sales numbers consistently.  If you get an overbearing manager who concentrates too much on the sales numbers morale and the quality of the team/work goes down precipitously.

pros: Good sales experience, utilize the experience to boast about relationship building and excellent service.  Read the 48 Laws of Power and live by it, playing politics will get you further than hard work and effort and make sure you notate every move you make in order to cover your ass when people attack you because you perform better than them.  If you can bite your lip and do what you're told you'll be seen as more of a value than if you were an independent thinker and this will move you up the ladder faster.  Overall, the idea is to get as many promotions as you can in order to make your resume "SHINE" ;)
cons:
Low pay vs. High expectations.  Often you will be offered a low position to do the same work of that of a hire position for less pay.  CSSR should be viewed as an acronym for underpaid Personal Banker (You will be expected to perform banker duties and meet banker goals until you're burnt out, at which point you will no longer desire your small pay increase to do the same duties for another year).  If you desire an "in" for a corporate job don't count on it, promotions to corporate jobs are next to impossible.  They don't hire full time tellers and with the current employee turn over rate lack of customer attention will result in negative service scores and a lower bonus.  No worries though, because if you really bust your hump you'll be highly disappointed by the time you get your bonus anyway.  

The benefits used to be great, now we've transitioned to HRA and HSA plans which pretty much make them not worth it.  I haven't used them since we switched.  What I do like is the 6% match on my 401k, the employee stock purchase plan, and the occassional company wide bonus.

If you have children, or other obligations, or you enjoy your nights and weekends, or don't appreciate ten hour work days...RUN.

Keep this is mind when you consider this job...Wells Fargo is a LENDING bank. Lending is where they make their money.  They are a successful and fabulous lending company but when it comes to retail banking products and services they need to revamp their approach to attract younger professionals to their banking products which in turn will lead to lending products.

pros: Position started out great, had a great manager initially, was able to put forth creativity with manager's trust.
cons: Due to re-organizational changes, I was re-purposed to another team without my consent or input, was told to take on more responsibilities without better pay yet the position became more silo-ed therefore alot of what I previous enjoyed doing were assigned to other silo-ed teams. When asked if I can transfer to another team/position, was told I had to wait 12 months before I can post out. Bonus structure was very vague, nobody seemed to be able to be very specific how it's defined, yet was told it's dependent 3 tiers - Line of Business performance, Department's performance, and team's performance. My individual perform only affected my annual raise with a 5% cap. After shift in mgmt/team, my manager did not know the business to speak fluently to the business nor make sound decisions, which affected the team's performance tremendously. However, the feedback received from the business was tailored to not reveal the weakness within the process nor the team, which didn't allow for us to have backup data to seek better mgmt. The lack of true analysis on the necessary evaluation of the business performance and successful hindered the ability to bring out the lack of skills or bad decision making. I also didn't feel that individuals were appraised and placed into mgmt roles based on their skills & experiences, but rather the number of years dictated the dedication to the company therefore rewarded into mgmt roles, which causes teams & individuals to not properly grow and perform up to their proper skill set. Since it's a bank with long term tenure, it has been successful in sustaining the economy, however from what I've seen the methods and lack of training necessary to support the teams that make vital decisions for the company, I find their method for success to be sometimes questionable.

pros: The benefit package is great. There's a lot of hardworking and very good at their job people that work. You meet all kinds of people from every circle of life.
cons: The bank is turning into a retail store. Its more concern with sale goals instead of  the people that bank there. they give no regards to forcing old accounts into new accounts by changing the qualifications of maintaining the account. The hours of banking are not realistic dues to the fact that processing is closed at 4p.m. and workers have little to no time to balance life and work. Sale goals aren't realistic I'm got against growth but not all the products  don't work for everyone  for an example   an 82 yr old customer who enjoys coming to the bank to do all his/her banking needs and have no clue about the internet will not use online banking  because when u know the customer well enough it makes no sense to pressure him/her into getting it. Also if you don't meet goals for the week prior be prepared for an extra early meeting as to why you haven't and still have to work a full shift following it. Retail and banking is different, your customers don't need so many accounts. Wells Fargo taken out all the joy of going to work with a smile to everyday over worked, stressed and  wondering if you'll have a job.

pros:
Great Training
Oppourtunity to advance
Strong Company
Good Benefits
cons:
Sales Goals are not tailored to the demographics. A Small town has the same sales quotas to meet as the big cities do.
You get placed on warning and are faced with possible termination if you do not meet your goals.
You are required to try to sell something to every customer that walks in, they track you through the computer and know if you aren't doing it.

pros: I've worked with great people, great managers, and great customers. It has been a pleasure thus far to be a part of Wells, and I do recommend it to friends. Being a teller has its pros and cons, but for me, the pros far outweigh the negative. Excellent upward mobility.
cons: A lot of sales pressure, although sales are fairly easy to come by. Sometimes, it can feel as if your work is a little under appreciated, as it's rarely about what you accomplished yesterday, but rather what you can do for them today.

review_title: Wells Fargo Home Mortgage! Work there at your own risk
pros: Can only think of the fact that current employees are considered for opened positions first
cons: First and foremost, the hiring process let to be desired! the recruiters do not fully disclosed the fact the dpt was a call center and the position production based. When asked the questions, it was only stated that the question could not be answered unless the job was accepted. Rewards/incentive are performance based which by the way, the employee has no control over, unless you are cheating. Even with a middle of the road performance review, you will not get a salary increase. Unless if your kissing up!. Training is a joke, if you were not already aware of certain things , good luck with that! They set you up for failure, changes/ updates are communicated after being implemented. Management seem to encourage cheating, as they reward cheaters a lot more than hard working/ honest employees. Most of the immediate supervisors are not knowledgeable. They are unable to recognize and retain good employees. They cultivate an environment of threat and fear and this can demoralizing. The job is stressful and the reward are not non existent. If you are young, fast, do not care much, do not mind micro management, just starting your career, this may be the place for you. Otherwise look elsewhere.

review_title: Started well for the first year then it went downhill
pros:
Brand-name recognition
Good place to meet other people
Company matches percentage of contribution to 401(k)
cons: When I started working for Wells Fargo back in 2010, I was very excited to be part of a growing company as it was absorbing Wachovia.  Back then sales goals were very reasonable and easy to meet.  By the time I had left in 2012, the atmosphere had become beyond unbearable.  Every year Wells Fargo increases its quarterly sales quotas, but at the same time makes it harder for employees to meet their sales quotas such as having the customer actually use the product/service within 45 days.  With such difficulties, it is not surprising to see many employees lying to customers.  Like many reviews here, lower management only focuses on the volume of number of sales.  It does not matter if there are no customers coming into the "stores", but employees are still expected to meet their numbers.  Promotion is only based on sales numbers, and not true leadership skills or any relevant competencies.  If employees are not meeting sales quotas or getting all 5s on the insipid "wow!" system, they should expect to be micromanaged until they are forced to quit.  None of my co-workers who were still there a year ago remain.  Employee turnover rates are very high.  Customer service has been reduced to an oxymoron at Wells Fargo.

pros: Given the right branch manager and district manager, there are possibilities for advancement assuming your numbers are where they need to be (well above minimum performance).
cons: Often very formulaic interactions with customers, trying to find any possible way to fit every next customer into a box for one of the products at the bank.

pros:
The company does really embrace technology. When we went from Wachovia to Wells Fargo we were brought up to date.  The ATM machines we updated, we could give out instant debit cards, there were computers put into the lobby for customer.  The Wells Fargo intranet was easy to navigate as well. 

If you stick it out you can move up quickly, part of this was because of the high turnover rate in the branches. I do know many people who were unhappy in the branch but were able to move to the corporate side and liked that much better.
cons:
I came from the Wachovia world and the culture at Wells was much different than I expected.  The sales were very aggressive, and I was encouraged to sell products to people that I felt they did not need. I refused because I could not in good conscience mislead people who were trusting me with their money! We had three calls a day to see how many products or "solutions" we sold. There is so much pressure to sell sell sell it seems like people were pushed to find loopholes in the system and cheat and we saw many people (in some cases almost entire branches ) get fired for this.  

Also as a personal banker you really do not have much power to make any real decisions. I can not use my own judgement to refund an overdraft fee ... there is a computer tool that is used and in some cases you need management approval. My wire limits were lowered, I could not override a system decision on a check. I understand that it was for security, but for years I had the ability to do these things, I never abused it, I never caused a loss to the bank and it impacted the customer experience. 


There are many people who work for Wells and love it, but the culture was not a good fit for me.

review_title: Wells Fargo is unanimously the worst bank to work for in the United States. Many ex employees go to suntrust.
pros: bonus pay is good (if you are meeting outrageous numbers. I never was able to make payout.
cons: 401k matching doesn't start until after your first year of work. Management treats you like a number and if your not meeting your sales goals. you are criticized and pointed out in front of other coworkers daily!!! (supposedly it helps with motivation)

job_title: Project Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: The people in this group are amazing: Kind, smart, talented, patient, and have a desire to make projects a success.
cons: Managers in this group are just not skilled to manage. There is little awareness of what truly happens within the work teams and there is way too much concern in "managing up" so team members lack role models and advocates. Contractors come in and out through a revolving door. Contractors who are failing are still left in place to bring projects down as it takes months for middle management to notice anything is wrong. (Sleeping in the office, project neglect, being cruel to co-workers while showing a totally different face to management.) Worse yet, ineffectual permanent employees are left in place ... even when management has acknowledged the problem.  There is no effort to train those folks, or send problem full-timers to communications or management training to make things better. The open floor plan, which would work at most internet companies, is a nightmare here and interferes with productivity.

review_title: So much time and effort put into a job that only recognizes the people who arent doing things morally correct.
job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good benefits, company has the right idea of what it WANTS to be, get to meet lots of interesting customers,  opportunity to move into management fairly quickly.
cons: hourly wage kinda sucks for the amount of pressure put on for sales EVERYDAY, company says they want quality but they actually want quality, sales goals are unrealistic so that people do immoral things to get a bonus and a promotion, half the time those people get promoted and move on, the other half of the time people get fired at random and in bulk, youre forced to sell to family and friends and THE BIGGEST PROBLEM THAT THIS COMPANY HAS IS MANAGEMENT. The turn around rate sucks so bad because the management roles are filled by inadequate leaders with minimal experience in anything but sales, scheduling form these managers can be a nightmare as i got my schedule week to week and sometimes day by day. getting notice of a day off the day before i was supposed to have it..

review_title: Fairly decent company, enormous amount of bureaucracy due to federal regulations

cons: Horrible work environment, cramped work spaces, very little privacy between desks, promises of promotions that do not come through, low wages compared to industry averages, extremely excessive executive compensation

review_title: Good leadership and a great place to work
job_title: Vice President Technology Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: Strong people focus as a company in general.  Good IT senior leadership.  A lot of flexibility in hours and work locations.  Excellent overall compensation.  Very strong risk focus.
cons: SLOW!!!  Takes a long time to get things done.  A lot of bureaucracy and lack of good process management contribute to that.  Almost over the top risk focus, spend a lot of time in this area.

pros: decent benefits, lots of internal resources, decent work life balance, friendly co-workers, incentive bonuses are good motivators
cons: Pay is far below average for the industry, very short-sighted management even at the executive level, widespread layoffs are frequent, too big for its own good, low-cost model, record profits but can't hold onto employees. I wouldn't even bank here after my employment scenario

pros: long hours, long hours, long hous, long hours
cons: great pay, fun people, loved the job, would return to the job

job_title: Personal Banker I in Newark, NJ
pros: I love the hours. It gives a good work/life balance. You work your eight hours and you go home. You sometimes work a Saturday for three to four hours in the morning and enjoy the rest of the day off. Sundays are off. Starting salary isn't bad for a young professional. The products and services you sell are competitive enough to give you a fighting chance when winning over customers from rival banking institutions.
cons: This is not a financial position. This is SALES SALES SALES. I never feel like I'm truly helping someone. They at least did not sugar coat it when we were interviewed. I got into banking to help people financially, not force on them products and services they don't truly need because we need to hit goal. The goals themselves are not that easily attainable and I've seen my own coworkers and other managers NOT DO THE RIGHT THING for the client in order to meet goals. It shouldn't be like that. Wells Fargo "wants to do the right thing for the client and show them that we care" but forcing on people multiple accounts or closing old accounts for new ones and going through all the trouble of switching bills and direct deposits just to hit numbers is not the right thing. I've had elderly clients confused and hysterical about their social security checks missing, and when I research, it's because another banker closed their perfectly fine accounts and opened new ones to hit goals. Management hounds you for numbers. The training taught you nothing about being a banker. Every day I feel that if I don't participate in the shade, I will not hit my goals and eventually get fired. Benefits for my family are way out there, more than any other company I've worked with.

job_title: Phone Bank Supervisor in Charlotte, NC
pros: Great company to work with overall. Well known bank with opportunities worldwide.
cons: Hr limits the ability to develop loyal employees by limiting the ability to compensate high performers properly. Having these limit in place drives high performers to look at competitors who will compensate them at the deserved rate.

review_title: My experience there was positive for the first two months but became unbearable soon after because of the toxic culture.
pros: Great pay and benefits as well as flexible schedule.  My direct manager was great to work with.
cons: The work environment in the Houston Structured Finance was the absolute worst that I have ever been around.  There was so much gossiping, backstabbing, and bullying that it was hell working there.  I can't count how many times that I have comforted an employee who was crying due to how some of the people in management talked to their employees.

review_title: Great People, great culture. They truely practiced doing the right thing.
pros: Worked for Wells Fargo Home Mortgage on the wholesale division as an account executive. Good income, great people to work with. They really did the right thing and backed me up even when it cost the company thousands of dollars. I never soul have left if Dodd/Frank hadn't killed the mortgage brokering business.
cons: Very production oriented culture. You need to be ready to always increase your business. But that is sales no matter where you are at.

pros: Decent company to work for considering the benefits. The size of this institution makes it so no matter where you go you can likely transfer your employment to your destination.
cons: Leaves much to be desired. I was taken on a wild goose chase to secure a position as a teller. I was run through about 3 interviews while juggling a college schedule only to be given excuses such as my particular schedule was much like some other candidates making it a difficult fit. However, the recruiter appeared on my college campus recruiting more people from the same educational institution. Then I finally secured a position in a less than desirable location of town, which was totally opposite where I lived making my commute a 30 minute or more track across town. The values say the customer comes first, well if this were the case customer service scores should be considered when you're trying to move up. However, the only number that seems to matter when you're trying to ascend is SALES, SALES, SALES. AS OF TO DATE ladies and gentlemen I've applied for close to 30 positions within Wells Fargo only to be in the same position. I feel that may be because of the my local management at my previous branch I did finally get a transfer and I'm much happier. However, when I think of the things I've experienced my stomach is turned upside down. Then I think of all I was taken through to get the position I currently have and compare it to some of the most incompetent individuals I ever met that get tapped into higher positions with a handshake. I think the communication between recruiting and management are suffering badly or are non-existent. Great empires have come to ruin because of a lack of communication or effective use of such.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
- PTO Days
- Great environment with other co workers
- Manager will make or break the branch
- Learn a lot about bank operations and fraud
cons:
- Unrealistic sales goals: They expect way too much out of every banker when it comes to sales. Recently, they've placed a much bigger emphasis on quality (accounts being used and funded) but still keep the sales goals the same. I don't understand this at all, you can't place a big emphasis on quality and expect everyone to hit the same amount of sales. The reason employees were even able to hit the previous goals was because quality wasn't an issue. Now they just want it all

- Upper Management: Some markets don't have this problem but I've noticed that some District Managers have no idea what actually goes on in branches. Therefore, they think following the road map (a script to solve "customer's needs") will solve everything. I work inside a grocery store so most of the time when I have a customer sit down with me, they're in a hurry and have no time to fill out a CNA (Customer Needs Assessment) but Management believes this needs to be done with every customer, even people that are just coming in to get a temporary debit card. 

- Be consistent in promotions: I've noticed a huge trend with DM's that have their "Favorites," this is a big issue with promotions because I've witnessed on several occasions that some tellers that hit Bronze and Silver in sales don't get interviews to be a banker while others that don't even hit Bronze will get interviewed because they suck up. This type of behavior sets a bad example for the company and shows that your hard work and effort don't mean anything to management. 

- WOW should no longer be a metric: The primary reason I say this is because some bankers are more worried about pleasing the customer then actually doing their due diligence with identification and check verification therefore it leads to a lot more fraud. This happens a lot with new bankers especially.

pros: Offers a work environment which encourages enthusiasm and teamwork.  Management is very encouraging and understanding within reason.  There is opportunity for timely advancement if goals and standards are met.
cons: Hourly compensation was not worth the risk involved with dealing large amounts of currency on a daily basis.  After being robbed at gunpoint, it really put into perspective the deficiency in wage to risk ratio.

review_title: Service Manager-It has been an interesting experience with great times , and really bad times.
pros: Pay, bonuses, work relationships, lots of recognition. Opportunity for growth is always there if your hungry enough to chase it. However that takes total dedication of your entire life.
cons: Managers are promoted based on performance, not whether they have the proper skills to develop an effective team. Sales are pretty much the only priority. No support on career growth beyond retail.

job_title: Service Manager II in Tempe, AZ
pros: Meet a lot of great teammates that turn into friends.  Great to start out with a corporate company and to gain experience. Lots of room to grow and quick.
cons:
Extremely Sales Oriented and often times stressful. If working in the branch, you have a set amount of goals each month that needs to be hit. But what is frustrating is every month in particular January, aka Jumping into January, and July, aka Jetting into July they expect you to have 10-20 friends and family appointments, meaning, they expect you to have 10-20 friends and family open accounts with you. 

Working there is like working with big brother, depending on who your DM is. Every day you have a 10:00am and 2:00PM call which is pointless. The same thing is said every twice a day, every day. Where is your store at, why haven't you hit your goal, what will you do hit your goal. They expect you to pressure the customers into opening accounts. Many times, it becomes not being in the best interest of the customer because you are desperate to hit your goal. Not hitting your goals for the week or day, required you (if you are salaried, sometimes hourly) to work over-time and or weekends. 

The amount of money, lack of, that you get paid, is NOT worth the amount of sales stress and pressure and do not get me wrong, I am extremely sales oriented and sales is my niche, but not the way it is done at Wells.

In addition, if you have an issue with management and contact HR and or tell your DM, they don't do anything about it. I once encountered a hostile situation and I contacted my HR dpt and of course, since they were the manager of the store, they are in favor for them. Telling my district manager got me no where.

pros:
Competitive pay in the industry
Paid time off, holidays (even snow days!)
Great customer service, sales, and financial experience
No degree or banking experience necessary to land this high paying job
Mostly 9am-5pm M-F with one weekday off so you are required to work Saturday 9am-2pm
Overtime for employees is avoided by management which helps with work/life balance
Great training at headquarter office!
I've found the best employees/managers were from the Wachovia merge (They are much more customer service driven rather than cold sales)
Plenty of room for advancement with the high turnover rates
Many volunteer opportunities!
cons:
Insanely high sales pressure, which leads to desperate employees who do anything to gain a sale. This is encouraged and swept under the rug by management because they are now meeting their high sales goals. 
Leads to favoritism and poor customer service
A co-worker would intimidate people into signing up for services and lying to them to quiet their concerns. Those customers would come back requesting to speak with someone other than them to get clarity on what they signed up for and often closed those services. 
Managment was informed of these frequent occurrences from several employees and in the end, the employee was promoted for high performance! 
This creates tension and low morale for the remaining employees abiding by the rules and moral code.

I also had a bad experience when attempting to stay with the company part time and work towards my degree full time. I gave them 4 months notice to allow for the full time 2 weeks of training, as well. Management agreed and was happy to work with me, but constantly put off the change telling me not to worry, it would all be worked out in time. I began my classes while they finally reduced my hours and began the HR process of switching positions. It finally became a concern that I would be unable to complete the training with my busy schedule. There is a time limit requirement of when the training must be completed and I would not be able to reach it. I was so frustrated beacuse I had forseen this and my concerns were constantly disregared. They claimed that they would try to figure it out but I also found out that a favorite employee had also applied for this part time position that I had no idea I was even competing for.

review_title: Started Great, Company Is Losing Values
pros: When I first began at Wells Fargo I loved it. Even though quotas were very demanding, I enjoyed working there. Great coworkers, Sundays off, paid holidays.. I was a young teller who loved customer service which made me perfect for the job. I LOVED my managers and made amazing friends. My first two years were great.
cons: However, at times it would become a little too demanding to the point of abuse. Managers all played favorites. And I mean at EVERY STORE. If you're not a favorite, good luck getting ahead. In my three years I watched idiots in  different stores get promoted all because they were a favorite employee. As I moved up and became a banker it just became uglier. If you're good at sales it will be a breeze. I am a great salesperson. But after a while you start to see the same customers over and over. You're forced by management to still shove products and accounts down their throats even if they don't need it. I watched so many bankers lie and lie and lie to customers just for a sale and have watched customers walk out thinking they were set up with a free account when they were put into an account they will be charged for in 3 months. You are told to lie to customers. On top of this, it's such a stressful environment. You'll love your coworkers but all fight over sales. I have watched horrible arguments, and have even experienced coworkers calling HR and creating lies in order to get coworkers fired. I honestly, don't think I was paid enough for the stress I had to deal with. I was constantly stressing, I brought work home with me, and the quotas only increase making them impossible. You basically can't comp unless you have shady practices. I refused to be unethical which made it impossible to comp, but I don't care. At the end of the day I know I did what was right for the customer so if that means no bonus check, fine by me. The company doesn't give a crap about you. My coworkers and I were all miserable. I ended up quitting because I found a better job.

job_title: Phone Banker I in San Antonio, TX
pros: The training is long, but it prepares you for once you are out on the floor. Ken was a great instructor!!
cons: They have this saying "bring the business home" each & every call they want you to refer some type of product. They say they are helping the customer financial needs, but actually just making it worst. We get simple calls like what's my balance. & they want us to refer a credit card. To a person that is in the negative balance.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Lancaster, PA
pros: Best reasons to work for wells fargo would be the ability to establish your own client base. Also, the salary is always negotiable. There is always room for advancement.
cons: Wells Fargo is a highly competitive company. No one works like a team within your branch as well as other locations. Managers will do whatever it takes to stay above 5 in their district. That includes selling products to customers who do not need them and the list goes on.

job_title: Business Banking Specialist in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: easy promotions, some weekends off, coworkers are awesome, all lead lists are pre-scrubbed and no cold calling has to be done, lots of walk in traffic
cons: very high sales goals and pressure to do unethical things to reach them, extremely bureaucratic, so many reports have to be filled out daily just to prove to management that you are spending your entire day selling accounts

review_title: Glorified teller, sales goals are ridiculous.
pros: You get paid more that a teller. You get a nice "title". The only thing I like is that I get to order things like staples and have Internet access.
cons: Still have to meet sales goals on top of operation duties. Your conversations with customers are scripted. Management has an input for everything and are willing to write you up for any little thing.

job_title: Store Manager II in New York, NY
pros: I get paid bi-weekly and I have a job
cons: For the past several months the news meida has been correctly reporting about the "sales culture" at Wells Fargo and how the Bank is being sued.  Senior management feigns dismay at the unethical practices and claims that this will not be accepted practice at the Bank.  Well- nothing has changed. Try to remember your worst car buying expirience- the sense that you needed a bath after speaking with a salesperson. Now multiply that by 50 and you get the exprience of being an employee at a Wells Fargo Branch.  Part of the "sales" process is to review a customer opportunity with the banker when the customer is in the store. But it is a common occurance for a banker to add products after a customer leaves-things that were not asked for.  If you like 2-3 daily calls about your "solution sales and proxy reveune" be prepared to be belittled on calls with your peers if you don't hit your daily results.   We are told that we "don't manage by the numbers, but by behaviors" but the only behavior I can look forward to each day is a withering critique by an "Area Manager" . The avergae age in our stores is 25-why? Because they recruit from Verizon Stores the only skill a banker needs is the ability to BS a client into signing up for things they don't need. Accounts are opened up wrong and in violation of laws and regulations- but thats ok- you hit your numbers and stay employed. Ethics go out the window. Buyer beware..As a store manager be prepared to work 6 days a week, have conference calls each day at 8am and again at 6pm. Be prepared to work in a store that is short staffed due to turnover, and the staff that is in place is clueless

pros: Great health, dental, and 401K plan. If you're lucky to work in a branch with a laid back environment then your job is easy.
cons: They promote people with power tripping attitudes that love to micromanage everything you do. The sales goals are ridiculous, and the company continues to make legitimate sales not count. They make you say certain phrases during every transaction so you sound like a robot when talking to customers.

pros: Management is generally friendly, the job itself is pretty straight-forward. The benefits are pretty good for what the job is, and the work environment is fairly relaxed. There are also a decent number of opportunities for growth.
cons: The pay is on the low end of okay. Organization and communication is hit or miss at best. I feel as important and valuable as an office plant.

job_title: Business Relationship Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Good selection of products.  Full service bank
cons:
Sales goals that are unrealistic.  I had a call from an angry company CEO that had opened  a checking account and had received an unwanted debit card.   He didn't want anyone using a debit card to access the corporate account.   The person that opened the account had ordered the card so he could get two product sales rather than one.   It was not a great  start for the relationship.

Management is always trying to fix things that are not broken.  Stupid promotional gimmicks  that employees were expected to participate in.   Annually they provide stuffed horses to bankers who are expected to hand them  out as favors.   I had to take a stuffed animal to a CEO of a major corporation as a thank you for his business.   He looked at me  like "what the hell is this".  I was expected to report the on the success of this project which was another waste of time.

Management  is very inconsistent.    There is always something "extra" to do.  Just let employees do their jobs without the distractions.   FYI tellers are expected to sell  7 products each day.   Try cashing a $10 check without getting a sales pitch.  It won't happen.

They discriminate against higher paid experienced employees.   In my  department they fired 3 out of 4 experienced senior relationship bankers and replaced them with 30 year old kids at lower saleries.  The  person that replaced me hand not paid a personal visit to my largest client 6 months after he  took over my portfolio.  The client was offended.  Stepping over dollars to pick up  pennys.   There is a huge turnover.   After 1 year I had seniority  over half of the bankers in my department.

Finally, all ideas come  from the top down.   Suggestions for improvement  from non-management employees are ignored.   Management is actually offended if you raise an issue.  I pointed out that they were overcharging for Attorney Trust accounts and just about got fired.

pros: It is a big company so there are always perks.  They allow days for volunteering so you can use those anytime you want to with discretion.
cons: In the back office world management was not the best.  It seems terrible management comes from the top down.  There are many good managers, but many more horrible 1's.  Also there were no female managers at all.

review_title: Best career decision, so much potential to advance within company
job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Cherry Hill, NJ
pros: So much room to grow within the company. Tuition reimbursement, employee recognition, trainings, PTO days given at time of hiring
cons: I can't say there are any cons because of how easy it was to be successful in this position. If you're new to banking, definitely apply for a CSSR position as you will have loan goals being a PB

job_title: Communications Consultant III in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: With such a big company there are plenty of opportunities to work your way up, both in job role and salary. Great benefits for medical, dental and other. Tuition reimbursement as well. You are allocated at least 20 days off a year and it goes up with time served.
cons: HR is NOT on the employees side. If you get a manager you don't agree with, or who does not like you, they can fire you by just filling out the proper forms. They do not have to prove their "case" against you and HR offers no help.
